TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in-vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the senators in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the decision of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to conduct a private hearing into the affairs of Rothwells Ltd and its associated companies because of the Commission's belief that, `offences that involve fraud or dishonesty may have been committed'. I ask the Minister whether he has noted these comments by the Chairman of the Commission, Mr Henry Bosch, on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning:

QUESTION.PARA: I think there's a great deal of public concern and I think it would be more reassuring to the public for it to be seen that there is a formal investigation process going ahead immediately.

Does the Minister not agree that investor confidence in the operation of Australian financial markets would be greatly enhanced if any such inquiry into the affairs of the collapsed merchant bank were conducted in public? If so, what can the Government do to ensure that either the investigation or its results will be made public? If that is not possible, will it seek the agreement of the Dowding Government to a joint Federal-State royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—And answer my question of 4 November at the same time.

—I do not know what question that was. In answer to Senator Messner, I believe that the sort of investigation being undertaken by the National Companies and Securities Commission will be important in creating an atmosphere, an assurance, within the public generally and within the investing community in particular that the particular matters relating to Rothwells will be fully, quite impartially and vigorously investigated under the auspices of the National Companies and Securities Commission. It is a very important step that has been taken. I myself did not hear Mr Bosch on the radio this morning. In fact, I saw him at Melbourne Airport as I passed through coming up from Hobart. Whilst I spoke to him briefly about this matter, he did not raise the particular matters of concern which the honourable senator attributed to him as being broadcast this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, the particular investigation being undertaken by the National Companies and Securities Commission is appropriate to determine what action needs to be taken in relation to possible breaches of the relevant legislation. It has chosen to conduct a private hearing under section 36 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act into Rothwells and its associated companies. It is expected that that will provide a sufficient and proper venue and means for examining the wide range of questions surrounding Rothwells. Do not forget that the National Companies and Securities Commission, using this process, has the power to summon witnesses to appear before the hearing and take evidence on oath.

It is, of course, open for the National Companies and Securities Commission at any stage to request the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, or any State or Commonwealth member of the Ministerial Council, to arrange a special investigation. But the National Companies and Securities Commission has not made such a request or sought any such direction, nor has it requested further resources for its current investigation. In fact, that was the particular question, if I may say so, that I put informally to Mr Bosch at Tullamarine Airport this morning. He indicated that he considered that the Commission was sufficiently well placed to undertake this investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you be prepared to support a claim for additional resources, if necessary?

—I am prepared to ask the same question of Mr Bosch at any time and see what his response is, and consider what further action the Government might take, if required. I believe it would be quite premature--
—You ought to read the Estimates committee Hansard.

—I am relaying to the honourable senator an answer given to me by Mr Bosch in relation to this particular investigation. He says that the resources are adequate. I believe it would be quite premature to speculate on what further resources might be necessary if certain further events occur. This matter can be undertaken, I am assured by Mr Bosch, quite speedily in its commencement and vigorously, though, of course, it may take some time to actually be completed. I believe the National Companies and Securities Commission will report to the Ministerial Council, which I think meets later this week, on the status of its investigation and the anticipated scope of its hearing. That will take place, as I said, later this week.

ANSWER.PARA: I think one part of the question related to the possibility of public hearings. I must say that I am getting a little wary of public hearings where allegations are made before royal commissioners which perhaps are never substantiated and never lead to the laying of charges. My own experience in relation to the National Crime Authority and to the decision by the Senate committee which I chaired and which devised the structure and mode of operation of that Authority, I believe, is correct; namely, that on the whole these matters are best undertaken with the protection of privacy so that, whilst questions, of course, can be asked of a most penetrating and full kind, they are not asked in a way which leads to public exposure and allegations which, as I said, are not assessed in the same way in which they would be in a court of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister expressed concern about the rights of individuals. He might have some concern for the rights of the taxpayers of Western Australia. Would he not agree that the NCSC is limited in the extent that it can pursue matters which have now been identified, such as fraud and dishonesty and that, consequently, those matters ought to be pursued in public? Does he not agree that, obviously, the NCSC may not have the legal capacity to pursue those matters?

—I have already indicated that the NCSC is vested with very considerable power in relation to summoning witnesses and obtaining documents, questioning those witnesses and assessing those documents. I believe that it is vested with sufficient power. Indeed, as I say, neither Mr Bosch nor the NCSC has indicated to the Government that they believe that the investigation that the Commission may undertake under section 36 would be inadequate for it to determine the matters surrounding the management of the affairs of Rothwells Ltd. It is a very worrying matter, obviously, that Mr Bosch should speak about allegations involving fraud or dishonesty. I believe that the sort of investigation that the NCSC can undertake is the best process available at this stage for the investigation of those allegations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Government received a response yet to the representations it made to the Yugoslav Government following the shooting yesterday of a youth outside the Yugoslav Consulate-General in Sydney? Can the Minister advise the Senate how the matter is being dealt with?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already expressed the Government's very grave concern about the events which took place yesterday at the Yugoslav Consulate-General in Sydney during which a teenager was shot by a member of the Consulate-General staff. Without repeating the whole of that widely reported statement of last night, I repeat that the Government regards this incident as both intolerable and totally unacceptable. Whether or not, as claimed by the Yugoslav authorities, protective security by New South Wales police and others was not adequate is essentially a side issue which cannot begin to justify the use of firearms. I am advised that the security protection provided at the Consulate-General was composed of four Australian Protective Service officers and seven members of the New South Wales police force. I have asked my Department to report to me on the arrangements made for police protection of the Consulate-General and I will certainly follow up this aspect.

ANSWER.PARA: As I announced last night, the Government has stressed, both in Canberra and in Belgrade, the urgent need for the Yugoslav authorities to meet three Australian requests. These are, firstly, that the security officer concerned be made available for interview by the New South Wales police; secondly, that the firearm which was used-a question arises as to whether it was licensed-be surrendered to the New South Wales police; and, thirdly, that the security guard remain for the present within the Consulate-General premises and certainly not endeavour to leave Australia. I am pleased to report that the Yugoslav Ambassador, following his consultations with Belgrade, has this morning given an assurance that these three requests will be met. We have advised the New South Wales police accordingly and further investigation of the matter is now in their hands. I add for the record that no question of diplomatic or consular immunity for the officer concerned has been raised by the Yugoslav authorities. The handling of the matter is, accordingly, proceeding on the Australian side on the basis that no such immunity exists or will be claimed. I wish to assure the Senate, finally, that I am advised that appropriate measures are being taken by the relevant police authorities to ensure that there are no further acts of violence of this nature in Sydney or elsewhere.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister noted reports of the enormous storm damage caused in the Hervey Bay region of Queensland on Tuesday, 23 November, and costing an unofficially estimated $1m in damage to caravans and power lines, unroofed houses and uprooted trees? Is it the intention of the Federal Government to consult with its Queensland counterparts with a view to providing financial relief to individuals, families and local authorities adversely affected by the storm damage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to natural disasters generally, it is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth to consult with any State government. The declaration of this storm, or any other storm or drought, as a natural disaster is the responsibility of the State government concerned-in this case, the Queensland Government. In the event that the Queensland Government declares the Hervey Bay storm a natural disaster, expenditure, if any, of Commonwealth funds will be in accordance with the 1988-89 natural disaster relief arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: To date there has been no notification from the Queensland Government that it intends to so declare the Hervey Bay storm. It probably will not do so because the people affected by the storm, from Senator Jones's description, are not the sort of people who normally are favoured clients of the Queensland Government. Its favoured clients are people who are National Party of Australia organisers in north Queensland, such as Mr Michael Behan-who is no relation to Senator Michael Beahan, of course-and those who otherwise respond to the arm twisting of the Queensland Government to contribute to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is a convention on food irradiation to be included in the agenda of a forthcoming meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in Geneva? Who is representing Australia at this GATT meeting to handle discussion on this food irradiation convention and what are their occupation and governmental associations? Is Ms Jan Taylor, a pro-irradiation spokesperson from Queensland, attending? Will she be speaking on behalf of the Government and, if not, will this be made clear to the meeting? As a signatory to GATT, will the adoption of this convention on food irradiation bind Australia, making it mandatory for us, firstly, to allow the importation of food irradiated overseas and, secondly, to allow the establishment of food irradiation plants in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —An international conference on the acceptance, control of and trade in irradiated foods, sponsored by the Food and Agriculture Organisation, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the World Health Organisation and the International Trade Centre, is to take place in Geneva on 12 to 16 December. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is not a sponsor of the conference, although along with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development it jointly funds the International Trade Centre, which is, as I said, one of the co-sponsors.

ANSWER.PARA: The aim of the conference is to adopt an agreed document on the harmonisation of national approaches to the control of the food irradiation process and international trade in irradiated foods for consideration then by national governments. The conference is not scheduled to consider any draft convention under GATT. Any adoption of the conference document would have no effect whatsoever on Australia's rights and obligations as a GATT signatory.

As to representation at the conference, Australia will be represented by Australian Government officials based in relevant European posts. A number of different portfolio interests are obviously involved in this issue, and we have taken the decision to attend based on the principle, which may not be acceptable in this place but which makes some sense to me, that knowledge is to be preferred to ignorance when one is embarking upon a consideration of these sensitive issues. To avoid any concern that the representation of officials at the conference might be construed as endorsement of some particular substantive position by Australia, I have directed that it be made clear that representation at the conference should not be taken as support for the process and certainly also should not be seen as pre-empting the work of the parliamentary Committee.

With that in mind, I have set two conditions for Australian participation: first, that participation is to be without prejudice for the Government's consideration of the parliamentary Committee's report and the development of a comprehensive government approach to the question of food irradiation; and, secondly, that Australian delegates are to make clear that, pending the submission of the report of the parliamentary Committee and the consideration of that report, the Australian Government has not adopted a position on food irradiation.

As to the other lady the honourable senator mentioned, Ms Taylor from the Queensland Consumer Affairs Bureau has been invited in a personal capacity by the conference organisers to present a keynote paper. She will not be speaking on behalf of the Australian Government and, if necessary, this will be made clear at the meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a letter which was published in today's Australian Financial Review under the heading `Productivity not impressive'? That letter asserts that Mike Stutchbury was wrong in stating that a more intensive use of our capital stock `would perversely show up as lower labour productivity'. Can the Minister inform the Senate how a more intensive use of out capital stock affects recorded labour productivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the letter. It appears over the name of Andrew Peacock, but the level of economic literacy-for somebody who, by his own admission, does not bring an accountant's approach to Budget matters or into any sort of figuring-which is displayed in the letter is obviously far too high for it to have been Mr Peacock's own work. I suspect it was written by Dr Hewson, but he did not want to put his name to it lest it appear that he was trying to pinch Mr Peacock's job-which, of course, he is. The letter is, as I have said, economically literate, but it is wrong on the subject of the effect on recorded average labour productivity of a more intensive use of the existing capital stock. I should say here that it appears that Mr Peacock has used the third quarter of 1984 as the base for his assessment. The letter says:

ANSWER.PARA: A more intensive use of our existing capital stock, such as the working of extra shifts, would increase output and may result in an increase, decrease, or indeed, no change in labour productivity.

It is true that when an economy emerges from a deep recession there is scope for average labour productivity to increase, largely because there would under such circumstances be an oversupply of skilled and highly productive labour which is either not being utilised at all or not being fully utilised. In other words, there would be skilled labour on the payroll surplus to the immediate requirements of the firm. There may also be some capital lying idle. Once the economy has emerged from the recession-such a recession as the Australian economy had by the third quarter of 1984-the situation is different. If a manufacturing firm, for example-or a mine, probably, for that matter-wanted to put on a second shift, it would have to dilute its work force with a less skilled or unskilled work force, which would tend to slow the pace of operation, or there are likely to be more operations or perhaps some decline in quality. But the average output per worker would be brought down by that. Secondly, because once a second shift is being worked the plant and equipment is subject to more intensive use, it is likely to require more maintenance and repair, but simultaneously there will be less scheduled downtime in order for that maintenance and repair to be carried out.

In short, however, Mr Stutchbury's much more comprehensive argument on this matter was correct. The letter in this morning's Australian Financial Review was incorrect-whoever wrote it-at least in so far as that aspect of Mr Stutchbury's article was concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Government support the United States Government decision to refuse a visa to Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) Chairman, Yasser Arafat, to allow him to speak at the United Nations (UN)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government regrets the decision of the United States Administration to refuse a visa to PLO Chairman, Yasser Arafat, to enable him to address the current session of the UN General Assembly. The United States has an obligation under the United States-United Nations Headquarters Agreement to permit the entry into the United States of people engaged in UN business. Yasser Arafat was to address the General Assembly when it considers Middle East items in the coming week, something it has not done since 1974. Australia hopes that this issue can still be resolved in the appropriate forums, including the UN Committee on Relations with the Host Country.

ANSWER.PARA: We certainly acknowledge the concern of the United States about the involvement of the PLO in terrorist act. Australia has emphatically urged the PLO to comprehensively rule out the use of terrorism, most recently in statements that I and the Prime Minister made last week, and it is the case that United States citizens have suffered badly in recent years at the hands of PLO terrorists, but the refusal of a visa comes at a time when the PLO appears to be moving in positive directions, including towards the renunciation of terrorism and acceptance of Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, at least as the basis for an international conference designed to advance the settlement of the Middle East dispute.

The situation, I guess, shows once again the need for the PLO to take a further step to build on the welcome steps taken at the Palestine National Council meeting in Algiers, to renounce unequivocally the use of terrorism and to recognise explicitly the right of Israel to exist within secure and recognised borders. We will certainly continue to urge the Palestinians to take that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health undertake to ensure that supplies of stilboestrol tablets for the treatment of cancer of the prostate are available to patients until such time as an effective and practical substitute is readily available? Will the Minister examine the possibility of encouraging the import of stilboestrol from nations where its manufacture still continues.

—Senator Knowles was kind enough to give me notice of this question, which enabled me to contact the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, and get an answer to the question which I can now give. Hamilton Laboratories Pty Ltd, the only Australian manufacturer of stilboestrol tables, effectively ceased manufacture in July 1988 because of its inability to obtain full product liability insurance while stilboestrol remained in its range and at low profitability. As there is no current source supply of stilboestrol, I am unable to provide the undertaking requested by Senator Knowles. However, I will ask the Department to explore the possibility of obtaining supplies elsewhere. Meanwhile, alternative effective remedies are available, with pharmaceutical benefits, for the treatment of cancer of the prostate. Patients who have been on long term therapy with stilboestrol tables will still be able to obtain medication through the individual patient usage scheme.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will be aware of reports that following heavy monsoonal rains last week many parts of southern Thailand have been hit by mudslides and severe flooding. Will the Australian Government offer assistance to those injured and left homeless by this natural disaster?

—Honourable senators will no doubt be distressed to have read the reports from southern Thailand to the effect that heavy rains last week caused huge mudslides, killing several hundred people and injuring hundreds more. The reports say that illegal logging in the area has added to the devastation, as mudslides studded with logs are sweeping through low lying villages. An estimated 300,000 people have been made homeless and food supplies are becoming scarce, as the floods have cut off road and rail links. While Thailand will rely first on its own resources to assist the victims of this disaster, we have been advised of statements by the Foreign Minister and the Chief of the Armed Forces making it clear that the Thais would welcome external assistance. I have decided, accordingly, that Australia will contribute $200,000 in emergency relief from Australian International Development Assistance Bureau funds to victims of the flooding, the worst in Thailand for some 40 years. Australian relief funds will be used to provide assistance to those directly affected by the devastation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the current serious disruption at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA), the predicted increase in tourism into Australia and the need to service both that tourism and domestic air travellers, when will the Government stop procrastinating and heed the warning given last week by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines that the domestic airline system will collapse unless a third runway is built-a solution that would increase available capacity by some 40 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has made it clear that this question is being closely addressed by the Government in the context of the report that has just been received from the working group set up by the Commonwealth and State governments to explore what are realistic options financially, environmentally and in terms of the operational requirements of the whole Sydney basin. Delays at Kingsford-Smith Airport are mainly a consequence of runway capacity and overscheduling by the airlines at particular times of the day rather than any shortfall in air traffic control facilities. That point needs to be made because it is a recurring theme in some criticisms.

ANSWER.PARA: It remains our policy, as it had been for a number of years, not to build a third runway at KSA. We have taken the view that Badgerys Creek offers a more cost effective and ecologically sound solution to the airport needs of Sydney. It is certainly anticipated that, even with that development going ahead at Badgerys Creek, as we hope it will in due course-and sooner rather than later-KSA will remain the main airport for international and domestic airlines services at Sydney for the foreseeable future. The proposed international terminal extensions will meet Sydney's needs into the next decade and will be financed totally by the Federal Airports Corporation. No money will need to come from taxpayers' funds. Those international terminal extensions are not an alternative to the development of the second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek; they are complementary to that development and KSA will continue to remain the focal point for international services. The belief of the Government essentially is that provided progress starts at Badgerys Creek and there is some rationalisation and reorganisation, particularly of the very small aircraft that are using Kingsford-Smith Airport at peak times at the moment and very badly clogging the system, it ought to be possible within a relatively short time frame to establish an acceptable environment that will be consistent with the airport needs not only of Sydney but of this country as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of the question, which I thought the Minister would have taken on board, was the fact that Ansett and Australian Airlines made statements that said that the domestic airline system would collapse unless the third runway was built at Mascot Airport.

—The airlines are always making millenarian, dramatic and tub-thumping statements of that particular kind. It is the business of governments to sort out the wheat from the chaff, which we have done in the way I have described.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Given, first, the current low level of oil prices and, secondly, the consequent fears expressed by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd that this may have an adverse impact on exploration activity, can the Minister inform the Senate on the outlook for petroleum exploration in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the Senate on the outlook for petroleum exploration in Australia, which remains strong. In fact last Thursday I released a document, the quarterly survey of exploration and development statistics for the Australian petroleum, minerals and resource industry. That shows that offshore activity was particularly strong in the last quarter leading to the end of September, with 10 offshore wells being completed, the largest number of offshore wells drilled from an exploration point of view for over 2 1/2 years. Offshore exploration drilling is expected to continue at approximately that level for the December quarter as well. Eight offshore rigs are currently working in Australian waters, seven in the North West Shelf and Timor Sea region and one in the Gippsland Basin off Victoria, in the Bass Strait area, reflecting what I believe is the industry's belief that the best prospects for large oil discoveries in the future in Australia lie offshore.

ANSWER.PARA: I also released last week a revised assessment of the outlook for petroleum exploration activities in Australia in 1988, prepared by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. This shows that the outlook for offshore activity in 1989-next year-is strong, particularly in the Timor Sea, given a substantial number of wells already committed, numbering 33.

Senator Beahan refers in his question to low oil prices. Those who have followed the fortunes of the vicissitudes of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries in the papers in recent weeks will see that it still looks likely that we will be expecting for some time yet a difficulty in OPEC to maintain control over production levels and, because of the declining influence of OPEC, the overproduction as well of non-OPEC countries. When we add that to a very mild northern winter and the fact that the market is currently overhung by about 30 million barrels of oil per day across the world, we expect low oil prices to remain for some time. Notwithstanding that, the types of statistics I have been able to give show that there is still strong activity, even in the context of low price, in Australia. Parliamentary Question
Response to question asked by Senator McGauran on 24 November concerning Trade Practices Commission decision relating to South Australia newsagency distribution system.
Last Thursday Senator McGauran asked me a question without notice concerning a recent decision by the Trade Practices Commission relating to newsagency distribution arrangements.

I indicated at the time that I was not aware of the decision by the Trade Practices Commission to which Senator McGauran referred and that I would seek further information. As the Attorney-General has the responsibility for the Trade Practices Act I have sought his advice.

Before turning to the particular concerns raised by Senator McGauran, I should say something briefly of the history of the Trade Practices Commission's consideration and examination of newsagency arrangements over recent years. As many Honourable Senators will recall, the Trade Practices Act of 1974 established an authorisation procedure whereby anti-competitive conduct, such as newsagency monopoly arrangements which would otherwise breach the Act, could be authorised by the Commission on public benefit grounds. Amongst the many applications for authorisation which followed the coming into force of the 1974 Act were applications in respect of various newspaper distribution arrangements in each State.

Pending an examination of those arrangements, the Commission granted interim authorisations. Since then, the Commission has progressively undertaken a detailed examination of each State. South Australia is the last State to be examined in detail and the Commission's decision of 14 November is the outcome of that examination.

Where the Commission's authorisation of the South Australian arrangements differs from those that it has made in relation to other States-and this is one respect in which the decision has attracted a good deal of attention-is that it removes the monopoly presently enjoyed by authorised newsagents in South Australia over retail sales. This aspect of the Commission's authorisation, coupled with its announcement that it will now undertake a national study of newsagency distribution arrangements, has led to some expressions of concern in other States that the retail sales monopolies presently authorised in those States will be also reviewed.

Senator McGauran has pointed to concerns by some family newsagency proprietors that any flow through of the South Australian decision to other States would have an adverse financial impact on the value of those businesses. It is worth noting in this regard, however, that there were many newsagents and other small retailers in South Australia who argued before the Commission that the monopoly should go.

For those who have these concerns I think it is necessary that attention be drawn to a number of important aspects of the Commission's authorisation in respect of South Australia and its decision to undertake a national study.

First, it needs to be borne in mind that the situation in South Australia differs from other States in regard to home deliveries which, in South Australia, are generally not tied to associated retail monopolies.

Secondly, the authorisation in respect of South Australia provides for compensation to those newsagents who will be disadvantaged by loss of this retail monopoly. An independent committee is to oversight compensation payments.

The third point I would make is that the national study will be carried out under the general research provisions of the Trade Practices Act and will not of itself have any legal effect on the currently authorised newsagency arrangements in any one State. Moreover, I would expect the Trade Practices Commission in its usual way to welcome and encourage the making of submissions by interested persons, including of course parliamentarians and small business people such as family newsagency proprietors.

For its part the Government will follow the progress of the inquiry closely and give consideration to the making of its views known to the Commission. That will, of course, be a matter for the Attorney-General to consider in view of his responsibilities for the administration of the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, you and other honourable senators will be aware that later this session we will be debating a series of Bills relating to triticale. I have found there is a great deal of ignorance as to what triticale is. Some have thought it was a city in South America; some thought it was an exotic device. So that honourable senators will be more informed when the Bills are debated, I have brought along a sample of the triticale plant to show the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Triticale Notes

Triticale is the name of a cereal developed by crossing wheat and rye. Normally such a hybrid of these two cereals would be sterile. In 1948 the hybrid triticale was treated with the chemical agent colchicine which caused the chromosome number in each cell to double and enable it to become fertile. The resulting plant was octaploid, that is it contained sets of chromosomes. The parent rye plant was diploid (2 sets of chromosomes) and the parent bread making wheat was hexaploid (6 sets of chromosomes). Later durum wheat, a tetraploid wheat (4 chromosomes) was crossed with rye to produce a hexaploid triticale which is what most modern cultivars have been developed from. The name triticale is a hybrid of the genus name for wheat, Triticum, and the genus for rye, Secale.

There were many problems in developing a commercial crop. Early plants were tall like rye and susceptible to flattening in storms. The seed set and grain yields were poor and the seeds were prone to sprouting in humid climates. Triticale took too long to ripen in the tropics because it was developed in temperate areas where it required long day length to mature.

Research into these problems continued in different parts of the world. In 1967 researchers at the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT) in Mexico developed a strain of triticale that was both short and not dependent upon a long day length to mature. The first triticale cultivar called Rosner was released in 1969 by the University of Manitoba in Canada.

Triticale is more similar to wheat than rye in the appearance of the plant and the protein and starch content of the grain. It contains higher levels of the amino acid lysine which is relatively low in most cereals. Its bread making characteristics are better than those of rye but poorer than wheat in that pure triticale flour does not produce very light breads or pastries. It is used in animal feed and newer varieties don't appear to contain the anti nutritional factors found in the parent rye.

Under optimal conditions triticale can produce grain yields at similar levels to that of wheat. In 1974 triticale from a field in California produced 9890 kg/ha, which was comparable to yields of the best wheats. In 1985 average yields were in France were 6 tonnes/hectare (t/ha) but in the USA the average yields 2.5-4 t/ha and in Australia the yields averaged only 2 t/ha.

The differences in average yields may relate to the fact that triticale is often planted in more marginal areas where it is seen to have an advantage over wheat. It has been claimed that triticale has an advantage over the best breadwheats in highland areas, in acid soils and in areas where drought tolerance is needed. As well it was considered to be highly resistant to rusts.

However Australian experience doesn't bear all these claims out. There is no evidence that triticale varieties in Australia survive drier conditions better than wheat or that they are resistant to stem rusts. Under irrigation, yields of 6-7 t/ha have been achieved but at the cost of breakdown in disease resistance. Varieties of triticale have been shown to do well on heavy soils and in acids soils with aluminium levels. The acid soils are increasing in Australia so a crop capable of growing under these conditions is important.

Most of the triticale in Australia came from the CIMMYT program in Mexico but some varieties have come from Eastern Europe to be used for dual purpose production of grazing the crop twice during winter and then growing out to grain with a slight loss in yield. The triticales from Eastern Europe and Canada grow in a protrate form during winter which allows them to be grazed with little damage to the plant's grain producing potential. There is still little planting of this winter habit in Australia. Often significant areas of triticale have been used for fodder production, especially in dry seasons.

Significant commercial production of triticale commenced in the late 1970's. Initial varieties didn't meet the expectations of the farmers and after rapid expansion in the early years the area planted has stabilised over the the past few years. Newer varieties have been more acceptable. The area sown in Australia in 1986 was 148,000 ha and this yielded 270,000 tonnes. Yield of triticale has consistently lagged behind that of wheat in most years in NSW. As mentioned earlier this is probably due to major sowings in marginal conditions, especially in acid soils.

Most of the triticale grown in Australia is used as animal feed, mainly for pigs and poultry. Some triticale is exported from WA to the Middle East but most is used on the domestic market. In 1983 only 50 tonnes of the 188,000 tonnes produced was used for human consumption. Triticale has a somewhat aromatic, nutty and sweet flavour, is a good source of fibre and can replace wheat flour for some people suffering from wheat allergies. It is cheaper than imported rye and can be used as a substitute in some products. Present uses are the incorporation of flakes in muesli, the use of flour and whole grains in specialty breadmaking and the manufacture of triticale macaroni. It still has not had wide community acceptance.
