INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 28 November, from Senator McLean:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The requirement for the Federal Government to initiate immediately such restructuring of Australia's Defence Forces as will-
(a) address all dimensions of the crises in defence effectiveness, morale and economics;
(b) bring Australia to a position of Armed Neutrality but with a modern, competent, mobile and flexible Defence force able to protect our national integrity if under attack;
(c) maintain and demonstrate a strong nuclear free stance;

(d) integrate our defence and other forces into potent dual civil/military roles and structures such as to render them of immediate relevance and visibility through such roles as fire fighting, emergency services, rescue, coastal patrol, drug surveillance and others; and
(e) support trends away from vast expenditures on armaments which reflect assumption of global conflict and thereby increase the likelihood of such conflicts.
Yours sincerely,
Paul McLean
Senator for New South Wales
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The requirement for the Federal Government to initiate immediately such restructuring of Australia's Defence Forces as will-
(a) address all dimensions of the crises in defence effectiveness, morale and economics;
(b) bring Australia to a position of Armed Neutrality but with a modern, competent, mobile and flexible Defence force able to protect our national integrity if under attack;
(c) maintain and demonstrate a strong nuclear free stance;

(d) integrate our defence and other forces into potent dual civil/military roles and structures such as to render them of immediate relevance and visibility through such roles as fire fighting, emergency services, rescue, coastal patrol, drug surveillance and others; and
(e) support trends away from vast expenditures on armaments which reflect assumption of global conflict and thereby increase the likelihood of such conflicts.

I am sure that all honourable senators-I may have to modify that and say some honourable senators-will agree that the state of our Defence Force is a matter of urgency which affects us all. Morale is at an all-time low, wastage rates are astronomically high and there is widespread dissatisfaction with conditions, both for serving personnel and for veterans. The Government's failures range from the petty to the profound. It still refuses to correct the 2 per cent discounted Defence Force retirement benefits; the repairs and maintenance budget for defence housing is appallingly low; some recommendations of the excellent Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses have yet to take real effect; and the Government, abetted to a degree by the Opposition, appears to be on a policy course which downgrades the status of veterans in our community.

There is real fear that after the next election the Department of Veterans' Affairs may be disbanded altogether. Our serving personnel are not stupid. They can see how the Government-sadly, with the assistance of the Opposition-views them and how much help they can expect at the end of their service. The fact that they are unimpressed is reflected in the current crises, especially in the resignation rates.

These factors and others, resulting from decades of neglect, not only by this Government by also by its predecessors, and a lack of imagination in the relevant portfolios are leading to the rapid disintegration of Australia's Defence Force. None of us want this. Some of us can see a clear solution. The Government has recently released several reports. I have here four substantial reports that have been released in the last 18 months to two years. These reports are ambivalent and contradictory documents which on the one hand acknowledge, yet on the other hand deny, the crises. None of these reports propose the type and scale of change that will redress the problems. I have here four reports. One, entitled The Management of Australia's Defence, was tabled in the Senate towards the end of last year and was acknowledged by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats as being an utter indictment of the management of our defence forces. The Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities was to be the foundation upon which a new, restructured and potent Australian Defence Force was to be modelled but, sadly, that is not proving to be the case. We have the recent Defence Report of 1987-88 and the document tabled in the Senate last week, entitled Personnel Wastage in Australia's Defence Forces-Report and Recommendations. The wastage phenomenon is the most indicative symptom of the utter devastation of our defence preparedness.

The Government's failures range, as I said, from the petty to the profound, and there has been much comment on them. The Australian Democrats believe that the only solution is to alter radically the structure and operation of our Defence Force. We live in a nuclear age, yet in an essentially peacekeeping country. Because of that we must shift our defence thinking, organisation and materiel from the offensive to the defensive and from the predominantly military model to the predominantly civil defence model. But under no circumstances must we allow ourselves to remain defenceless-the position in which we now find ourselves. As I said a moment ago, the most severe sympton of this defencelessness and the importance of our Defence Force lies and is recognised in the alarming level of personnel wastage from the Australian Defence Force. On page xxv of the foreword to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the Committee says:

The Committee does not support the Department of Defence's conclusion that wastage is of concern only in `some specific specialist areas'. That kind of assessment pays insufficient attention to the qualitative aspects of wastage, as well as understating the overall effect and extent of numerical losses. Our assessment is that there is cause for concern across a wide range of ranks and skills, in the following general and specific groups:

The report mentions male trainees, male officers, junior officers, project officers, Army corporals and senior non-commissioned officers, Royal Australian Navy Officers of the rank of commander and below, Navy engineers, Navy principal warfare officers, Navy technical sailors, Navy submariners, Army officers of the rank of major and below, signals corps officers, Army soldier specialist tradesmen, Royal Australian Air Force engineers, Air Force pilots, Air Force technical airmen, and flight engineers.
These are the aspects of our Defence Force personnel structure which it says are in tatters. The report continues:
The extent and magnitude of wastage in some of those areas is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.
Of course this document is a profound indictment of what has prevailed in the planning of our Defence Force, not only by this Government but by previous governments.

The Australian Democrats advocate armed neutrality as being by far the most effective moral and appropriate position for our Government to adopt. Neutrality is a status recognised under international law. It is divided into transient and permanent neutrals. Permanent neutrals such as Sweden, Switzerland, Ireland, Austria and Finland must stay out of all wars and must follow policies in peacetime which enable them to do this. These countries cannot accept any obligation which would impair their neutrality in war. How would armed neutrality affect Australia? I quote from a paper on the subject by David Martin, author of a book called Armed Neutrality for Australia. He says that Australia:

. . . would have to withdraw from the ANZUS treaty. It could no longer station RAAF squadrons in Malaysia. It would have to end `defence arrangements'-which include the gift of arms and war material-with Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines and Papua New Guinea.
Australian units could not exercise with foreign fleets, armies or air forces, or grant overflight rights to American bombers.
Australia could not be host to foreign or jointly-controlled military bases. No Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape `facilities'.
Australia could freely supply aid to anti-colonial movements in Africa, to Afghan resistance fighters, to Solidarity activists in Poland, but not if that aid could be misused for military purposes.

Australia could train foreign officers, so long as their countries are internally and externally at peace. It could not link itself to a trade grouping like ASEAN, which has strong military implications, but could enter an essentially trade-centred Pacific Community.

In developing his thesis concerning armed neutrality, he goes on to address other ways in which armed neutrality would affect Australia and to address the question of whether we would have to have conscripts to sustain a position of armed neutrality which was such that we would be able to protect ourselves adequately against foreseen threat. He answers the question profoundly by saying:

No, since we don't need million-strong forces to confront superpowers. In this, too, we are luckier than Sweden and Switzerland. Modern defence thinkers estimate that from 150,000 to 250,000 properly trained reserves are what we want.

We could get these by adopting the Voluntary Latent Service system, first detailed by Dr Ross Babbage. It relies on the voluntary annual enrolment of approximately 20,000 to 30,000 carefully chosen and well paid volunteers. They would undergo intensive training-not of uniform length, since different specialities demand different schedules-and return for updating courses in succeeding years. They would then become militarily trained civilians, a democratic, semi-professional militia. They would be under contract to answer a call-up within 14 days.

If they remained `on tap' for five years, we would have reserves of 150,000, if for eight years, 240,000 to flesh out our small standing army. The personnel would be sufficiently well paid and trained in specialties to make the service attractive to highly motivated people. The system would be adaptable, affordable, and easy to run. Training costs would be higher than now, but not if measured against the returns. There would be no rejects or drop-outs.
That is from David Martin. How would armed neutrality affect Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe it?

—Of course I believe it, otherwise I would not be here now advocating it, unlike some members of the Opposition who stand up and mouth things that they do not believe in. If you, Senator McGauran, had had the time or the interest to review the Hansards you would have seen that from the time I was elected to this chamber I have advocated this case over and over again. It is simply an extension of the crisis in which we now find ourselves exemplified in that document-once again, if you had the interest to read it-which was tabled in this chamber last week. You should not just flippantly open your mouth with some casual interjection which is supposed to have some significance.
—Order! Address your remarks through the Chair, Senator McLean.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. If Australia became a permanently neutral country we would not need to be totally self-supporting, although we would naturally follow the same policies we have now of becoming self-reliant as far as possible and as to the manufacture and maintenance of defence capital equipment and materiel. Although other neutral countries such as Switzerland and Sweden find that they have to rely upon conscription to provide the numbers of Defence Force personnel they need, we are in a more fortunate position strategically than they are. We should be able to get by with an increased Defence Force through voluntary enlistment as well as a well-trained reserve of 150,000 to 250,000 committed, well-trained reservists.

SPEECH.PARA: Armed neutrality is a realistic, sensible step for Australia to take. New Zealand is already moving in that direction. The sooner it is given genuine, detailed consideration, the better. Of course by far the most controversial, aspect of armed neutrality is the concept of non-alignment. It is important not to confuse non-alignment with isolation. The former in no way implies the latter, and to argue that it does would be dim-witted, stagnant thinking and again unimaginative.

In recent months in this chamber I have attempted to project some new thinking into the area of defence. We must move towards new integrated models of defence based upon both civil and military defence thinking, models which would provide for increased and substantially improved morale within the Services by making their tasks more relevant and visible. Many Western European countries employ their defence forces in non-military tasks. One example is Austria, which employs her defence forces in mountain and air-sea rescue, as frontier police, for disaster relief, as police reinforcements and for fire control reinforcement. Similar undertakings are typical of the Belgian civil military defence forces. In Denmark they undertake mountain and air-sea rescue, coastguard work, and disaster relief. In Finland they undertake mountain and air-sea rescue, coastguard work, frontier police work, disaster relief, and reinforce police and fire control authorities. I could go on to illustrate what happens in Greece, West Germany, Norway, Portugal, Spain and Sweden, all of whom have a much more modern approach to the structuring of their armed forces than we have in Australia.

On the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald honourable senators will have read further revelations of the continuing debacle of our coastal surveillance program. The whole area of coastal surveillance is one which could and should be handled by our defence forces. Honourable senators might recall that in January of this year the appropriate Senate committee called for submissions on coastal surveillance. Senator Coulter and I made one such submission in which we made proposals which we believed were forward thinking. To this stage they have not been acknowledged as even having been submitted to the committee. I will now quote from a part of our submission to that committee. It said:

The problem of protecting the lawful integrity of our territorial sea, especially its northern portion is just one to which the solution suggested here would make a major contribution. We believe the need for `northern surveillance' so-called has been improperly analysed and wrongly perceived.

The development of over-the-horizon radar has meant or will shortly mean that most `surveillance' will be conducted without physically going and looking. On the contrary physically going and looking at a vessel engaged in an illegal activity merely tends to frighten it back to international waters. If the only method of interception remains naval patrols which take some days to reach the position of the sighting, little is achieved for a great deal of expenditure.
In the submission that we made to the joint committee we went on to say:
It is argued here that a rapid and effective interception capability is the primary requirement and that the Canadian CL 215 amphibious aircraft meets such a requirement.

There are many other national problems to which this aircraft could make a very significant contribution. The cost of these aircraft make it unwise to purchase them for one purpose only. However, using them for the multiple purposes outlined here would make their acquisition quite cheap.
The other problems to which the CL 215 offers significant solutions are:
1. Sea rescue including retrieval of persons from offshore installations, islands and ships for medical treatment.
2. Maintenance of offshore installations-lights, buoys, drilling rigs.
3. Bushfire and fire fighting.
4. Maintenance of a naval air arm.
5. Greater peace-time role for military forces and consequently better rapport between military and civilian personnel.

We went on to comprehensively propose the purchase and use of the Canadian CL 215 in just one of the numerous civil-military defence roles which clearly should be undertaken by our newly structured defence forces. The Government's approach has been to pass this vital role to private companies which are now squabbling over this prize and employed in legal action between themselves and against the Federal Government. Clearly such a role is one for a new wave defence force suitably equipped with the Canadian CL 215 aircraft.

The Australian Democrats argue that we are facing an unprecedented defence crisis. It must be addressed now and it can best be resolved by profound lateral and bold rethinking of how best to reorganise our defence, both civil and military. We therefore call upon the Government immediately to establish a task force which objectively examines alternative defence models such as those that I have cited, which are widely spread and in use in overseas countries, and ensures the adequacy of Australia's civil and military defence now and into the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a Government member to speak on this motion moved by the Australian Democrats. At the outset I wish to indicate that an amendment which will be moved on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Newman when she speaks, is acceptable to the Government. I will leave Senator Newman to explain the details of that amendment. I must say that this motion could be more seriously treated if it did not attempt to do everything in both defence and foreign affairs and be everything to everybody in the world. I really find it extraordinary that at one level it calls for increased expenditure on defence armaments and for services to the defence forces and yet in paragraph 5 it calls for a reduction in expenditure. I cannot see how it can call for independent, non-aligned, neutral defence forces in Australia without having a substantial increase in defence expenditure. I believe that that is the great weakness of this urgency motion and that is why I will be opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some comments about why we in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) support the general Western alliance and, in particular, our alliance with the United States of America. It has been the policy of the Labor Party since 1942; it has been generally debated in our Party on many occasions; and, on every occasion, the overwhelming majority has supported Australia staying a part of the Western alliance and the American alliance.

I think the superficiality of the Australian Democrats' motion calling for a neutral, non-aligned Australia has to be carefully examined. Although it may give them a warm inner glow and may give some people in sections of our community a chance to beat a hairy chest about how strong Australia can be, it does not deal with a couple of fundamental positions that Australia faces in the world. First of all, we have to accept that Australia is a democracy. The Western alliance is overwhelmingly made up of countries that are committed to the same cultural, political, social and economic values as is Australia. It would be very difficult for Australia culturally to align itself with a large number of countries of the Third World which are one-party states, which in some cases are totalitarian and which in many cases have human rights abuses that we in Australia rightly condemn. But if we talk about neutrality and non-alignment, as is suggested by the Democrats, presumably we would be applying to join the non-aligned movement or the third force in global politics. Even if Australian people were interested in that proposition, when they saw the cost to Australia, not only politically but also economically, they would reject it.

Senator McLean talked about the way in which Australia could have a non-aligned, neutral Defence Force. He said we could do this by having what I would describe as a militia of 150,000 people. That would mean a substantially increased cost to the Australian defence budget. He raised all these matters because he could not get over the great weakness of his argument: if we want a neutral, non-aligned Australia, completely separated from any other alliances, we will have to create a much larger defence force in order to convince the Australian people that we are capable of defending ourselves. The only way to do that would be to introduce conscription which is the case in countries such as Sweden and Switzerland. We could not avoid it. I do not believe that it is necessary to have conscription in a country such as Australia. Once we went down the road to conscription and a much greater defence capability we would be starting to develop a military industrial complex that would end up leading us into ventures such as the Vietnam war. One of the reasons the Americans went into the Vietnam war was that they had developed a large military industrial complex-something that President Eisenhower warned against in one of his last major speeches.

If the Australian Democrats want increased government expenditure and taxpayers resources going into the Defence Force, they should say so. They should also bite the bullet and say that they would introduce conscription.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they got conscription after they were in the Vietnam war, not before.

—The Democrats would have to introduce conscription if they wanted totally independent armed forces in Australia. Senator McLean in his speech used examples of other countries that we can look to. He said that Sweden has been neutral for a long time. There is much that I admire about Swedish society; much of it is an example that we in Australia can look to. But when we talk about neutrality in Sweden we should not forget that, during the Second World War, although Sweden was neutral it had no objection to large amounts of its iron ore being sold to the nazis in Germany-iron ore that was used to make weapons and to build concentration camps.
—Australia sold iron ore to Japan.

—Senator McLean uses the example of Japan. I do not think he should. At the time the ALP condemned what the then conservative government of Australia was doing in selling iron ore to Japan. We gave the correct warning. But Senator McLean has used Sweden as an example of the way we should go. He has said that it is neutral and non-aligned and referred to its moral position. There is much that I admire about Sweden but it should not be forgotten when Sweden sold iron ore all through the Second World War to the nazi war machine. I point out also that, in 1940, when Finland was invaded by the Soviet Union, the Swedes did nothing to help their fellow Scandinavians. They sat by and stayed neutral when a country was overtly attacked and suffered much in that war. Senator McLean also used the example of Switzerland. Switzerland has been neutral and non-aligned for a great many centuries.
—I am asking you to look to the future.

—The honourable senator used the examples of these countries to justify a position of neutrality and non-alignment. Switzerland is one of the very few countries that refuse to join the United Nations-an international body which I would have thought even the Democrats would support.
—Especially the Democrats.

—Perhaps, then, the Democrats can explain why, if neutrality and non-alignment are so good, Switzerland is refusing to join the United Nations. Senator McLean then talked about other neutral and non-aligned countries. Should we follow the Indian example? India is neutral and non-aligned, but guess what it has? It has atomic weapons and it refuses to sign the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. If India is a wonderful example of what neutrality and non-alignment means, as far as I am concerned the Democrats can stick that example, because India has nuclear weapons. That is one of the aspects of its non-aligned and neutral policy.
—Give us an Australian example; tell us how good we are.

—Senator McLean might not like it but I am trying to explain to him that, when he raised his wonderful examples of neutral and non-aligned countries, he should have looked very closely at their foreign and defence policies. India, a major force in the non-aligned movement, has nuclear weapons. It has policies on nuclear weapons that I trust the honourable senator's Party would totally oppose.

SPEECH.PARA: Another country that plays a big part in the non-aligned movement is Cuba. Whatever we may say about the success of the Castro revolution in 1959, which got rid of the very nasty, right wing, corrupt Batista regime, unfortunately in the last 15 years Cuba has acted as the de facto armed forces for Soviet foreign policy in various parts of the world. It stands up and says that it is a member of the non-aligned movement, yet it has armed forces in various parts of the world. I mentioned in the Senate only three weeks ago that I was in Eritrea in Ethiopia in October. Guess who helps the Ethiopian regime and advises that regime in a military capacity to bomb defenceless citizens and civilians in Eritrea? It is Cuban military advisers based in Ethiopia. So we have another example of a country that is neutral and non-aligned but has policies that all right-minded people, including, I hope, the Democrats, would disagree with. So the Democrats should not tell us that being neutral and non-aligned is the wonderful way to be in the world because, unfortunately, there are overwhelming examples of neutrality and non-alignment in international politics having been the opposite of what the Democrats have proposed.

I have already mentioned the Democrats' great difficulty in explaining to the people why we will not have to have conscription to provide a defence force capable of showing that, even though we are not a party to the Western alliance, we can defend ourselves. Until Senator McLean addresses that position with clarity for the Australian people, urgency motions such as the one he moved today will be a nonsense.

Senator McLean also attacked the present Government over its defence policies, and I presume that Opposition speakers will accuse us of being deficient in some areas of defence. I want to put on the record the opinion that people should recognise that the Australian Labor Party in government has usually done more for the defence capability of this country, going right back to the Fisher Government. Despite conservative opposition in 1910 and 1911 it established an independent Royal Australian Navy. During the Second World War it was the Australian Labor Party that had to takeover the government of this country when the conservative government of the day ended up as a rabble and could not carry out Australia's war effort against nazism in the world. Our defence achievements have always been to enhance our defence self-reliance. In only five years we have done a number of things to establish-and I hope Senator McLean would appreciate this-a defence force that can look after the defence of Australia in the general context of our alliance arrangements. For example, instead of buying submarines off the shelf overseas at considerable cost to our balance of trade we are going to build submarines in Australia-I am pleased to say in my State. It will give us a long range strike capability which will be one of the best in our region. We have continued the decision of the previous Government to purchase F18s which, again, improves our long range strike capability. We decided to introduce in-flight refuelling, to update the F111 which also has the strike capacity of the PC3 Orions. We have a strike capacity in our region that is our first level of defence. I would think all of those achievements are ones that the Democrats would not try to besmirch but would welcome as an ongoing development. We do have a self-reliant defence force.

I now refer to foreign affairs. One paragraph of the motion refers to a strong nuclear free stance. The Democrats should sometimes give us some credit. I am not saying that they should give it all the time; I understand politics. They have to appeal to their own base to achieve their quotas to get elected, but I thought it would have been quite reasonable to mention and to give credit to the achievements of this Government over the last five years. Firstly, we signed the nuclear free treaty for the South Pacific. That is an achievement which Senator McLean and the Democrats have done nothing but harp on, saying that it has not gone far enough. If it were not for a Labor government there would not be any Australian involvement in a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific.

I do not hear the Democrats congratulating this Government for the fact that at every United Nations General Assembly meeting each year for the last four years it has proposed a comprehensive test ban treaty on nuclear weapons. I point out to Senator McLean that in that last vote, which was only a few weeks ago, on a motion sponsored by Australia and New Zealand, 127 countries voted in favour, six abstained and only two were against. That was an initiative of this Government in the United Nations which has given us and the Australian people a recognition around the world that we are leaders in achieving nuclear disarmament. I just wish that occasionally the Democrats would give us some respect for that achievement.

The Democrats say that we are totally obligated to the Americans in foreign policy. I point out to the Democrats that although we are part of an alliance with America and the general Western alliance, there are a significant number of foreign affairs issues on which we have publicly disagreed with the Americans. They know it; we know it. We have explained that our relationship with the Americans is a mature relationship, and we do disagree. An example of that was shown today at Question Time when Senator Gareth Evans put on record the Australian Government's disagreement with the Americans in refusing to give a visa to Yasser Arafat to visit New York to address the United Nations General Assembly. It is on the record that we disagreed on an issue to which America is extremely sensitive. I would like to list for Senator McLean some of the areas where we have disagreed with the Americans over the last five years. We have from time to time expressed our opposition to America's policy on Central America, particularly as it relates to Nicaragua. We have supported the Contradore policy. On most of those occasions I never saw any Democrat spokesmen making a public statement in support of the Government's position when it opposed the American policy on Central America. I do not see too many Democrats jumping up and down supporting us. In 1983-84 when Bill Hayden was attempting a very courageous initiative to get a settlement in Kampuchea, which was in contradiction to American policy and to the Association of South East Asian Nations policy, the Democrats did not support us. We tried very hard. It is only now that much of what Bill Hayden was putting forward is proving to be correct. As I said, we disagreed with America on Kampuchea. We disagreed with the Americans over the strategic defence initiative. We made it quite clear that we thought it was unnecessary and that it was destabilising. We disagreed with the Americans over the MX missile proposal in 1984. In 1983 when the Americans invaded Grenada we indicated that we did not support that invasion and the way it was carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —All that wasn't worth a jot.

—I suppose under Senator McLean's position with a neutral and non-aligned policy he would be wanting to send a battalion to Grenada to fight the Americans, or he would want to send a battalion into Kampuchea. What position would he have influenced? With a neutral and non-aligned policy no-one would listen. If Senator McLean's policy were put into effect the Democrats would be the moralising irrelevant group in Australia of which no-one would take any notice. If they want to have Australia made irrelevant in the world as a middle sized power we will carry these sorts of nonsensical contradictory motions. The Democrats keep putting them up; we will keep knocking them down. They are irrelevant to the strategic defence and foreign affairs policy needs of Australia. I hope that at some time in the near future the Democrats will try to come to terms with the fact that Australia is a middle sized power with an independent foreign policy, with a self-sufficient defence force. If this sort of junk motion were carried it would mean at one level that we would cut defence expenditure and at another level we would be asked to have an independent, non-aligned defence force. The Democrats want-and it will never work-a pacifist defence force and an aggressive foreign affairs policy. I do not think the Democrats can have it that way. If we want to be influential around the world we have to participate in multilateral affairs at all levels. We have to negotiate with people in the diplomatic area. We also have to back it up with a self-reliant defence force; not with the pie in the sky that the Democrats want, which is to cut expenditure and then say, `We want a neutral and non-aligned Australia'. I ask the Senate to reject this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 February this year in an earlier debate on defence policy an honourable senator said:

SPEECH.PARA: A long time ago I reached the conclusion that politicians should not be the formulators of defence policy.

The speaker on that occasion was Senator McLean. If ever I agreed with him I agreed with him on that statement. When one looks at what he has put forward here as the Australian Democrats' policy for defending Australia, I am appalled to think that this simplistic and irrelevant nonsense could come from the pen of a former serviceman, an officer in the Australian Regular Army. I am very disappointed. I could not believe that Senator McLean could allow the Democrats to continue to live in cloud-cuckoo-land as he has done. What Senator McLean in his urgency motion is saying is that we need to fix up all the problems in our Defence Force which boil down to money, morale and effectiveness, and to do that we have to aim for a force which can defend us when we are attacked, but we have to do so without any assistance from our friends which means that neither our friends nor ourselves have any nuclear capacity. The Opposition is very supportive of the Democrats when they recognise the problems in the Defence Force today. The Opposition does not, however, go along with them when they suggest ways of dealing with it.

I am disappointed that the urgency motion was framed in the terms that it was, because clearly if Senator McLean had chosen other words we could have supported him thoroughly. In the past he has supported my urgency motions with regard to the effect of the Government's run-down of the defence capacity of this nation. But he has combined our genuine concerns about the morale and the effectiveness of our Defence Force with this incomprehensible approach taken in this motion, which states that expenditure on armaments is likely to increase the likelihood of global conflicts. He wants to turn our defence forces into some kind of mother's milk peace corps. His motion refers to the maintenance of a strong nuclear free stance and the bringing of Australia to a position of armed neutrality. For goodness sake, that cannot be the country that I think is worth defending. Senator McLean is a former Army officer. I wonder where he got all that garbage from.

The Democrats, by way of their motion, urge us to support their demands for a unilateral disarmament of the democracies while our enemies can retain their offensive capacities to their heart's content. The Opposition utterly rejects this as a dangerous approach to the defence of this country and one which will undermine our defence capacity. Senator Schacht has already referred to the amendment which I hope to move. I foreshadow the use of a contingent notice of motion which will affirm the maintenance of our alliances, particularly those with the United States, and reject a unilateral approach to disarmament and arms control.

Having recognised, by implication, that we are having trouble with the effectiveness of our defence forces through a lack of resources and mobility and the dilution of experience, the Democrats would have them take an even greater role in fire fighting, emergency services, rescue, coastal patrols, drug surveillance, et cetera. To cap it off, they would redirect expenditure away from armaments, which they claim increase the likelihood of conflict, as I said before. I reiterate that that is an infantile and simplistic approach to matters of enormous national moment. I am glad that Senator Schacht talked about the irrelevance and superficiality of that approach. I welcome the Government's support for my amendment. I look forward to it placing on the record the need to maintain our alliances and not go down that unilateralist disarmament path.

Let me place on the record what is the situation in our defence forces. As I said earlier, the motion contains a few sentiments which we would have supported had they not been surrounded by so much nonsense. Our defence forces do lack a surveillance capacity. We have problems in seeing what shipping comes into our waters. As we know only too well, we constantly have uninvited visitors. We have problems with planes travelling in our air space, and we are lucky if we find out about it afterwards. We have a lack of capability in getting our forces over beaches. We need to increase our amphibious capability. We have constrained establishments. When the Government does not have enough manpower to meet the jobs to be done, it just writes down how many men it will need, and then it does not look as though it is managing quite so badly. We need to deal with the problems of constrained establishments and low manning levels.

We do not have sufficient air cover for our ships when they travel further out to sea. That means that we will not have protection for our trade in times of harassment or war. We have a lack of protection for our infantry. We would have to send them in without air cover or artillery cover. It is a dangerous and disgraceful exercise to send in light infantry without the sort of back-up needed. One of our most serious problems-the others are more noticeable, but this will be a long term problem-is that we have too high a proportion of men with too little experience. The Opposition has been trying to warn the Government about this matter for a couple of years.

I remind the Senate that a couple of weeks ago the Cross report-a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-was handed down. It said that the present level of wastage in our defence forces is substantially too high and has been for some time. It also stated that that would be a most dangerous practice to allow one key element of our defence capabilities to degrade past a certain level. We need to implement all actions simultaneously; that is, we need to maintain capital equipment; we need to maintain our operational capacity; and we need to maintain our personnel levels. I have dealt with the issue of morale in the past. I do not have time today to go into it in great detail. It relates to the problem of job satisfaction, the problems of pay and allowances, and the problems of bureaucratic management of the Defence Force. It relates to the lack of political and service leadership and to the need for improvement in family well-being. It even concerns the problems of lack of personal equipment for servicemen doing the job.

The motion states that the dimensions of the crises involve economics. The defence budget this year was $7.6m. Of that, 29.1 per cent was spent on capital equipment, only 43 per cent was spent on personnel, and operating costs are supposed to represent 27.9 per cent. Earlier Senator Schacht referred to the shopping list of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) which would be fine if it were not being achieved at the expense of our personnel and their operational costs. Let me remind the Senate that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation talks about running costs of 8c per person per day. We are prepared to spend only $1.25 per person per day to defend the country. Mr Dibb recommended expenditure of 3 per cent of gross domestic product. We are not spending anything like that, but for an extra 10c per person per day we could reach that amount. We are prepared to spend $3.80 per person per day on social security. I leave honourable senators to draw their own conclusions.

We need to shift the balance in the defence forces. It is not good enough to cancel exercises for the rest of this year and to cancel promotional courses. There will be a shortage of 750 corporals this year. People are not being promoted to corporal because we cannot afford the money to train them for their promotional exams. Adventurous training is also being cancelled. Army vehicles are being put off the road for one day a week for the rest of this year so as to deal with the fuel bill. As I said the other day, the Government has even cut out parsley from the meals provided to personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it, Senator? What are you proposing?

—I would be very interested to know whether Senator McLean has anything positive to say, because he talked a great deal of waffle. I would rather tell the Senate that there are problems with flying hours with the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). We are unable to provide any more live firing support by the RAAF for the Army. There are problems with insufficient equipment and training. We are cancelling training. These are pretty serious matters. The Opposition would have supported the Australian Democrats if that is what their motion had been restricted to. But the Democrats have gone on with a great deal of nonsense. Soldiers are short of combat rations, compasses, binoculars, 7.62 mm linked ammunition, shells, mortar ammunition, and radio sets. There is a shortage of unimog trucks, telephone sets and night vision devices-to mention only a few items. This is a disgraceful exhibition by the Government. We would have been happy to join with the Democrats in supporting the motion condemning this situation. However, this motion which Senator McLean has brought forward is totally unacceptable for the reasons I mentioned earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to make sure that our servicemen are competent. They will be really competent only if they have been able to stay in the forces after about six years' training. That is not happening now. We need to be able to take the M113 project off the backburner and ensure that servicemen get to their destinations with protection. Black Hawk helicopters are not enough to protect them; we need the M113s as well. We need to take the landing craft out of mothballs. We need to fully utilise the amphibious capacity of HMAS Tobruk. We have to make sure that the Navy is flexible and can get out to sea with appropriate air cover. We need to be able to refuel the FA18s and the F111s if we are to achieve maximum flexibility of our Air Force.

Let me draw attention to what could be the outcome of the Democrats' motion. Let us look at the capacity in the Warsaw Pact countries and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) countries. The nuclear deterrent has managed to achieve peace in spite of the fact that there is an enormous discrepancy between conventional equipment and weapons production in the Warsaw Pact countries and the NATO countries. At the moment-this came out of the statement on the Defence Estimates by the United Kingdom Secretary of State for Defense just recently-the figure for the main battle tanks for the Warsaw Pact is 28,900, and for NATO it is 11,500; the figure for other armoured vehicles for the Warsaw Pact is 48,500, and for NATO it is 19,150; the Warsaw Pact figure for field artillery, mortars and rocket launchers is 32,550, and for NATO it is 6,550; the figure for technical combat and interceptor aircraft for the Warsaw Pact is 9,400, and for NATO it is 6,750. The ability to stay at peace despite those enormous discrepancies in arsenals is what the nuclear deterrent has managed to achieve for us.

The Opposition has no intention of cutting off Australia's future defence options. I am glad that Senator Evans, in the debate on 4 November on my motion about the visits of nuclear warships, said that United States military support would be forthcoming and mentioned how important it was to the Government. I have no time to direct the Senate's attention to further quotations on this matter.

This is not just a question of covering our own backs in having these alliances. It is our responsibility as part of the global network of seeking and contributing to world peace. It is something I had hoped the Australian Democrats would have had some sympathy for. Senator Evans, in the debate I mentioned earlier, was very specific when he said that these alliances do improve our ability to defend our region. It improves our credibility. It is not just a question of looking after Australia. Our region is the stronger for maintaining those alliances.

Senator McLean should know better than most people that the Defence Force cannot spread its efforts too far and too thinly. The hours that our servicemen already work are too long. They work about 58 hours a week, and service personnel leave the Defence Force as a result. Senator McLean should know that the maintenance of the aim is a principle of war. In other words, keep it simple stupid-which might apply to the Democrats in trying to teach them how to approach a defence matter. We should not divert our efforts from the main goal, which is to defend Australia.

In referring again to the Democrats' unilateralist line, I point out that they say that by being well armed we are increasing the likelihood of global conflicts. The truth is that history has proved them wrong over and over again. People died in the Second World War because of those policies. At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be addressing my remarks specifically to points 3 and 5 in Senator McLean's urgency motion. In the debate several days ago on foreign bases on Australian soil, I developed the argument that a dependence on nuclear weapons is counter-productive. A nuclear defence is no defence, firstly, because one cannot use it and, secondly, because dependence on nuclear weapons diverts enormous resources from other non-nuclear options, including spending more on foreign aid to reduce international tension. It thus leaves Australia more vulnerable to attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has come to rely heavily and, the Democrats believe, foolishly on close links with the American military machine. The Americans have aggressively nuclearised their military capability. Australia has therefore come to rely on nuclear weapons for the defence of this country should there be an attack on us beyond the mere trivial. It is extremely unlikely that the United States of America could or would come to our aid unless the United States itself was under threat.

As has been pointed out repeatedly, and as our Government has now conceded, the presence of US bases makes Australia a first strike nuclear target. Senator Newman naively suggested the other night-I think she has repeated this implication today-that we must make ourselves a nuclear target in order to prove our friendliness to the United States. What nonsense!

The Opposition in the same debate repeatedly misrepresented our position as unilateral disarmament. One of the reasons for today's debate is to explain that armed neutrality is not, in any sense, disarmament. Armed neutrality is not disarmament any more than Sweden, also pursuing a position of armed neutrality, is disarmed. The position we are putting is this: a non-nuclear, effective, non-aligned, defensive-in contrast to offensive-military capability with integration of the civil and military roles of the defence forces and with greater emphasis on targeted foreign aid so as to reduce international tensions and reduce the possibility of armed conflict.

It is our belief that, far from destabilising a precarious balance between superpowers with itchy fingers and fallible computers poised above nuclear buttons, the adoption of this position-the position we are proposing-by a progressively larger number of countries would make it easier for the superpowers to negotiate an arms reduction. We reject as a non sequitur the claim that, because there has not been an armed conflict between superpowers in the last 40 years, mutually assured destruction, or MAD, was the only way this could have been achieved. We point to the hundreds of wars and armed conflicts throughout the world over this period of 40 years, which have been caused and exacerbated by the profligate diversion of resources by the industrial world into armaments. It has certainly not been peace.

The claim by Senator MacGibbon the other night, that the placing of short range nuclear rockets in Europe was the only strategy that could lead to the recent arms reduction agreement on these weapons, is another non sequitur. As for the argument that the world has been peaceful since 1945, in that time there have been approximately 130 wars, with casualties of between 19.5 million and 21 million people. Since 1945 the frequency of war has been increasing. So, at present there are 40 wars or armed conflicts in progress. Some peace since 1945!

It is our strong contention that the policy we espouse, if adopted by Australia and progressively promoted to and adopted by other nations, would make for a more peaceful world. An important component of that strategy is to swing more resources into targeted foreign aid so as to reduce the causes of war. According to the United Nations group of government experts on the relationship between disarmament and developments:

There can no longer be the slightest doubt that resource scarcities and ecological stresses constitute real and imminent threats to the future well-being of all people and nations. These challenges are fun- damentally non-military and it is imperative that they be addressed accordingly. If this is not recognised, . . . there is a grave risk that the situation will deteriorate to the point of crisis where, even with lower probability of success, the use of force could be seen as a way to produce results quickly enough. This is far from being a remote possibility. In recent years, there has been a marked tendency in international relations to use or to threaten to use military force in response to non-military challenges to security.

Thus, the diversion of resources by the industrialised world to military purposes is directly impoverishing the underdeveloped world and increasing the risk of armed conflict. Global military spending is now well in excess of $1,000 billion. That is a million million dollars a year. This is more than the total income of the poorest half of humanity. It represents the equivalent of almost $1,000 for every one of the world's one billion poorest people.

Put another way, military spending surpassed the combined gross national products of China, India and the African countries south of the Sahara. Moreover, global military spending has risen not only absolutely but also proportionately, from an estimated 4.7 per cent of world output in 1960 to over 6 per cent, representing an increase of over 150 per cent in real or constant price terms. Three-quarters of current expenditure is in the industrialised world. The true cost of the arms race is the loss of what could have been produced instead with scarce capital, labour skills and raw materials. The plants that manufacture weapons, the transport of these weapons and the mining of minerals for their production all place enormous demands on energy and mineral resources and are a major contributor to pollution and environmental deterioration.

The distorting effects of the arms culture is most striking in the deployment of scientific personnel. Half a million scientists are employed on weapons research worldwide, and they account for around half of all research and development expenditure. This exceeds the total combined spending on developing technologies for new energy sources, improving human health, raising agricultural productivity and controlling pollution. Military research and development-$70 billion to $80 billion worldwide in 1984-is growing at twice the rate of military spending as a whole. At the same time there is a paucity of resources available for monitoring global climatic change; for surveying the ecosystems of disappearing rainforests and spreading deserts, and for developing agricultural technologies appropriate for rain-fed tropical agriculture. The US Agency for International Development reported that El Salvador-what a cruel irony that name has proved to be-is one of the most environmentally impoverished nations, with some of the worst soil erosion rates in the region. I quote that report:
The fundamental causes of the present conflict are as much environmental as political, stemming from problems of resource distribution in an overcrowded land.
President Eisenhower observed at the end of his term in office that:
. . . every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired represent, in the final analysis, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, who are cold and not clothed.

There are, of course, no military solutions to environmental insecurity. As I said a moment ago, the world is spending over $1 trillion a year-or more than $3,000m every day-on military purposes. An action plan for tropical forests would cost $1.3 billion a year over five years. This annual sum is the equivalent of half a day's military expenditure worldwide. Implementing the United Nations action plan for desertification would cost $4.5 billion a year during the last two decades of this century-the equivalent of less than two days of military spending. One of the greatest environmental hazards in the Third World is lack of clean water for household use, contributing to 80 per cent of disease. The United Nations Water and Sanitation Decade, although given only a small fraction of the support needed, would have cost $30 billion a year during the 1980s. This is the approximate equivalent of 10 days of military spending. To supply contraceptive materials to all women already motivated to use family planning would cost an additional $1 billion per year on top of the $2 billion spent today. This additional $1 billion is the equivalent of 10 hours of military spending.

Four of the most urgent global environmental requirements relating to tropical forests, water, desertification and population could be funded with the equivalent of less than one month's global military spending. Much of the industrialised world has become a prisoner of its own arms race. It is time Australia broke out of this prison. We could contribute far more both to our own security and to the security of the world as a whole were we to do so.
