SPEECH.PARA: In the short time I have available this afternoon I want to go through a little of the history of Australian security requirements. I start with the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities in 1985 and the aims behind it and I will go on to talk about points (2) and (3) in the urgency motion. I think the aim behind the commissioning of the Dibb report in 1985 was to establish a comprehensive overall approach to Australian defence that would implement the principle of defence self-reliance. The Dibb review drew together all the separate considerations of self-reliance over the last decade and a half and proposed an achievable and cost-effective future policy. The review said that the prime national task of the Defence Force should be the defence of what it called our area of direct military interest, which if defined is the whole of the Australian land mass and its approaches out to about 1,000 nautical miles. The review went on to describe the basic elements of a capability to defend this area of direct military interest: a comprehensive surveillance and interdiction capacity in the north and across the whole span of our northern approaches; aerial mobility for the ground force; a greater commitment of defence resources in northern Australia; the establishment across the continent of proper infrastructure and support for the Defence Force; and greater use of reserves in meeting our immediate defence requirements and as a base for expansion. These capabilities will provide us with the capacity to meet the credible forms of military threat that could arise.

The Dibb review set down our defence priorities-Australian defence priorities. It proposed a system of secure defence for this country, not on the basis of what other countries wanted or needed, but based on a consideration of the most credible threats to Australia and the capabilities needed to counter these sorts of threats. At a time of economic difficulty-to put it mildly-for Australia, at a time when we have a particular responsibility to the Australian electorate properly to order our defence priorities, the Government believed that the Dibb review gave us the means of doing so, based on the pretty fundamental principles of self-defence.

In 1984 David Martin, the author of Armed Neutrality for Australia?, said in discussing Australia's capacity for self-reliance that Australian forces lacked three basic essentials: first, a structure flexible enough to meet the challenge of continental defence; secondly, enough trained reserves to provide a surge capacity in the event of hostile escalation; and, thirdly, means of effectively integrating these reserves into the regular forces. Whether that analysis was appropriate in 1984 is debatable. Certainly, it could not be asserted in the post-Dibb era. The scheme of capabilities proposed in the Dibb review, essentially drawing on existing resources with some modification, provides a comprehensive capacity for continental defence and in particular emphasises the fundamental place of the reserves in our security planning. The Dibb approach is one of comprehensive defence in depth-over the horizon radar and possibly airborne early warning aircraft for surveillance of our northern approaches; FA18s, F111s, submarines and surface elements of the Navy for intercepting threats in our approaches; a mobile army readily deployable across Australia; and reserve units trained for surveillance, northern defence, and the maintenance of expansion skills in tank warfare and medium artillery.

Australian defence doctrine in future years will bear a strong resemblance to that which was detailed. The review identifies capabilities essential for proper self-reliance and central to a responsible Australian defence policy. As outlined in the review, defence self-reliance is here to stay. Australia has an obligation both to itself and to its region to build a defence force with a basic capacity for self-defence. The Government believes that an Australian Defence Force which is able to deal effectively with the least unlikely challenges to this nation's sovereignty will contribute substantively to the continued stability of our region.

The most obvious factor arguing against neutrality or non-alignment is our self-interest in maintaining the American alliance. Non-alignment or neutrality would, of course, abrogate our formal ties with the US. A security alliance is only meaningful if, as well as representing some commonality in attitude, both parties have the necessary day to day self-interest to preserve it. From Australia's point of view it is the cost saving benefits of the US alliance that make defence self-reliance for Australia affordable. Fundamental to the effective development of a self-reliant defence force is comprehensive, intelligence cover of our area of primary strategy interest. Whilst we possess significant indigenous capabilities in this field, it is access to complementary US intelligence, and particularly access to US satellite intelligence, which we could not afford to duplicate, that assures to us a comprehensive knowledge of regional developments relevant to our security. This confidence in our regional intelligence cover allows us to order our defence priorities according to credible threats and the timescale in which they could develop.

Looking at the other major cost-saving element of the alliance, many of the most important items in the Defence Force's inventory are purchased in the United States. The FA18s, FFG frigates and F111s are a few examples, and other vital capabilities, such as the indigenous Jindalee OTH radar, draw heavily on our access to US research and experience. By virtue of the alliance we have access to the latest military technology and hardware. The availability of US military technology means, effectively, that our Defence Force will remain a qualitative jump ahead in regional terms for the foreseeable future.

There is one other difficult to quantify area that emerges as an indirect benefit of our alliance relationship. This relates to what might be termed the insurance and attrition element of an armed and neutral posture. At a minimum we would require a major increase in the permanent store of key war stocks, including difficult to store precision guided munitions. Were resupply from an ally in doubt, this would be essential. Israel's experiences in this regard in 1973 are indicative and instructive. More costly in the insurance area would be the additional requirement for multiples of our major equipments. What we have now is probably enough, but a successful pre-emptive attack on our forces could start to make 100 front line aircraft and 14 warships seem rather paltry. Certainly Australians would never be convinced that we had enough in these circumstances. Access to ready resupply from an ally largely eliminates this concern from Australian debate.

Finally, though we encourage defence manufacture and export, our policy now maintains a disciplined relationship between our industrial base and our contemporary requirement with a limited expansion capacity for war time. To be self-sufficient in our defence effort, particularly in high technology areas, would require a massive injection of funds. If honourable senators do not like how we now look as a defence exporter, think of what we might look like if we went into a Swedish defence industry mode.

The cost-limiting aspects of the US alliance are a major stumbling block for alternative theories such as armed neutrality. One proponent of this strategy for Australia, David Martin, has estimated that a one per cent rise in the proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) allocated to defence annually would be sufficient for Australia to replace from its own resources the benefits inherent in the US alliance. Even assuming that he is correct, and there are reservations about an increase as small as that, when seen against the 2.9 per cent share of GDP defence currently receives, that one per cent increase adds up to $3 billion per year. Whilst there is longstanding majority support in Australia for an effective defence force, there would be a real question of community acceptance-to put it mildly-should the Government propose such an increase for defence. In addition, some vital capabilities, such as access to US satellite intelligence and military know-how, simply could not be replaced by greater government outlay. It would not be possible, even with the allocation of all our budgetary resources. The alliance with the US is thus vital to our capability to achieve a self-reliant defence capability.

That is far from the alliance's only contribution to our security. The US alliance and joint facilities helps to keep the nuclear peace, and so protect Australians from the most serious threat to their national survival-global nuclear war. The joint facilities undoubtedly make nuclear war less likely. Those who argue that the joint facilities should be removed have to show how Australians would be safer if nuclear war were more likely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by Senator McLean on behalf of the Australian Democrats is a most peculiar motion. One part of it has something in it, but the other four parts of the motion reveal the Australian Democrats in their usual light, that is, proponents of nonsense, of part understood ideas picked up and put forward in a most peculiar and unreasonable manner. I find it very difficult to discuss Senator Coulter's contribution-it did not seem to bear any rational relation to defence-so I will not do so. I will talk about Senator McLean's contribution because at least he addressed the matter in a slightly more coherent way.
—Only slightly.

—Yes, only slightly more coherent. I agree with the first part of his motion-that the Government should, as a matter of urgency, address all dimensions of the crises in defence effectiveness, morale and economics. There are real crises in this area. The manpower situation and the morale situation are very worrying. In the five years since the Australian Labor Party Government came to power, of our Defence Force of roughly 70,000, 45,000 have voted out with their feet. The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, pretends that there is no problem. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) even went so far as to say in August this year that the high number of resignations was good for morale. Good for morale! The high resignation rates cause great disruption of the Australian Defence Force. Training costs go up enormously. If there is a constant personnel turnover, training costs increase, which is a great drain on the available defence budget.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a loss of experience. Untrained or inexperienced people hold critical jobs. There is a loss of available effectives. If too many people are undergoing basic training there will be that many fewer people available for the jobs which require experienced, trained personnel. I will give the Senate a couple of examples of the mess this Government has created. In the last five years we have lost 300 trained pilots. A fair assessment of how much the training of those 300 pilots would have cost would be $800m-that is, $800m of wastage by this Government. To try and overcome the wastage, the Government introduced a bizarre scheme to give pilots $70,000 each if they agreed to stay on for a period. That scheme had problems. One problem was that other defence personnel of at least equal skill and importance could not see why the pilots got $70,000 to stay on and they did not. Worse still, the scheme did not work because the pilots who stayed-the helicopter pilots-were not going anyway, and the fixed wing pilots left to join the commercial airlines as they were always going to do in the first place. That is typical of the way this Government is mishandling defence.

There are so many areas where things are not working out properly. Pay is inadequate. For the first time in history our officers are now being paid less than British officers of equivalent ranks. They receive $10,500 a year less than equivalent British officers. There are problems other than pay, although that is important. There is a general feeling that the Government is not interested in defence, that it does not care about defence, that defence is a nuisance it must put up with-`Let us do as little about it as possible'. The Government does not care about the people who make up the Defence Force. If it has to have something, it wants showy capital projects. Too much of our resources are going into that area and too little are going into keeping contented and efficient the people on whom an effective defence force depends.

I will not go into all the matters that are causing concern because the debate does not allow sufficient time for that, but I will itemise a couple. People in the Defence Force, pay 5.5 per cent of their salary as a compulsory contribution to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits fund. If they leave before they have completed 20 years of service they get their contributions back with no interest. Defence housing is a disgrace.

So many other support systems are needed for the very special problems in the Defence Force, and I itemise just one to show the way the Government is making a total mess of it. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has been very vocal about her efforts in the education area. It is good that she recognises there is a problem but the publicity and the reality do not match. She has talked a lot about tuition allowances. Out of 30,000 married personnel in the Services, only 27 children are receiving a tuition allowance-and the Minister makes a big deal of it. If she had said this was just a start we could see that, although very little was being done, the situation might improve; but she thinks this is a wonderful achievement. This is typical of the great problems that effect our Services and the morale of personnel. They are things that this Government seems unable to comprehend and tackle, but they must be tackled in the interests of the defence of this country.

One other area this Government cannot tackle is defence management. Recently a joint committee reported on the organisation of the Department of Defence. The report was severely critical, and correctly so. The report was unaminous from the members of all parties. It was not a partisan report; Government and Opposition members all agreed that the structure and organisation of the Department of Defence were a disgrace. The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, rejected the report. He talked about having creative tension between the public servants and the defence officers. There is certainly tension, but I think it would be a very peculiar person who thought it was creative. What we have is divided responsibility between public servants and trained defence personnel. Unqualified public servants have responsibilities which they cannot effectively carry out. We have grotesque overmanning in the Department and over-ranking in the Defence Force. As an example, the Army now has 65 officers of the rank of brigadier and above, the Royal Australian Air Force has 48 air commodores and above, and the Royal Australian Navy has 43 commodores and above. There are very few operational appointments for any of those people. For instance, the Navy has only one operational job for its 11 rear admirals, and it has no sea jobs for its 30 commodores. The result is that we have these people manning committees, matching themselves up with public servants, and being involved with all these interminable committees and organisations of the Defence Department-and they are not in current operational training.

The whole rank structure has gone astray and the reason is that the public servant-defence rank matching has been grotesquely skewed. The public servants are brought in one or probably two ranks too high and that has caused a necessary matching explosion in the number of senior officers in the forces. That is a problem that the Minister just must tackle, but it seems he will not. The organisation is a disgrace. The only way to sum up the situation is by an old Greek saying: `Give mine enemy a golden sword'. I think a modern version might well be, `Give mine enemy an organisation like the Australian Defence Department'.

That is where, up to a point, I agree with what the Australian Democrats' motion says. Let us come to where I start disagreeing. The motion refers to the importance of defence effectiveness and morale, and it then says we must:

Integrate our defence and other forces into potent dual civil/military roles and structures such as to render them of immediate relevance and visability through such roles as fire fighting, emergency services, rescue, coastal patrol, drug surveillance and others.

I presume the `others' would include the Boy Scouts. What we cannot do if we have a highly trained professional force and we wish to maintain efficiency and morale is dissipate members of that force around as aids and all sorts of other things. Certainly in moments of extreme crisis that may happen, but we should not expect them to be auxiliary firemen, auxiliary drug surveillants or auxiliary rescue people. If that does happen, we will not have an efficient, professional force. It is a possible role for the half-trained conscripts all over the place, but it is not a role that is compatible with the high morale, professional Defence Force which we have now. So there is a gross internal contradiction in the Democrats' motion.

There is worse to follow. The Democrats want to bring Australia to a position of armed neutrality, and they want to maintain and demonstrate a strong nuclear free stance. At the same time, they want to cut back the money spent on defence. The first target of this is, without doubt, the ANZUS alliance-the alliance between Australia and the United States. We ought to be quite clear about the value of this alliance to Australia. I am in favour of it. I think it is of great value to Australia. It is also of value to the United States. It does not guarantee American support. The Americans will come to our aid if they think it is in their strategic interest to do so. If we think about it, it would be disgraceful if they operated on any other basis. But the ANZUS alliance ensures that what happened when the Americans came to our assistance in 1942 will not happen again. In 1942 we had no common tactical doctrine, no common ammunition and no common communications. We just could not operate together. It took at least a year to sort that out.

In the first place the ANZUS alliance ensures that, if ever they need to come to our aid again, that aid will be immediately effective. Secondly, the ANZUS alliance allows us to keep operationally effective by exercising with the Americans and with others so that our forces can be brought up to a higher pitch of efficiency than would be possible if they were entirely self-contained. Thirdly, and in some ways most importantly, the ANZUS alliance links us into the American supply network so that we can, with the same rights as American forces, demand stores from their worldwide supply network. That is of great financial advantage to us. It has been estimated, and I think it is an underestimate, that if we did not have the alliance with America the cost of maintaining the present modest capability of our Defence Force would double. So much for the Democrats trying to cut back on defence expenditure.

The Democrats also seem to link this in to a desire to opt out of a nuclear war. My attitude is that if a nuclear war occurs it will be devastating for the whole earth. I do not know whether this will cause a nuclear winter or the total elimination of mammalian life on earth, but what I do know is that all the previous estimates by nuclear physicists of the likely effects of their weapons have been underestimates. We must accept that a nuclear war would be a total catastrophe for the whole earth. Once it starts, it will not stop short of an all-out exchange of 40,000 or 50,000 weapons, or whatever the number is. We must as responsible people do what we can, in our own interests as well as the interests of the rest of the world, to prevent such an event taking place. The American facilities in Australia have several functions, some of which are beneficial to us and some of which are beneficial to America, but the dominant reason I like having them in Australia and why they must remain here is that they contribute to lessening the likelihood of a global nuclear exchange. That is in our interests and in the interests of the whole world, and to reject that concept I think is a total abdication of our international responsibility and our responsibility to the Australian people.

This is, in my view, a very foolish motion. The Australian Democrats have highlighted some of the ways in which this Government has been neglecting our Defence Force. That is accurate, but the way in which it is being handled-suggesting that we can in some way hide our head in the sand, that in some way we should try to opt out of the world and hope that the world will pass us by and not notice us-is totally irresponsible. We are a mature country with considerable potential power. We must make our contribution to making this country, and the world, a safer place. We can do that. We must do it, and we must eschew this sort of pacifist rubbish-which it is-because it does not get to grips with the real nature of the world scene. I sympathise with the motives of the Australian Democrats'. I suppose they are honourable, but they are very foolish indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other speakers have said, this is a very confused motion that we are debating today and it makes addressing oneself to it within 15 minutes somewhat difficult. I have tried to analyse the origin of the confusion, and I can think only of some two or three explanations. One is that it is based on some sort of political `throwing mud at the wall' theory; that one throws in everything one can possibly think of, throws as much mud at the wall as can be imagined, and hopes that something will stick. The related explanation is what is sometimes called the `bower bird theory'; that is, one picks up a little idea from here and a little idea from there and elsewhere, sticks them all together and hopes that somehow or other they will make a composite whole. Or, as a member of my staff suggested to me, perhaps it was in the best Australian Democrat tradition-the Democrats had a Caucus meeting and every member of the party wrote a clause. They stuck them together and composed a motion, but none of them had spoken to each other. Irrespective of the explanation of their confusion and contradiction, I have to accept that in 15 minutes I am not going to be able to cover all aspects of the motion. So I will attempt to complement the contributions made by my colleague Senators Schacht and Black, and concentrate on the areas of effectiveness, economics and the related question of the dual civil and military roles of the military.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion, as proposed, calls for a restructuring of Australia's Defence Force to address the `crises in defence effectiveness'. I think it has been very unfair and unreasonable and all too easy to attack the effectiveness of Australia's defence forces. It would be unfair and unreasonable to say that now or in any peacetime situation there is no room for improvement in Australia's defence forces and defence facilities. But we do have at the moment, and we are working towards improving, a plan and program that is entirely suited towards Australia's unique geopolitical situation that is based on the concept of self-reliance, as developed in the excellent White Paper of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), and the concept outlined by my colleague Senator Black of layered defence or defence in depth. What is important about this assessment of effectiveness is that it is based on a realistic assessment of the capabilities we may face. It is not based on imagined threats or confident assertions that there will be no problem, nor on a political assessment of who may have the will to use those capabilities, but on a military assessment of what capabilities might exist, and particularly those risks which could arise with little warning. It is conceivable that in five or 10 years time almost any country of substantial size could develop the capabilities to deliver a major attack on some country in its region. But to be able to do so without warning requires it to have already established such an enhanced defence capacity. As Australia's defence is currently constituted, it is designed specifically to meet such capabilities as may reasonably be expected to arise.

I wanted, in not concentrating too much in this area, to quote both the Chief of Naval Staff and the Chief of the Defence Force in their concern about the facile and all too often quoted criticisms of Australia's defence capacity at this moment. The Chief of Naval Staff said:
I quote a recent public statement with which I totally disagree: `Australia's defence capability is becoming a sick joke to our friends and allies'. . .
I might say that that is a quote from the shadow Minister for defence, Mr Peter White. The Chief of Naval Staff continued:
If I did not know better I could only assume that the author of that remark had no knowledge of where the truth lay; nor was interested in finding out.

There are, of course, difficulties such as the shortage in some areas of trained personnel. In other areas we are losing more than we can really afford; and no Chief of Staff will ever claim that his service has enough money for operating expenses; but while we may be relatively small, I have no hesitation in saying that the ADF is as professional as it has ever been. A realistic approach is being taken to the allocation of resources to ensure that the balance between capability, readiness and sustainability is maintained. As I have said before, we are not preparing for World War III. The balance that has been struck is sensible in terms of current strategic outlook and flexible enough that we can react to the uncertainty we could face in the future. So despite the criticism of the ill-informed, Australia does have a Defence Force with a capability to meet credible, I again stress credible, contingencies and the infrastructure to expand in response to higher levels of conflict.
That is a very eloquent and effective contribution from the Chief of Naval Staff. I would also like to quote the Chief of the Defence Force. In a recent public statement he said:

Australia has a coherent defence policy, an efficient and effective Defence Force and skilled service professionals in whom Australians can feel pride and confidence. Yet it has become almost fashionable in some small but vocal segments of the community to talk about the rundown of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and of our defence in general. Both propositions are demonstrably untrue. Unchecked, they are potentially damaging and run the risk of causing Australians to lose confidence in their Defence Force. Such propositions are also depressing for the ADF itself which knows that reality is otherwise.
I welcome those comments by those two very senior and respected defence spokespersons for Australia.

I would now like to turn to the question of defence economics, although that as a concept is a bit hard to understand and it is unexplained. Senator McLean talks about restructuring to address dimensions of the crises in defence economics. I assume by `defence economics' he means determination of the extent of the resources required to carry out necessary tasks when put against the range of possible resources to which the taxpayers' resources could otherwise be applied and, as a subpart of that, the allocation of those resources between various defence-related options. That is only my interpretation because Senator McLean never actually told me what it meant. But I think, as a student of economics, in an attempt to apply it to defence, that must be what he means. So let us talk about the allocation of resources.

In the 1988-89 Budget $7,658m was set aside for defence, a real increase of 0.5 per cent on 1987-88, and there was an increase in the emphasis in that expenditure on personnel. There are various ways in which one can look at possible critiques of that allocation of resources. One is that more should be spent, and the responsibility lies with those who advocate that to explain, in the very old parlance of Australian politics, where the money is coming from?. Are they talking about increasing taxation or reducing expenditure elsewhere? Senator McLean did not address this and I think those on the Opposition side tend not to address the question of how they will fund increased defence expenditure while at the same time reducing the deficit and taxation.

As this is Senator McLean's motion, let me refer to his proposal. He is talking about having a reserve force of 150,000 well paid reservists. I do not know what he means by `well paid'. But if 150,000 reservists are paid $1,000 a year each, it costs $150m. If they are put into full time training for a month on average weekly earnings-which is not exactly being well paid, but we will use that as a definition-it will cost $300m. That is without any extra costs incurred in training or feeding them; it is just for wages. If we are at the upper end of Senator McLean's scale, where he talks about perhaps 250,000 reservists, those figures would be either $250m or $500m. As Senator Black said so effectively, the person whom Senator McLean so selectively quoted, David Martin, has said that defence self-reliance would cost an extra $3 billion.

It is possible to argue that perhaps we are spending too much. If we read Senator McLean's motion we see in it a couple of points which might indicate that is what he thinks. I am not quite sure. But the problem in the defence forces is such that I am certain no-one is advocating reduced expenditure on personnel, and his use of `self-reliance' I think means that we cannot realistically spend less on capital equipment. So what we need to address is whether it is sufficient to meet the reasonable capital equipment requirements outlined in the defence White Paper, consistent with self-reliance and with the concept of layered defence.

I want to distinguish between that concept of self-reliance and the concept of armed neutrality, which Mr Martin was referring to when he talked about $3 billion and which Senator McLean referred to earlier. At current levels of capital spending as a proportion of defence spending and given the maintenance of the proportion of defence spending as outlined in the last Budget, the defence budget provides nearly $40 billion of capital expenditure over the next 15 years. The capital program outlined in the White Paper requires only a little over half of that sum, which of course allows flexibility to meet further requirements for equipment and facilities and to expand manpower and operating budgets as circumstances demand. Those figures show that we can afford the defence we need provided we focus carefully on our real priorities. We cannot afford a wish list and we cannot afford something that does not refer to priorities.

The last point I wish to make is that the economics of defence, as with economics elsewhere, require the addressing of the issue of priorities. This means that we have to look at how much we put in and where we put it. This Government has been exceptionally successful in getting the resources to the right place. For the first time somebody is actually implementing the much discussed issue of a two-ocean Navy. When I was in the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia, every three years we had the same triennial promise from the Liberal Federal Government. Usually Mr Killen would come across and, with Sir Charles Court, promise that the Government would build a naval base at Stirling, and three years later they would come back and make exactly the same promise. Now, at last, a two-ocean Navy is being developed. We are getting the Air Force to the north of Australia for the first time. For many years Australian defence personnel have been first class and in many instances, the defence equipment has been well planned. If only we could have persuaded any potential aggressors to make sure they came via Sydney, we would have been very well protected, because that was where all the defence resources were. At last they are being sent to the north where they properly belong and we are also sending the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin.

There are many other aspects of efficiency to which I would like to refer but time will not allow. I would like to digress for one moment to say that I am very concerned at one implication of Senator McLean's motion. If, as he said, the concept of armed neutrality would not allow us to put our forces in friendly countries overseas, this would mean that the Army engineers who are currently serving in an extremely popular and effective role in the southern highlands of Papua New Guinea could no longer operate there. I think that would be very unfortunate-a setback for Australian relations and a setback for the development of Papua New Guinea which should not be allowed to happen. There are also other aspects of efficiency and allocation of resources concerning the Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs, for example.

I would like to take the last minute or two to talk about the dual civil and military role and, again, the question of priorities. It is true that at present the military has skills and capabilities to contribute to the civil community in necessary roles such as fire fighting, but firstly we have to assess whether in developing and enhancing them any further-that is, developing our military capacity in the most appropriate way to defend Australia, which is the primary purpose-we have found the most cost efficient way of providing those civil resources. There are many examples of Defence Force personnel making themselves available and making significant contributions in firefighting, in search and rescue, in coastal surveillance and in opposition to drug trafficking. The Australian Defence Force can contribute and already contributes significant resources. We have to remember that the very reason for maintaining armed forces must always be borne in mind as a priority and of necessity the limitations must be placed on how far that can happen.

I think we ought to reject this motion. It is not fair to so many Australian men and women who are involved to treat the defence forces as a shambles or to say that we are defenceless. I think the Chief of the Naval Staff and the Chief of the Defence Force have repudiated that and I think that the motion should be rejected on those grounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to this motion because of a fundamental flaw in the structure of paragraph (2). Also, we do not support paragraph (5) of the motion and we think that paragraph (3) is misleading. For the benefit of the Senate, the whole point of the Australian Democrats' argument turns on the case of armed neutrality. Once again it is the old Democrat proposition that there are easy, simple and cheap solutions that the better minds of this Parliament have never been able to find. It does not matter what the problem is-whether it is migration, an economic problem, a social problem or defence-along come the simple-minded Democrats with a simple, easy, cheap solution.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for the Democrats' armed neutrality case is that they are basically a pacifist party and they have always been that way. They are rabidly anti-American, they are in favour of nuclear disarmament and they are very interested in trying to corner the market for the peace vote at present. They know they face extinction in the next Senate election and, grasping at straws, they are trying to corral the vote of the peace movement and take it away from people such as Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn. It is very interesting to note that they did not offer a voice today to either Senator Dunn or Senator Vallentine, the representatives of the peace party, in what is inherently a pacifist debate. They did that with damn good reason-because they do not want to help those people in any way at all.

Another point that is behind their approach is that the Australian Democrats are inherently a lazy party. They do not contribute to the running of this chamber and only today we learned that the deputy presidency that they held has gone because it is too much work for them. They do not take any part at all in the Estimates committees-the hardest working committees in this place. There is not one Democrat on any of the six Estimates committees. They get involved only in issues in which they think there is a benefit for them in terms of the vote. The great difficulty in life for the Democrats is working out whether they do something to help the Labor Government or to help themselves with their vote. So we have the Democrats' simplistic solutions for what are inherently very difficult, very complex and very expensive programs. The defence of Australia falls into all those categories. But unfortunately for the Democrats it is something that the Parliament cannot run away from. The Democrats can run away from it because they know they will never be in a position of having to take a decision about the government of this country because they will never be the government of Australia. I suppose that is the one good point about the whole of the existence of the Democrats.

The proposition of having armed neutrality is not open for Australia. It is not open on political, economic and, least of all, military grounds. What are the Democrats saying when they talk about armed neutrality? Do they want Australia to become like India, to get up and sanctimoniously mouth the cause of peace at every international forum, but at the same time stoking billions of dollars into a nuclear armaments industry? Do they want to arm Australia with nuclear weapons in the way the Indians have armed themselves behind the guise of being a non-aligned nation? Do they want us to be like Cuba and have tens or hundreds of thousands of Australian servicemen in Africa doing the bidding of the Soviets? Tragically for the Cubans, the last public health estimates show that well over 50 per cent of the troops they have committed in Africa are infected with acquired immune deficiency syndrome so Cuba has paid a very high price for being a lackey for the Soviets in their African adventures.

We hear a lot about Sweden, not only from the Democrats but also from the Australian Labor Party, because it is one of those cherished Valhallas for the socialists of this world. But as Senator Schacht said, in a rare moment of historical accuracy, they were the people who were selling iron ore non-stop to the Germans through the Second World War. We do not want to be like Sweden or Switzerland anyway because their armed forces have not fought for about 200 years and the one certainty in life is that if they were ever called upon to defend their countries they would be a total and abject failure. The only reason they have not been called on to fight is that Sweden and Switzerland are irrelevancies in world power politics. It has always suited the giants of Europe to keep Sweden and Switzerland as independent countries for their own good purposes. It is quite a different proposition for Australia. As a regional power in the south Pacific region we have responsibilities, and those responsibilities have impacted on this Government, which used to talk like the Democrats before it came into office. While the Government's educational program is quite incomplete at the moment, it has changed dramatically from the stance it took some years ago when it followed the same line of nonsense that the Democrats are putting out today. So politically it is not an option for us to go down that path. It is not an option for us to go down that path from an economic point of view. There would be an absolutely huge cost that the Australian public could not bear of maintaining the size of the Services. We would have to run well over 200,000 to 300,000 men and women in uniform at any one time if we got rid of all our alliances and stood completely on our own feet to defend this country. We just could not afford it.

Earlier in this debate Senator Schacht talked about the fact that, inevitably, we would have to go down the path of conscription. I do not agree with that. I differ very much from Senator Schacht's proposition that conscription would lead us onto a path of embarking on wartime adventures. That is a complete and total non sequitur. I have no objection to conscription. I do not believe that conscription is a political issue in Australia today, provided three conditions are met: firstly, that everyone goes in; secondly, that service is for a short period, three or six months, followed by training in the Reserves afterwards; and, thirdly, that everyone serves on the Australian mainland and not overseas. We should go back to the situation where Australian servicemen abroad have always been volunteers. If those three conditions are met I see no problem with introducing conscription. But I do not see the possibility of any government, whether it is Liberal or Labor, introducing conscription in the next decade or two simply on economic grounds. It would cost us a great deal of money-money that should be spent on repairing the great ravages to the defence forces that have taken place under the economic neglect of the Labor Party. So conscription just is not an issue at all.

Finally, we come to the simple military side of it. Apart from the number of people we would need in the defence forces, we simply could not develop the military techniques with the small force structure that we have without a reliance on alliances. There we get to the very heart of the matter. Australia, with its population, has to have alliances. If Senator McLean reads the White Paper he will find in chapter one the central statement that alliances are critical to Australia's military posture. Well they might be. Of course, the most important of those alliances is the ANZUS alliance which is anathema to the Democrats and the nuclear disarmers because it is an American alliance and anything that is American has to be very bad and cannot be tolerated.

The second point we do not agree with is the proposition that we have to maintain and demonstrate a strong nuclear-free stance. That is, typically, a misleading statement by the Democrats trying to imply that Australia, under a Labor government, has nuclear forces. If they knew anything about the subject matter they would know that, under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons which was signed by the Liberal Government, we cannot have nuclear arms in Australia and the nuclear arming of Australian forces is not an option that is considered at all by any of the major parties at present.
The final point on which we and the Democrats differ is item five which states:
Support trends away from vast expenditures on armaments which reflect assumption of global conflict . . .

I am sorry. Australia, with its small population, with very big geographical responsibilities in defending our land mass, which is as large as continental United States of America, simply has to use high technology as a force multiplier to make up for the small numbers we have. Regrettably, that is very expensive; there is no simple way out of it. To go down the path that Senator Coulter wandered down in his misguided way, railing about the armaments industry and all the rest of it, completely overlooks the fact that the countries that put money into developing arms-maybe they put in too much-derive a great benefit in terms of employment and the spin-off that comes from the scientific and technological advances made through military research. They are of very real benefit to the civilian population. So the Opposition is delighted that the Government is supporting it in opposing this urgency motion.

I would like to say something about the Labor Party spokesman. It is rather sad that, in the Senate today, we do not have one person, either in the ministerial ranks of the Labor Party or on the back bench, who can get up and take part in any defence debate. Not one member of the Labor Party in the Senate today has any knowledge at all, let alone any specialised knowledge, in the field of defence. I think that reflects the importance of defence in the Labor Party style of things. Senator Schacht, who spoke today, is just a great tourist. He wanders around the world and thinks he knows a bit about foreign affairs. Senator Black then read a speech that came out of the Department of Defence-the same sort of speech that Mr Beazley normally reads when he is trying to convince us that all is well. We then had a similar thing with Senator McMullan who drew heavily on the writings of the Department of Defence. Not one of the three speakers we had today had any ability to tackle the subject in any depth at all. In that circumstance it is not surprising that some mistakes were made.

I am sick and tired of hearing in this chamber that the Labor Party bought the F18s. Let me put on the record once and for all that the Liberal-National Party Government undertook the work. I see that Senator Tate is smiling but he knows damned well, because in the old Parliament House he sat through many a speech that I made on the virtues of the F18 before the contract was signed, that the contract for that was signed in 1981-two years before the Labor Party came into power. It is quite mischievous for and highly ignorant of people on the other side of the chamber to claim now that this was a Labor Party initiative. The other thing that disturbed me was that Senator Black, when reading his Mr Beazley-type speech, told us that the Australian defence forces will maintain a qualitative jump ahead of all other regional forces. Mr Acting Deputy President, that is not true. If you knew anything about the activities of the Association of South East Asian Nations and other countries in the region you would know that Australia has a very tenuous hold on its technological advantage. In fact, in some fields in some services we are quite behind what is going on in the countries of some of our close neighbours and that is a very serious problem.

I take exception to the very singular view of history that Senator Schacht had. Senator Schacht had a view that the Services have always done well under Labor. Nothing could be further from the truth. The tragic loss of 45,000 out of the 70,000-odd personnel that has taken place under the Hawke Administration has been paralelled completely by the great disabilities the defence forces suffered under the Scullin Government. In the late 1920s, under Mr Scullin, the same tired thesis of no threat for 10 years was wheeled out and postulated to the Australian people as an excuse for not putting enough into the defence forces-precisely the same argument as Mr Beazley and Mrs Kelly are running today. It is not true, but it is an old cliche of the Labor Party.

One of the tragic things that the Labor Party has done has been to destroy totally the capability of the Australian defence forces. Through its neglect, which stems from a lack of leadership and a lack of adequate funds, many people have resigned from the defence forces. I regret very much that defence, which should be a bipartisan issue, and which has the support of the major parties in this place, should be turned into a political football by a bunch of political opportunists such as the Australian Democrats.

I draw attention to the fact that this report quotes a number of standards which have been adopted by the Australian Capital Territory Radiation Council with respect to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I note that all of those standards which have been adopted are old standards. The situation with respect to setting standards in radiation is rather different from setting standards for many other chemical substances because it is generally accepted that there is no safe level of radiation. When one sets a standard of radiation exposure, one is accepting that there is some risk associated with that.

The standards which this body is applying are old standards, based very much on the older assessment of the survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and of those patients who were heavily exposed to radiation in the 1940s for the treatment of diseases such as ankylosing spondylitis. Recent recalculation of the risks associated with the radiation exposure of Hiroshima and Nagasaki survivors has indicated a very considerable underestimate of the risks associated with that radiation. Generally speaking, expert opinion around the world is of the view that the standard should be decreased by a factor of about three. I understand that that has actually been done in the United Kingdom by the National Radiological Protection Board. It is also in the process of being adopted by the International Commission on Radiological Protection. Therefore, it is of concern to note that in the ACT we are still complying with the old standards.

Several years ago I gave evidence to the Industrial Court in South Australia in an award case for radiologists. The officer in the South Australian Health Commission responsible for radiological protection, Jill Fitch, gave evidence that she would mount an inquiry into exposure of radiologists only if the radiation exposure proved to be more than one-quarter of the then allowable limit. Using the figures which were published by the Biological Effects of Ionising Radiation Committee-known as the BEIR Committee-which is a subcommittee of the National Academy of Sciences, it was possible to calculate that the level of extra cancer risk to which the South Australian Health Commission considered that workers may be exposed involved an increased risk, if I remember the figures correctly, of between 3 and 16 per cent. If one accepts that the present acceptable levels should be reduced by a factor of three, one sees that one quarter of the old level is remarkably close to the maximum level of radiation to which people can be exposed. It also represents a very significant increase in the cancer risk of people working with radiation, such as radiographers, radiologists, dentists and the like. For these reasons, it is of great concern to me that the allowable levels of radiation in the ACT are based entirely on the old standards, which are currently under review and which, I believe, have been discarded by the National Radiological Protection Board in Great Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of important amendments to the Copyright Act 1968. The amendments will legitimise home audio taping by introducing a royalty on blank recording tape to recompense copyright owners; protect performers from unauthorised recording or broadcasting of their live performances; enable educational institutions to copy television programs off air; streamline the existing licences to educational institutions to photocopy, and institutions assisting the handicapped to make `talking books' and other useful materials; remove protection for most industrial articles from the Copyright Act provisions on artistic works; streamline the statutory licence for record manufacture; and make other miscellaneous amendments. As a companion measure, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is also introducing the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 to provide sui generis copyright-style protection for plans for computer chips.

SPEECH.PARA: Background

These major amendments are the third stage of this Government's reform of the copyright law. In 1984, we introduced amendments to make it clear that computer programs, and other works in invisible computer memory, were protected against unauthorised copying. In 1986 we introduced amendments to substantially strengthen the anti-piracy provisions and to give the handicapped greater access to copyright materials. The amendments that are being introduced today are the result of extensive consultations by the Government with consumers, educators and industry participants, particularly in the last two years. The Government's aim is to provide a fair, certain and effective copyright law which will properly reward innovators and reflect modern consumer practice, while taking into account the legitimate practical considerations that affect particular groups such as educational institutions and institutions working for the handicapped. The need to amend the law so frequently is the direct result of advances in technology. Copyright, as much as-or even more than-any other area of the law, is vitally affected by technological developments which allow copyright material to be used in new ways.
