SPEECH.PARA: Statutory Licence: Photocopying by Educational Institutions

The amendments in this Bill will also revise the existing educational photocopying scheme. The present scheme has proved to be extremely cumbersome to operate and costly to administer because of its complex record keeping requirements. Following expressions of dissatisfaction from both educational institutions and copyright owners, the Government examined the feasibility of a revised scheme which could operate along the same lines as the scheme for copying of television programs.

Whilst substantially preserving the range and extent of materials that may be copied, the revised scheme is based largely on voluntary agreements already entered into between Copyright Agency Ltd-the authors' and publishers' collecting society-and a substantial number of educational institutions throughout Australia. Co-operation in this regard has largely been achieved by abandoning the record keeping requirements of the present scheme under which payments are required for actual copying. Instead, payment is being made on the basis of agreed sampling schemes whereby estimates can be made of the amount of copying and payment made on a per student basis.

The amendments proposed by the Government facilitate these voluntary arrangements and ensure that they can operate effectively under the legislation. The revised photocopying scheme will adopt the flexibility of the television copying scheme. It will provide for the establishment of a collecting society representative of copyright owners-or a defined class of copyright owners-and will enable schools to elect to pay for copying on a per student basis or, as at present, by full record keeping. However, if full record keeping is opted for, records will now be required to be sent to the relevant collecting society for assessment. This will avoid copyright owners having to carry out time consuming and costly record inspections at the thousands of schools spread around the country.

The criminal penalties in the Act for offences relating to record keeping have understandably been the subject of concern on the part of teachers. These have been substantially omitted from the revised scheme.

For the teachers who will have recourse to it on a daily basis, the revised scheme will in practice be much simpler to comply with. It will also substantially improve the means of remunerating copyright owners for the user of their copyright materials. In keeping with the proposed changes to the educational photocopying scheme and the new provisions dealing with copying of television programs by educational institutions, the Bill also includes new provisions which will streamline copying by institutions assisting handicapped readers and intellectually handicapped people.
Copyright-Designs Interaction

The Bill will update the protection given to artistic works that are either registered as designs under the Designs Act 1906 or are industrially applied without registration. Manufacturers, artists and designers of a diverse range of articles experience problems with the excessive copyright protection of `industrial' products by the Copyright Act, the uncertain operation of the legislation and its often inequitable effects. The legislation has also attracted criticism from both legal commentators and the courts.

Last year the Government published a discussion paper that canvassed various options for reform, and received submissions from copyright owners and industry. The preferred solution was to remove the possibility of copyright protection for three-dimensional industrial products. It is considered that these products should be protected only under the designs legislation or other appropriate law. The Designs Law Review Committee report of 1973 on the law relating to designs also reached this conclusion. The amendments introduced by the Bill will amend the Copyright Act accordingly. In addition, the so-called `non-expert defence' in the Copyright Act is to be repealed. It provides a qualified defence to infringement of the copyright owner's right to reproduce an artistic work in a different dimension. It has not operated as intended and has been the subject of much adverse judicial comment.

These changes will not affect copyright protection for artistic works reproduced on the surface of an article, such as a T-shirt, or for buildings or works of artistic craftspersonship for which a design has not been registered. Thus, protection by copyright will continue for these essentially artistic creations; for example, tapestry or certain craftwork. As well, the changes will not affect designs for articles excluded by regulation from registration under the Designs Act.
Computer Chips

The Circuit Layouts Bill 1988, which protects computer chip layouts from unfair copying, is the second part of the Government's copyright reform package. The Australian computer chip industry is small but important and growing. Australian chips, for example, make bionic ears and heart pacemakers work, detect messages from space and from the ocean, and convert sunlight to power. Importantly, our specialised products have found valuable markets overseas.

A consequence of the copyright-design reforms already mentioned is that copyright will be of very limited use to chip designers to protect their products against piracy. The Designs Act may apply to some parts of chip layouts but, like copyright, designs monopoly protection is not suitable for chip layouts because it is excessive. Chips are essential products in modern society. Innovators need to be able to stop unauthorised copying in order to protect their investment. However, that protection should not be at the expense of proper availability of the product for use in machinery and consumer appliances.

The Circuit Layouts Bill will repeal inappropriate and uncertain Copyright Act and Designs Act protection, and provide protection for original chip layouts along the lines of the laws passed recently in the United States, Japan, Scandinavia and European Community countries. The Bill is also consistent with the major elements of the World Intellectual Property Organisation's draft `Treaty on the Protection of Intellectual Property in respect of Integrated Circuits'. I expect this draft Treaty to be finalised at a diplomatic conference in Washington in May 1989. It is highly desirable that this Bill be law before that conference to ensure that Australia's negotiating position is equal to that of the other countries which already have chip protection laws. In the unfortunate event that the conference does not agree on a treaty, Australia will need to enter into bilateral arrangements. As a result of this Government's representations, Australian chips have been protected in the US since mid-1985. However, that protection is only interim, and ends in May 1989.

The Circuit Layouts Bill provides modified copyright protection. It grants to the creator of an original chip layout the exclusive rights-to copy the layout; to make a chip in accordance with the layout; and to first commercially exploit the layout or a chip made in accordance with such a layout. The rights will, like copyright, arise `automatically'. This is a simple, low cost form of protection involving no red tape, which is welcomed by industry and the Government.

As well as a short term of protection-minimum 10 years, maximum 20 years, from making-the Circuit Layouts Bill includes several significant departures from traditional copyright because of: the short market life of chips; the need to preserve fair competition between innovators; and the fact that Australia imports most of its chips, either inside consumer products or for installation in products made here. Accordingly, importation of legitimate chips may not be prevented by the rights owner; a pirate layout or chip innocently acquired may be `on-sold' by the purchaser even after he or she knows of its infringing status, provided the purchaser pays a fair fee to the rights owner; and copying for `reverse engineering' is permitted, and a layout or chip made on the basis of this reverse engineering will not infringe rights in the first layout, provided it is also `original'.
Statutory Licence for Record Manufacture

The Copyright Act presently contains a statutory licence for the manufacture of recordings of musical work. The relevant provisions specify conditions upon which the licence operates and a mechanism for changing the rate of royalty payable to music copyright owners. This mechanism requires the Attorney-General to determine that the current rate is `inequitable'. Then there is an inquiry and report by the Copyright Tribunal. Any variation of the rate is by regulation.

The Government considers that the preliminary requirement for the Attorney-General to determine the current royalty rate to be `inequitable' is an undesirable and inappropriate role for Government. It is also an inappropriate role for the Governor-General to have to consider a Tribunal report and make regulations, where appropriate, to vary the rate. In 1979-80 this matter proved a very controversial one for the Attorney-General of the day.

Accordingly, the Copyright Amendment Bill will introduce a simplified scheme, based solely on a Copyright Tribunal determination of the rate in the absence of agreement, which will be consistent with other schemes in the Act, for example, the compulsory licence for broadcasting music. Such a scheme will have industry support and will remove unnecessary government involvement in the industry.
Miscellaneous

The Copyright Amendment Bill will also introduce a number of other reforms which will extend the right of the Australian Archives to copy works in its archival collection, standardise rights of review under the Act and facilitate copyright protection for choreographic works made in the form of film or video.
Financial Impact

The Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 will have a minimal impact on Commonwealth revenue and expenditure. There may be some increase in revenue due to a slight expansion of the sales tax base resulting from introduction of the blank tape royalty. The statutory educational copying and blank tape royalty schemes are largely self-administering. The Bill will therefore not directly lead to any increased cost to the Commonwealth. However, there is a possibility of some increased costs to the Commonwealth in relation to funding of the Copyright Tribunal, in that greater demands may be placed on the Tribunal to hear applications under those new statutory licence schemes. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Puplick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has chosen to omit large sections of the second reading speech on pages 3 to 12, part of page 18 and pages 20 to 21, despite the Opposition having agreed to the motion to have this matter debated by suspending the 25 November deadline. That is a most unfortunate omission from the Hansard, especially for people who have a genuine interest in the matter. Therefore, I seek leave to have incorporated in the Hansard the full text of the second reading speech.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to make a number of important amendments to the Copyright Act 1968.
The amendments will:
legitimise home audio taping by introducing a royalty on blank recording tape to recompense copyright owners;
protect performers from unauthorised recording or broadcasting of their live performances;
enable educational institutions to copy television programs off air;
streamline the existing licences to educational institutions to photocopy, and institutions assisting the handicapped to make `talking books' and other useful materials;
remove protection for most industrial articles from the Copyright Act provisions on artistic works;
streamline the statutory licence for record manufacture; and
make other miscellaneous amendments.
As a companion measure, I am also introducing the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 to provide sui generis copyright-style protection for plans for computer chips.
Background
These major amendments are the third stage of this Government's reform of the copyright law.

In 1984, we introduced amendments to make it clear that computer programs, and other works in invisible computer memory, were protected against unauthorised copying. In 1986 we introduced amendments to substantially strengthen the anti-piracy provisions and to give the handicapped greater access to copyright materials.

The amendments I introduce today are the result of extensive consultations by the Government with consumers, educators and industry participants, particularly in the last two years. The Government's aim is to provide a fair, certain and effective copyright law which will properly reward innovators and reflect modern consumer practice, while taking account of the legitimate practical considerations that affect particular groups such as educational institutions and institutions working for the handicapped.

The need to amend the law so frequently is the direct result of advances in technology. Copyright, as much as-or even more than-any other area of the law, is vitally affected by technological developments which allow copyright material to be used in new ways. Within the last century, the introduction of the record-player, films, broadcasting, photocopying and cassette and video recorders and, more recently, computer programs has transformed the manner of use of copyright material. The amendments introduced by this Bill will update the law to reflect technological advances and ensure continuing protection for copyright owners.
I will now address the more significant of the measures in this Bill in more detail.
Blank Tape Royalty Scheme for Home Taping

For some time the Government has been discussing with relevant industry participants a possible legislative scheme for the home-taping of audio materials. Home-taping is widespread in the community. Under the present law this practice is in breach of copyright yet, clearly, it cannot be controlled by copyright owners either by technical means or by legal action. The Government has been anxious to find a solution which would acknowledge the current practice yet also ensure that copyright owners are compensated for the use of their material. In the process, the Government consulted not only with copyright owners and consumer groups, but also with blank tape manufacturers, importers, wholesalers and retailers. The scheme contained in the Bill accommodates the concerns of both consumers and copyright owners.
Important features of the scheme are:
Consumers will be able to home-tape published recordings, directly or off-air, for their private and domestic use without infringement of copyright.
In return, owners of copyright in the recordings will receive remuneration through a royalty to be levied on blank recording tape.

The royalty will apply to audio tapes with playing times in excess of 30 minutes and will be calculated by reference to the length of the playing time. The actual amount of the royalty will be determined by the Copyright Tribunal having regard to relevant matters such as, for example, the extent of home-taping of eligible copyright material and the value to copyright owners of the material so taped.

In the interests of minimising the administrative costs of royalty collection, the duty to pay the royalty will be imposed on the first sellers, i.e., importers and manufacturers, of blank tapes in Australia.

Copyright owners will only be able to receive royalties where they are members of a single, authorised collecting society, the rules of which have been approved by the Attorney-General. The collecting society will operate along similar lines to existing copyright collecting societies and will be responsible for the collection and distribution of the royalties. The Government will therefore not be involved in the running of the scheme and will not receive any part of the royalty.

Copyright owners who will benefit from the scheme will include composers, lyricists, authors, music publishing companies and record producers. Very importantly, the recording companies have agreed that a substantial share of the royalty will be passed on to performers under their contracts. This would ordinarily amount to 1/3 of the royalties collected by the society. The Government would be concerned if this share were eroded and will be monitoring this aspect closely.
These features are consistent with recommendations in the McLeay Report on Commonwealth Assistance to the Arts released in September 1986. That report recommended a levy on blank tapes.

In addressing the impact of home-taping on copyright, Australia is ahead of many comparable countries. However, a number of European countries have already introduced or are proposing to introduce a blank tape royalty scheme in one form or other.

The proposed royalty will be payable on all blank tapes ordinarily used for recording audio materials, including digital audio tapes (DAT). The superior quality of DAT, equivalent at least to that of compact discs, has led to calls here and overseas for bans on equipment not incorporating and `anti-copy' or spoiler device. However, the Government does not favour controlling home-taping by such means.

The Government acknowledges that not all blank tapes are used for recording material in which the copyright belongs to others. The Bill therefore includes specific provisions to enable institutional users (e.g., schools and institutions for the blind) to purchase tapes free from the royalty. Individuals or organisations who buy tapes on which the royalty has been paid, and who do not copy others' copyright material, will be able to obtain a refund of the royalty.

One aspect of the scheme the Government has examined very closely is how to treat foreign-owned copyright material. The Government has been concerned to prevent outflow of funds from Australia to foreign countries which do not reciprocate with similar benefits to Australian copyright owners. For this reason, the royalty will be collected for the benefit of only `relevant' copyright owners, that is, owners of Australian audio copyright materials and owners of audio copyright materials in countries which have similar schemes which provide comparable benefits to Australian owners. This will ensure that Australia adheres to the spirit of the relevant international copyright conventions without providing a windfall to foreign owners in countries which have not addressed the problem of home-taping.

One very important feature of the scheme is that 15% of the royalty raised will be set aside by copyright owners for the benefit of those people in the Australian music industry most in need of assistance. The Government is gratified that the music industry has agreed to provide part of the royalty to the Australian Contemporary Music Development Company, recently established by the Government, to foster Australian contemporary music and, most importantly, young, up-and-coming Australian musicians. Moreover, the 15% will be increased in the event that other substantial music exporting countries introduce similar reciprocal blank tape royalty schemes under which Australian copyright owners could benefit, thereby offsetting some of the potential outflow of funds from Australia.

The blank tape royalty will free home-taping from the unsatisfactory status of an infringing activity on terms that meet the convenience of the public and are acceptable to copyright owners. It will also indirectly secure fair recompense to copyright owners for lost sales resulting from the ever increasing spread of home-taping.
Performers' protection

The Bill will create new civil remedies and criminal offences for the unauthorised use of performers' performances. Performers, including actors, singers, musicians, puppeteers, dancers and variety artists have long advocated the need to have greater legal control over uses of their performances. This Government referred their claims to the Copyright Law Review Committee (CLRC) in 1983.

The CLRC's report to the Government on performers' protection clearly expressed the need to provide performers with protection from commercial exploitation of their `unfixed' performances, that is, their live performances (as opposed to recordings of performances). This need has arisen because technological developments have created very effective means of commercial use of performances, namely recording, broadcasting and diffusion by cable. These developments make it increasingly difficult for performers to effectively control the dissemination of their performances.

As recommended by the majority of the CLRC, the amendments will not confer copyright protection (i.e., property rights) on performers. Instead, they will create unassignable civil rights of action which also have counterpart criminal offences. The new provisions will complement the 1986 amendments made to the Act in relation to piracy and will also indirectly provide performers with greater bargaining power when negotiating contracts.

Complementary regulations which are proposed will extend the operation of the new provisions to citizens, nationals and residents of countries which are members of the Rome Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organisations (1961) and also to performances in those countries.

These amendments, together with other proposed regulations which will extend copyright protection to foreign broadcasts, will enable Australia to meet the minimum requirements of the Rome Convention. It is the Government's intention that steps be taken towards accession to this important Convention in the near future.
Educational copying

Access to the literary, musical and artistic heritage is fundamental to the role of the educator and that means access to a wide range of copyright material. The Government is therefore concerned that teachers have available to them any material of educational value circulating in both the print and audio-visual media. However, this should be achieved in a manner which ensures that relevant copyright owners are justly remunerated for use of their material.

It has been a great challenge to educators and copyright owners alike to reach agreement on this issue of educational copying. The proposed statutory licences for copying by educational institutions contained in the Bill recognise the need for educators to have easy access to copyright material for teaching purposes. They also recognise the need for copyright owners to be remunerated for the use of that material. While copyright owners should not be called upon to subsidise the educational needs of the public, there should be as few obstacles as possible to access to educational materials. The statutory licensing schemes will provide the appropriate mechanisms whereby the interests of copyright owners will be balanced against the interests of educators in the most efficient manner possible. These statutory licensing schemes are also consistent with the requirements of the international copyright conventions.
Statutory licence: Audio-visual Copying by Educational Institutions

The Bill will amend the act to establish a statutory licensing scheme which will allow educational institutions and institutions assisting handicapped persons to make off-air copies of television programs in return for payment to copyright owners.

The need for these provisions is clear. TV programs are widely used by schools in the course of educational instruction. Copying enables programs to be shown at a more convenient time and to be retained for repeated use.

Under the Copyright Act at present, however, off-air copying of TV programs by educational institutions is an infringement of copyright unless permission is obtained from relevant copyright owners. To avoid breaching copyright, it is necessary to obtain permission to copy a program from each copyright owner who has copyright in the program. There may be a number of separate rights in each program and, consequently, separate permissions are required with respect to the script, sound recording, background music, film (if pre-recorded) and the broadcast itself. This is an extremely onerous task for an institution wishing to copy a TV program. In the time normally available it is practically impossible.

The scheme introduced by this Bill follows recommendations in the 1986 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on Audio-visual Copying by Educational Institutions. It represents the result of extensive discussions between copyright owners, educational interests and the Government. I believe that it achieves a fair balance between the respective needs and entitlements of educational institutions and copyright owners, and I have every confidence that it will provide an effective and workable solution to the problems in this area.
One of the major advantages of this scheme will be its flexibility:
Educational institutions will be able to make off-air copies, for educational purposes, of all TV programs whether or not the programs were specifically made for educational purposes.
Copyright owners will be able to claim payment for the copying of their material through a single collecting society approved by the Attorney-General.
The amount payable to copyright owners will be as agreed between the parties or, in the absence of agreement, as decided by the Copyright Tribunal.

Institutions will be able to elect to pay for the right to copy either by way of an amount per student, or according to actual material copied based on full record-keeping. In the latter case, institutions will be required to send records to the collecting society at specified intervals.
Statutory Licence: Photocopying by Educational Institutions

The amendments in this Bill will also revise the existing educational photocopying scheme. The present scheme has proved to be extremely cumbersome to operate and costly to administer because of its complex record-keeping requirements. Following expressions of dissatisfaction from both educational institutions and copyright owners, the Government examined the feasibility of a revised scheme which could operate along the same lines as the scheme for copying of TV programs.

Whilst substantially preserving the range and extent of materials that may be copied, the revised scheme is based largely on voluntary agreements already entered into between Copyright Agency Limited (the authors' and publishers' collecting society) and a substantial number of educational institutions throughout Australia. Co-operation in this regard has largely been achieved by abandoning the record-keeping requirements of the present scheme under which payments are required for actual copying. Instead, payment is being made on the basis of agreed sampling schemes whereby estimates can be made of the amount of copying and payment made on a per-student basis.

The amendments proposed by the Government facilitate these voluntary arrangements and ensure that they can operate effectively under the legislation. The revised photocopying scheme will adopt the flexibility of the TV copying scheme. It will provide for the establishment of a collecting society representative of copyright owners-or a defined class of copyright owners-and will enable schools to elect to pay for copying on a per-student basis or, as at present, by full record-keeping. However, if full record-keeping is opted for, records will now be required to be sent to the relevant collecting society for assessment. This will avoid copyright owners having to carry out time-consuming and costly record inspections at the thousands of schools spread around the country.

The criminal penalties in the Act for offences relating to record-keeping have understandably been the subject of concern on the part of teachers. These have been substantially omitted from the revised scheme.

For the teachers who will have recourse to it on a daily basis, the revised scheme will in practice be much simpler to comply with. It will also substantially improve the means of remunerating copyright owners for the use of their copyright materials.

In keeping with the proposed changes to the educational photocopying scheme and the new provisions dealing with copying of TV programs by educational institutions, the Bill also includes new provisions which will streamline copying by institutions assisting handicapped readers and intellectually handicapped persons.
Copyright-Designs Interaction
The Bill will update the protection given to artistic works that are either registered as designs under the Designs Act 1906 or are industrially applied without registration.

Manufacturers, artists and designers of a diverse range of articles experience problems with the excessive copyright protection of `industrial' products by the Copyright Act, the uncertain operation of the legislation and its often inequitable effects. The legislation has also attracted criticism from both legal commentators and the courts.

Last year the Government published a Discussion Paper that canvassed various options for reform, and received submissions from copyright owners and industry. The preferred solution was to remove the possibility of copyright protection for three-dimensional industrial products. It is considered that these products should be protected only under the designs legislation or other appropriate law. The Designs Law Review Committee report on the law relating to designs (1973) also reached this conclusion. The amendments introduced by the Bill will amend the Copyright Act accordingly.

In addition, the so-called `non-expert defence' in the Copyright Act is to be repealed. It provides a qualified defence to infringement of the copyright owner's right to reproduce an artistic work in a different dimension. It has not operated as intended and has been the subject of much adverse judicial comment.

These changes will not affect copyright protection for artistic works reproduced on the surface of an article, such as a T-shirt, or for buildings or `works of artistic craftsmanship' for which a design has not been registered. Thus, protection by copyright will continue for these essentially `artistic' creations (e.g. tapestry or certain craftwork). As well, the changes will not affect designs for articles excluded by regulation from registration under the Designs Act.
Computer Chips
The Circuit Layouts Bill 1988, which protects computer chip layouts from unfair copying, is the second part of the Government's copyright reform package.

The Australian computer chip industry is small but important and growing. Australian chips, for example, make `bionic ears' and heart pacemakers work, detect messages from space and from the ocean and convert sunlight to power. Importantly, our specialised products have found valuable markets overseas.

A consequence of the copyright-design reforms already mentioned is that copyright will be of very limited use to chip designers to protect their products against piracy. The Designs Act may apply to some parts of chip layouts but, like copyright, designs monopoly protection is not suitable for chip layouts because it is excessive. Chips are essential products in modern society. Innovators need to be able to stop unauthorised copying in order to protect their investment. However, that protection should not be at the expense of proper availability of the product for use in machinery and consumer appliances.

The Circuit Layouts Bill will repeal inappropriate and uncertain Copyright Act and Designs Act protection, and provide protection for original chip layouts along the lines of the laws passed recently in the United States, Japan, Scandinavia and European Community countries. The Bill is also consistent with the major elements of the World Intellectual Property Organisation's draft `Treaty on the Protection of Intellectual Property in respect of Integrated Circuits'. I expect this draft Treaty to be finalised at a Diplomatic Conference in Washington in May 1989.
It is highly desirable that this Bill be law before that Conference to ensure Australia's negotiating position is equal to that of the other countries which already have chip protection laws.

In the unfortunate event that the Conference does not agree on a Treaty, Australia will need to enter into bilateral arrangements. As a result of this Government's representations, Australian chips have been protected in the United States since mid 1985. However, that protection is only interim, and ends in May 1989. Enactment of the Circuits Layouts Bill is needed to obtain permanent protection for Australian circuit layouts in the important United States market.
The Circuit Layouts Bill provides modified copyright protection. It grants to the creator of an original chip layout the exclusive rights-
to copy the layout;
to make a chip in accordance with the layout (in copyright law terms `to make a three-dimensional copy of a two-dimensional work'); and
to first commercially exploit the layout or a chip made in accordance with such a layout.
The rights will, like copyright, arise `automatically'. This is a simple. low-cost form of protection involving no red tape, which is welcomed by industry and the Government.
As well as a short term of protection-minimum 10 years, maximum 20 years, from making-the Circuit Layouts Bill includes several significant departures from traditional copyright because of:
the short market life of chips;
the need to preserve fair competition between innovators; and
the fact that Australia imports most of its chips, either inside consumer products or for installation in products made here.
Accordingly,
importation of legitimate chips may not be prevented by the rights owner;
a pirate layout or chip innocently acquired may be `on-sold' by the purchaser even after he or she knows of its infringing status, provided the purchaser pays a fair fee to the rights owner; and
copying for `reverse engineering' is permitted, and a layout or chip made on the basis of this reverse engineering will not infringe rights in the first layout, provided it is also `original'.
There are three other matters which need to be mentioned.

First, at the request of industry, the Bill provides only civil claims as remedies for infringement. This is because chip piracy has not been a problem so far in Australia. However, should this position change, we would need to look again at introducing criminal sanctions and customs controls.

Secondly, unlike some foreign laws, this Bill is not limited to current chip technology. For example, there is no requirement that `masks' be used to make chips, and protection is not limited to layouts for `semiconductor' chips. It may be, however, that the Australian chip industry develops in a way not covered by this Bill. If those developments were threatened by piracy, the Government would of course give consideration to further reforms.

Finally, I note that the proposal to introduce this legislation has been the subject of consultation with industry since 1985. A detailed outline of the legislation was circulated to over 40 companies and industry organisations in July this year.

If Australia is to obtain protection for its designs in the vital US and European export markets-either under the proposed Treaty or as a result of reciprocal arrangements-Australia must have a law, such as this Bill, in place as soon as possible.

The Australian computer chip industry is recognised by this Government as an important, innovative and growing one. The Government is committed to fostering its development. The Circuit Layouts Bill is a significant and timely demonstration of this commitment and Australian companies-both innovative producers and users of computer chip technology-will benefit from legal certainty provided by this special legislation.

However, the Government also recognises that in this fast moving area, its commitment must be responsive to the needs of the industry. Thus, after enactment of the Bill, it will be important to consult broadly with industry participants to ensure that the legislation achieves the desired result of providing appropriate intellectual property protection in Australia and in key export markets for the chip industry. The Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce will co-sponsor a program of consultation with industry during the first year of operation for this purpose.
Statutory licence for record manufacture

The Copyright Act presently contains a statutory licence for the manufacture of recordings of musical works. The relevant provisions specify conditions upon which the licence operates and a mechanism for changing the rate of royalty payable to music copyright owners. This mechanism requires the Attorney-General to determine that the current rate is `inequitable'. Then there is an inquiry and report by the Copyright Tribunal. Any variation of the rate is by regulation.

The Government considers that the preliminary requirement for the Attorney-General to determine the current royalty rate to be `inequitable' is an undesirable and inappropriate role for Government. It is also an inappropriate role for the Governor-General to have to consider a Tribunal report and make regulations, where appropriate, to vary the rate. In 1979-80 this matter proved a very controversial one for the Attorney-General of the day.

Accordingly, the Copyright Amendment Bill will introduce a simplified scheme, based solely on a Copyright Tribunal determination of the rate in the absence of agreement, which will be consistent with other schemes in the Act (for example, the compulsory licence for broadcasting music). Such a scheme will have industry support and will remove unnecessary Government involvement in the industry.
Miscellaneous

The Copyright Amendment Bill will also introduce a number of other reforms which will extend the right of the Australian Archives to copy works in its archival collection, standardise rights of review under the Act by the AAT and facilitate copyright protection for choreographic works made in the form of film or video.
Financial Impact

The Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 will have a minimal impact on Commonwealth revenue and expenditure. There may be some increase in revenue due to a slight expansion of the sales tax base resulting from introduction of the blank tape royalty.

The statutory educational copying and blank tape royalty schemes are largely self-administering. The Bill will therefore not directly lead to any increased cost to the Commonwealth. However, there is a possibility of some increased costs to the Commonwealth in relation to funding of the Copyright Tribunal, in that greater demands may be placed on the Tribunal to hear applications under those new statutory licence schemes.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1988-89APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned I was commenting on the fact that Time magazine published a special environment issue this week, a copy of which I have with me. I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the wonderful painting by Arthur Boyd which graces the cover of Time magazine. It is called Earth, Fire-the Struggle for Australia. As I was saying, two of the major conservation issues highlighted in this edition of Time magazine are Western Australian issues-Shark Bay and its frustrated World Heritage potential, and Rudall River, where CRA Ltd is proving up a massive uranium deposit inside the national park and on Aboriginal land, in anticipation of a change in Australian Labor Party uranium policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the anti-environmentalist Margaret Thatcher has apparently recognised a flaw in the unbridled capitalism for which she has been so fiercely vocal. In her own words, reported in the Advertiser:
The health of our economy and the health of our environment are totally dependent on each other.

Conservation in the context of sustainable development obviously does not require every ecosystem to be preserved intact. It is much too late for that, even if it were our objective. With the exception of Antarctica, we are left with isolated pockets of wilderness which must be protected, and large areas of modified and degraded land which must be rehabilitated. Senator Cook's national task force on soil conservation will not work unless it is properly funded to allow representatives of regional conservation groups to sit on soil district committees and contribute to the objectives of the task force.

A similar need exists with Senator Cook's proposed forest accord process involving government, the timber industry and conservationists. Adequate funding must be provided to allow conservation representatives from Western Australia and other far-flung States to participate effectively in the peak accord committee, if tokenism in the forest accord is to be avoided. Staff resources and funding to carry out the critical function of liaison between conservation groups, industry and government are imperative for verbal commitment to translate into effective action.

Before a forest accord can be developed, however, knowledge of forest ecology, conservation requirements and the extent of usable resources must be vastly improved. Funding for the appropriate bodies, such as the Australian Heritage Commission and the CSIRO, and grants to the States must be increased to provide this necessary baseline research and to monitor the ongoing effects of logging on forest ecology, if we are fair dinkum about sustainable use of our forests. Sustainable development also requires the conservation of plant and animal species because these are not renewable resources. It also requires the minimisation of adverse impacts on natural systems, in order to sustain their function and overall integrity.

Commonwealth responsibilities to the National Estate are being neglected in many areas. In Western Australia, for example, we have mining tenements extending across national parks and wilderness areas, including D'Entrecasteaux and Rudall River national parks, and in the last remaining tuart forest, which once extended north and south of Perth. All three are on the register of the National Estate, as is Shark Bay. Shark Bay is being investigated for World Heritage nomination by a State appointed committee to prevent it from becoming an election issue before we go to the polls early next year. Meanwhile, land degradation and speculation continue unabated at Shark Bay. It is one of the areas which are detailed to some degree in the edition of Time magazine to which I have referred.

Sustainable development is the recognition that the earth's natural resources are part of an interconnected ecosystem and that the system-wide effects of exploitation must be accounted for in the overall budget of sustainable yield. Put another way, in assessing long term costs and benefits of proposed developments and policies, environmental effects must be given precedence, and not be treated as an afterthought. At present, environmental impact assessment is treated as an afterthought. It effectively occurs after approvals in principle have been given by the relevant Ministers and the deals with industry have been worked out. Environmental consultants are then given the job of assessing the proposed development's effects in the best light possible, for their client to clear this last hurdle.

While the environmental regulatory authorities do the best job possible under the existing governments' attitudes, the resulting long term environmental costs are usually left for future generations to contend with. A current example in Western Australia is a proposal by a French Government-owned company to process radioactive mineral sands and to dispose of the radiotoxic waste in ponds and shallow burial sites. From the very beginning, support and approvals in principle were given by the relevant State Minister and the then Federal Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, to facilitate the acceptance of this development. Outcries from residents and environmentalists concerning the company's inadequate environmental assessment resulted in the Government taking on the responsibility for the transport and disposal of the radioactive waste, which will be with us for thousands of years. The Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) recommended against this environmentally damaging stage 2, and so far the Government says that it accepts the EPA's findings. Whether or not this process results in the project being scrapped, as residents would like, it has been expensive because environmental considerations have been left until last.

Within a sustainable world view, the lifestyles of most young professionals in Australia would be defined as overdeveloped. The agricultural resources alone to support an average Australian's eating habits amount to five times that required by an average Indian, Nigerian or Colombian. The conversion of grain to meat, as well as overeating and wastage, accounts for much of the difference. Apparently, the average American carries nearly 10 tonnes of steel around with him or her in cars and household equipment. Hundreds of kilograms of additional metals and plastics are contained in various appliances and so-called necessities. In addition, some 300 kilograms of wrappings, bottles and cans are used and thrown away per year per person. Judging from the roadside litter and the love of disposables in the Parliament House of Australia, I would not think the rates would be much less in this country.

In addition to generating nasty lifestyle diseases and degrading our environment, this pattern of development has serious implications for the majority of the world's people, who live in underdeveloped nations. At the source of violent conflict is insecurity, and the real sources of insecurity encompass unsustainable development and resource inequities between classes, races, genders and nations. Development is not a neutral factor in this equation. Its value lies in how it is achieved; that is, at what cost to the environment and future generations. For example, the arms race has grossly distorted the development of science and technology, because approximately 25 per cent of the world's scientists are directly engaged in military research and so-called development. In the United States of America, over 60 per cent of all Federal research and development funding went to aerospace and defence programs in 1980.

In 1983, Commission for the Future Chairperson, Dr Ian Lowe, pointed out that because some 90 per cent of Australian energy research is funded by the Commonwealth Government, it is critical to ask whether the thrust of energy research is consistent with sustainable resource use and the public interest. Traditionally, there has been a heavy emphasis on supply technologies while neglecting the social, political and economic factors affecting energy demand. The Government's Energy 2000 document does little to reverse this trend. Despite repeated calls from the academic, scientific and environmental communities to adopt an energy policy to provide central direction for appropriate research, and the enormous challenge posed by the greenhouse effect to change our mode of resource use, this Government has refused to provide the needed direction.

This Government's commitment to a balance between development and conservation in Australia is going to require money up front-more money than we are accustomed to spending on our life support systems but less than if we keep putting off the debt. We do that at our peril, and we do future generations a great disservice if, as a nation, we ignore warning signs and continue only to mouth platitudes rather than getting on with the real change of direction, setting new priorities and adequately funding them. That is the Government's responsibility, if it looks further than the next election. Young Australians have a right to look to us, as elected representatives of the people, and I believe they have a right to expect an all-party push for the care of our environment. It should not be too much to expect. After all, we do not inherit the earth from our forefathers, but we are mere borrowers of the earth from our children. A most important and serious task is for us to be good stewards of this fragile yet beautiful environment. Surely, there is enough for everyone's need but not for everyone's greed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating these Appropriation Bills, I would like to address in particular the subject of appropriations for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The veteran community in this country is not happy. Probably more than anything else, veterans resent the fact that they have to fight with the Department for every so-called entitlement. In other words, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, their Department so to speak, is too often the adversary rather than the advocate of the veterans' cause. This role reversal must be rectified. It has become only too apparent to me that there is a growing dissatisfaction and suspicion among veterans. They believe, rightly, that this Government has decided that the time has come to begin the process of merging veterans' administration into welfare at large, a process already begun by hospital mergers. Despite denials and despite some modest acknowledgment of special needs, for instance in relation to Vietnam veterans counselling, the trend of the past few years has been to contract the range of veterans' entitlements and to contract effectiveness of dollars expended in this portfolio. These trends have given rise to suspicion, resentment and disillusionment in attitudes which are now directed at both the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give just one powerful illustration of this negative attitude of veterans towards the Department. In the last three issues of the newsletter of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, titled Debrief, there has been a series of articles which have given vent to this unfortunate disillusionment and distrust. I would like to quote from some of those articles. Under the heading `Chieu Hoi Charleys Debrief', subheaded `Doings at the Department-Vetaffairs Dirty Tricks Department' a review recently analysed the attitude of the Department towards veterans' claims for entitlement. I quote from page 11 of the last issue of Debrief:

In recent times considerable attention has been focused on the existence of a `cell' of bright young legal eagles operating within the wong-towered auspices of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in Canberra. The principal function of this `cell', which I can assure you does indeed exist-
that is the assurance of the author-
is to make veterans fight every inch of the way and incur as much expense as possible in order to obtain the benefits which are rightfully theirs under current veterans legislation.
The article continues:

The ``cell'', or to give it its correct title of the ``Advocacy Branch'' approaches its task by ``going for the jugular'' at every opportunity it gets. In the process, it is making a mockery of established approaches to the administration of remedial legislation and the claim by its employing department that ``Vetaffairs cares''. The veteran community is regarded as the ``enemy''-to be defeated whenever possible and by any means possible. A review of a number of recent appeal cases heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the Tribunal) and the Veterans' Review Board (VRB) should serve to illustrate my point.

This article goes on to vent the animosity and disillusionment of veterans concerning the administration of `their department' and of legislation in relation to `their entitlement'. Much to the indictment of the Department, it cites a series of cases where this attitude would appear to prevail. It cites the case of John Elliott and the Repatriation Commission centring on the rather controversial concept of the application and the application day. It cites the case of Fitzmaurice and the Repatriation Commission. It cites the case of McMaugh and the Repatriation Commission. It cites the case of McGuine and the Repatriation Commission where it says:

. . . the same band of intellectual giants argued that a digger who had been forced to give up work due to his accepted disabilities should have his assessment reduced to reflect an ``absence of work related stress''. The Tribunal was unimpressed. Perhaps understandably so.
They argue that:

The same line of reasoning would see a double amputee's pension reduced because he didn't need to buy as many socks, or a bed-ridden digger's pension reduced because he didn't need to buy clothing or footwear. They never give up!

TALK.START.PARA: —You are kidding, aren't you?

—I am quoting from the newsletter of a veterans' group-the most recent veterans-which exhibits their attitude towards their Department administering their legislation. The resentment is extraordinary and the last three issues of this newsletter ooze, build up, stack up and express this resentment. It is real. The newsletter quotes the case of Repatriation Commission v. Law-that is now the infamous Nancy Law case-as well as the Repatriation Commission v. H. Lee. I will continue to quote from just the last of these newsletters which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In a recent VRB case an advocate really did his homework, and hit the Board with an ancient Latin maxim in arguing that a digger's service-related smoking habit amounted to ``volenti non fit injuria (a voluntary assumption of a risk). If taken to the limit, this argument would deny benefits to any diggers who enlisted voluntarily or did something ``about and beyond the call of duty''.
Further on, the same article says:

It is obvious that the Department's Advocacy Branch is not concerned with the proper administration of the Act. It has instead declared ``open season'' on what it sees as ``repat bludgers'' in order to save the Department's precious money. Every pension and entitlement to treatment knocked back means money saved.

However, in order to realise its goals, the Advocacy Branch is operating in a manner akin to a bunch of corporate lawyers engaged in a big-business litigation. Typically, this type of litigation is conducted on a no-holds-barred basis.

I will not go on, but it is simply sad to see documented in this way, and so recently, the resentment and bitterness that typify the attitude of ex-diggers and veterans to the administration of their Department.

Recently in the other place the honourable member for Reid, Mr Tom Uren, expressed his resentment about the attitude of his own Cabinet and his own Ministers in relation to the administration of the Department. I quote from Mr Uren's speech on 20 October 1988 in the other place, when he said:

However, my remarks today are strong criticism of those Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet who I have often described as having cash registers for hearts and little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows.
This is a member of the present Government, a former Minister, speaking of the attitude of the present Government specifically to ex-prisoners of war. He said:
This speech is not about reparations from the Japanese Government but about justice from our own Government.

It is a powerful speech and I would recommend it to members of the Government, the Opposition and the public as a genuine statement of a concerned Government member about the attitude of his own Government towards veterans.

In the Senate on 8 December 1987 I referred to a brief paper which had been prepared and circulated by veterans' groups in my State of New South Wales entitled `Summary of Losses by Veterans between 1985 and 1987'. I took the article on trust at the time, as I do now, and invited correction by the Minister should it be in error. No corrections were forthcoming. That document cited 18 areas in which veterans' entitlements and circumstances have been eroded since the May statement of 1985 through the veterans' entitlements Acts of 1986 and 1987 and the economic statement of May 1988. Some of those erosions of entitlement which I cited are as follows: the deletion of dependants' pensions; the reductions in pharmaceutical entitlements for red card holders; the reduction in dental benefits; the deletion of 10 per cent disability pension assistance when glasses are prescribed; restrictions on the issue of glasses; intermediate or special rate disability pensions that have come under fire; non-reimbursement rights when obtaining supporting medical opinions; absolutely unacceptable criteria inherent in the guide to assessment of entitlements which, fortunately, has been reviewed, but the reviews are yet to come into effect and the change of the system has yet to be assessed.

Other erosions include the offensive life-styles questionnaire which, fortunately, also has come under review but the effectiveness of that review is yet to be assessed; the means testing of the veterans' children's education scheme; the deletion of the intellectually handicapped dependants' allowance; freezing of the social security portion of war widows' pensions; and restriction of travel and mileage allowance for veterans when attending review boards or presenting the case for their entitlements. These are 13 of the 18 cited areas in which pensioners' entitlements have been eroded in the last three years.

Some of the Government's recent actions have been more hurtful than others. The one that rocked us all was the introduction of the $117 per week for nursing home care levied on totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners presently in nursing homes. This small group of people-there are only about 750 of them-have always been regarded as special Australians who deserve our special gratitude. Yet, cruelly, on 1 January 1988, the beginning of the great celebration of the nation, the Government changed its attitude towards these people and served them, for the first time, with a Bill of $117 per week for the rest of their lives. I believe that that was a shameful act. I tried to stop it by an amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill but, sadly, my amendment was defeated by the combined vote of the Government, the Liberals and the Nationals.

There is quite specific and tangible evidence of the Government's attitude to veterans generally, and of the Opposition's collusion with the Government to spend as little as possible on veterans. There are also many people in our veterans' community who are very dissatisfied because they feel they should be entitled to benefits which the Government denies them. The merchant seamen who survived the most dangerous and deplorable conditions during war are currently battling the Department for adequate recognition of their status as veterans. Even though such acknowledgment has been granted by other allies, the Government still has not acknowledged the equality in all wars of women who served in combat zones.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was probing the depths of disillusionment out in the veteran community concerning the attitude of the present Government towards veterans' entitlements, particularly the way in which the Veterans' Entitlements Act is being administered by the Department at the moment and the fact that it seems to be locked into an adversary role rather than an advocacy role. Unfortunately, in some of these battles the Opposition has gone with the Government in opposing amendments to entitlements. All in all, there is very widespread disillusionment in the veteran community. In fact, I had cited the last three editions of the Vietnam Veterans Association newsletter Debrief which documents in some measure the extent of that ill feeling that is prevailing at the moment. I had cited 18 areas in which veterans' entitlements have been eroded since 1985. This process of erosion, together with the posture being adopted by the Department and the Minister in relation to veterans' entitlements-the fact that veterans have to fight so hard and vigorously to overcome every resistance to gain those entitlements-has served only to entrench the resentment.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I was in the process of citing a number of specific groups that have not as yet won those entitlements. I had made reference to the fact that, for instance, the women who served in combat zones in wars have not yet achieved equal status to males who served in those zones. I cited the fact that the merchant seamen who made such profound sacrifices have not yet gained equal entitlements to other veterans. The Vietnam Medal is being sought by members of the HMAS Sydney Veterans and Logistic Support Group and by Vietnam war correspondents but they continue to be denied the right to wear a decoration to which they believe they are totally entitled. Even though they have all other entitlements, they are being denied the right to wear medals that they believe are rightfully theirs and they are very resentful of this denial.

In a series of questions in this place over the last few months I have indicated that it has even been suggested that a number of those veterans, by virtue of their being members of their organisation, belong to a subversive organisation. Even though that accusation has been profoundly denied the two co-founders of the organisation in question have suffered dire consequences. One has been forced to resign from the Naval Reserve and one has been forced to resign from a State police force, and they attribute the need to resign to the fact that they are supposedly branded as subversives. As extraordinary as such an accusation might seem, that is what these people truly believe about the reaction to their fighting for their entitlements as veterans.

Of course there is the continuing saga of the nuclear veterans' fight for their rights. The Johnston case, which is a key deliberation in relation to the rights of nuclear veterans, is before the New South Wales Supreme Court at the moment. I cannot comment in detail beyond saying that it will cost the taxpayer millions of dollars in legal fees and other costs, probably ultimately denying Mr Johnston what he and his fellow nuclear veterans have always believed since they took part in the tests at Maralinga to be their rightful entitlements as veterans, even though Britain has long since acknowledged the entitlement of its nuclear veterans to such veterans' privileges. It is quite possible that the Government will spend literally tenfold what it would cost it to grant this man and his colleagues their entitlements. It will spend that much in order to deny that entitlement through court action.

Of course a number of national servicemen believe that, even though they did not serve in Vietnam, they are being discriminated against because they have not received some of the entitlements, such as access to housing loans, which were extended to Vietnam veterans even though it was not by virtue of their having served in Vietnam that they gained such entitlements. So we have numerous examples of people who believe that they are truly entitled to such entitlements not gaining them, and who have been fighting those battles for or in excess of 20 years. They will continue to fight those battles and I will continue to support them in that process.

Several things are worth noting about the plight of the nuclear veterans. There are very few of them and it would cost the Government so little to acknowledge their service. Britain has long since acknowledged the entitlements of its equivalents and the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1952 and 1963 assembled vast evidence in their support. Here is a further example of a `cash register for a heart' phenomenon which was so powerfully referred to by the Hon. Tom Uren in the other place and to which I referred earlier.

Merchant seamen, Vietnam logistic support groups, nuclear veterans and some national servicemen all feel neglected, denied and abandoned by a Government that purports to support the entitlements of veterans. So many who are entitled feel offended by continued and persistent rejection by the very Minister and Department supposedly serving their needs.

I think two relevant analogies could be drawn. Firstly, the Government's attitude to the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam is indicative of its attitude towards veterans in general. Faced with an overwhelming and growing mass of evidence that the findings of the Royal Commission are flawed beyond redemption, the Government has chosen to bury its collective head in the sand and to hope that the problem will go away, thereby spending as little money on veterans as possible. The Government's attitude to veterans in general is, `Do not do anything and, if you are compelled to do something, fight the veteran tooth and nail'-through the Department's so-called advocacy branch-`before you are forced to give to the veteran any benefits or entitlements'. Little wonder, therefore, that the resentment of the magnitude that I cited earlier is now beginning to express itself in the veteran community.

Secondly, the way in which the Government treats veterans is linked inextricably to the manner in which the Government treats members of the Defence Force, which I spoke about earlier in today's urgency motion debate. It is no wonder that the morale of the Australian Defence Force has plummeted and that rates of wastage are massive. I spent almost 20 years of my life in and around the Army, including the Vietnam years. I know veterans and I know how veterans view the Department of Veterans' Affairs at the moment. Indeed, how veterans must inevitably view this Department has to be quite obvious to any person of sensitivity. Any dealing with the Department is another battle in a very long war for entitlement. At the moment the Department seems to be winning, keeping expenditure to an absolute minimum at the expense of veterans.

It is obvious to all of us involved with the veteran community that the Government intends, after the next election, to disband the Department of Veterans' Affairs and distribute its responsibilities between the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Social Security, keeping on the Repatriation Commission as an advisory body. The transfer of repatriation hospitals to the States, years earlier than promised, is the first swift step in that direction. The Government appears to be doing everything it can to further erode veterans' status as special individuals with special needs and, therefore, accelerating and easing the transition out of the specialty Department of Veterans' Affairs to the general welfare umbrella.

As far as the Democrats are concerned, this just is not good enough. Veterans are entitled to a special place in our society. That has been acknowledged by foregoing governments and that promise must be abided by. We cannot ask people to risk their lives in the service of their country and then desert them when and if they return home. We should not be treating these people, as is far too often the case, as an annoyance to be dealt with as quickly as possible and frustrating them in their pursuit of their entitlements. When the honourable member for Reid, Mr Tom Uren, described these people-and they were his own people, his own Cabinet-as `having cash registers for hearts' and as `having little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows', he was absolutely accurate. Sadly, but accurately, he was referring to members of the present Cabinet and Government and to the responsible Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document introduced to Parliament on 23 August to which the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1988-89, which we are debating this evening, give effect was not a Budget. A Budget is a blueprint for the management of the economy in the year to come. This document was a fraud, a put-up job, a false prospectus, a `Paul for PM' prospectus. Its purpose was to create phoney euphoria, front page headlines proclaiming that the world's greatest Treasurer had done it again. The media and others whom it was meant to deceive swallowed it hook, line and sinker-or should I say, Hawke, line and sinker. Who can forget the display of spleen and envy by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the following day? But it all came unstuck. Regrettably, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) counted his votes for the leadership challenge on the same fingers and toes he used to calculate the inflation rate and the balance of payments deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, all that I have said might be totally wrong. The Treasurer and the Government, as the sponsors of this Budget, might not be guilty of fraud and deception at all, but guilty merely of massive incompetence. It has to be one or the other. How else do we explain a forecast inflation rate of 4.5 per cent and a current rate headed for 6 to 8 per cent-an actual rate of 7.3 per cent at the end of the September quarter? How else do we explain a Budget forecast balance of payments deficit of $9.5 billion compared with the currently projected figure of $12 billion after October's second highest ever deficit of $1.69 billion? The one the Government got right, the forecast of a stronger Australian dollar in 1988-89, turns out to be an equal indictment of incompetence. The dollar is stronger-not because of a stronger economy, but rather because a panic stricken Government tightened monetary policy, jacked up interest rates and invited a consequent inflow of foreign money.

Remember on Budget night the Treasurer's preening and lipsmacking claim that he was bringing home the bacon? This Budget turns out to be another part of a pig's anatomy-and he cannot blame anyone else. He cannot blame the usual litany of fall guys: Howard, Fraser, Menzies-Billy Hughes! He cannot invoke the usual Keating cop-out that his forecasts were made in good faith and overtaken by unexpected economic deterioration, because at the time the Budget was handed down a survey of 40 academic and business economists set out average forecasts that were much more pessimistic and, as we see, much more accurate than the Treasurer's. Keating predicted growth at 3.5 per cent; the experts said it would be 2.7 per cent. Inflation, Paul told us, would be 4.5 per cent. The professionals said that it would be 5.7 per cent. The Treasurer put the balance of payments deficit at $9.5 billion. The unbiased opinion of people who do this sort of thing for a living was $10.6 billion. They were optimistic, weren't they? But then, these expert economists were not surveying the mantlepieces at the Lodge for the best spot to park an antique French clock. Their priorities did not include a by-election in Oxley and getting John Cain back in Victoria before the Victorian Economic Development Corporation hit the fan.

The truth is that the Australian economy is dangerously vulnerable because this Government has abandoned the real job of economic management for a desperate and dishonest exercise in manipulating the political agenda. The needs of the Australian people run second to getting Bob and Paul re-elected. Thus, in the lead-up to the Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Groom by-elections and the New South Wales State election, this Government eased monetary policy and forced down interest rates. As a result, we are failing to reap the full benefits of commodity price improvements, and the balance of payments deficit runs $3 billion higher than under a realistic monetary policy.

Only days before the Victorian State election we had Keating, Hawke and even the Governor of the Reserve Bank anticipating that interest rates would fall. Only days afterwards interest rates exploded. And who were the participants in that process? They were the same people who gave us the fudge-it Budget-the Canberra branch of the Dodgy brothers, Keating and Hawke. But for all the sleight of hand and hype, this Government can no longer hide from the Australian people the central fact of Australian politics today-that in a period of unparalleled international economic growth, the Hawke Labor Government has presided over a massive decline in the living standards of ordinary Australians. Although money wages have risen at twice the rate of those of our trading partners, the average weekly wage earner with a dependent spouse and two children needs a tax cut of $56 a week to restore the same disposable income he enjoyed when Labor came to power in March 1983. He needs $56 a week, or one-sixth of the Treasurer's travelling allowance. There are two reasons for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to tell us your policy?

—Our policy, when it is released, will ensure that the standards of living of the Australian people are restored to the levels they were able to enjoy before this disastrous Government came to office. The outline of that policy already gives enough detail to indicate the directions in which we will head. The more specific details will be released at an appropriate time and will ensure that the honourable senator's Government is defeated at the next election. Before I was interrupted by the honourable senator, I was saying that there are two reasons for the fall in living standards: lack of productivity improvement and excessive taxation. We pay ourselves more and become less competitive. The end result is to fuel inflation. And who benefits from that? The Treasurer's coffers benefit through that fiscal phenomenon, bracket creep. People receive an illusory wage rise that simply pushes them into a higher tax bracket. Their income is no higher in real terms because of inflation, but they lose a bigger slice of it in tax. From this bracket creep rort alone the Treasurer has ripped an extra $8 billion a year out of taxpayers' pockets. Next year it will be $10 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that this Government is addicted to higher taxation. The Treasurer is a tax junkie mainlining other people's money. He cannot survive without his regular fix of new or increased taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not pay his own, though.
—We know that.
—He has not even filled in the returns.

—He is late with his returns and he maintains that travelling allowance rort. Since coming to office the Hawke Government has introduced over 300 taxation measures. That is better than one a week. Those designed to increase the tax take outnumber those designed to reduce it by 2 : 1. We have had new taxes: the capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, entertainment tax, and the Medicare levy. Let us not forget the boomerang tax: the airport arrivals tax that comes back to us via the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been tax intrusions into new areas. There is sales tax on citrus drinks, wine and flavoured milk. The tax on superannuation and the taxes on Telecom Australia and Australia Post amount to backdoor taxation of essential services. This Government has invented tax by stealth in the form of automatic indexation of excise on beer and cigarettes, and of passport charges. It has abolished worthwhile rebates and concessions on health insurance and housing interest and reduced the depreciation allowance for farmers and industry. If it breathes, tax it; if it works, tax it.

In the life of the Hawke Government inflation and average weekly earnings have increased by some 50 per cent. But personal income tax is up by 107 per cent; company income taxes have increased by 133 per cent; and sales tax is up by 147 per cent and rising.

No wonder people cannot get ahead. No wonder people are starting to draw comparisons between the current catastrophe and the last days of the Whitlam Government. But even at Whitlam's worst we were spared the sight of Gough sunning himself in his Speedos on a banana lounge at Kirribilli House. That was the response of the Prime Minister to the September balance of trade setback. It is his only response: `Trust me. Trust the Treasurer'-even though they do not trust each other-`Get yourself a banana lounge, sit in the sun and wait for the tax cuts'.

But do not hold your breath. The truth is that this Government's mismanagement has turned the long awaited tax cuts into a mirage. Much needed and greatly deserved as they are, we are already being softened up to expect less-much less, if anything at all. Or does the Treasurer have a secret weapon, a Commissioner of Taxation who has seen too many Rambo movies, who declares he will override the law of the land to maximise his tax take? Have Mr Boucher's instructions come from above perhaps? `Grab every cent you can off them by hook or by crook, no matter who gets hurt, to fatten up our surplus this year. We will use it to fund the tax cuts on the eve of the next election, even if we have to give most of it back later through appeals, after we are re-elected'. Keating has collected so much Louis XIV he thinks he is Louis XIV.

I referred earlier to two prime causes of the shameful fall in living standards under this Government. After excessive taxation, the second of these causes lies in Australia's poor productivity performance. This can be traced directly to our outdated industrial relations structure. At the National Press Club in May this year Mr Keating declared that the Government's policy objective was to create a flexible industrial relations system in which wages and conditions reflect the different levels of prosperity of various industries. He called this the most important remaining area of reform. In June, at the Australian Labor Party National Conference in Hobart, barely a month later, Mr Keating made no reference whatsoever to labour market reform. What happened to it? Did he lose it at the roulette table or was it traded off in yet another of Labor's interminable backroom deals?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the money he had in that bag on that occasion?

—Yes, we might ask questions about that too. Living standards have fallen and will continue to fall because Australia is economically uncompetitive, because our industrial relations system is entirely inadequate for the latter part of the twentieth century, as are most creations of the early 1900s. The last thing business and workers need in today's economic circumstances is a system of built-in conflicts, centralised wage movements and ever-broadening barriers of protectionism. The new Industrial Relations Act debated here only a few weeks ago enshrines the Hawke Government's failure to act on its own agenda. That legislation bears all the hallmarks of those de facto Cabinet members Crean and Kelty. It will deny Australia the chance under this Government to develop the greater cooperation between employers and employees at the workplace level which is essential to lift productivity and so improve living standards. Real industrial relations reform will have to await the election of a coalition government. This, we know, will take place about a fortnight after the tax cuts, or lack of them.
