SPEECH.PARA: A coalition government will deregulate industrial relations and tackle the hard areas, like the national embarrassment that passes for our waterfront, where four officers who dislike Fijian politics can close a major port; where 16,000 containers are tied up on our wharves; where nick-off days on full pay and chronic overmanning are standard work practices costing the Australian people and economy millions of dollars. The Castle Bacon case is a step in the right direction. It demonstrates that, despite this Government's neglect, at long last the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is beginning to understand what voluntary agreements are all about. At last we see legal recognition that workers and management have mutual interests and that the interests of workers often differ from those of union officials who claim to speak for them. For all Treasurer Keating's rhetoric, it was Castle who brought home the bacon.

To the extent that the Australian economy remains afloat, it reflects no credit on this Government; it is due simply to the hard work and international competitiveness of our rural producers. Rising commodity prices alone have saved the Treasurer's bacon, and even these in Australian dollar terms have been largely offset by the fall in the American dollar. Again, for all the Treasurer's rhetoric, what we have to thank for this immediate relief is the American drought and the situation of shrinking world stocks. It is some economic management, when Australia's living standards depend on whether it rains in Kansas! Prices continue to rise and seasonal conditions have been generally good so far this year, with the tragic exception of South Australia's Eyre Peninsula, to which this Government turns an ungrateful blind eye.

The gross value of rural production is forecast to increase by 9 per cent to $21.6 billion in 1988-89. While this is welcome, do not forget that last fiscal year the gross value of rural production remained stagnant at zero growth. In fact, according to the September 1988 issue of the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, gross value of crops has increased a meagre 5.6 per cent over the six years since 1983-84. So just as the Government misread the strength of the commodity prices boom over the last two years, it is now relying too heavily on that improvement. It ignores the potential tapering off in world economic activity and commodity demand. It ignores a possible fall in world inflation, possible increases in United States interest rates and financial market instability.

The sad thing is that Australia's difficulties are essentially unnecessary. They could be overcome by the right policy initiatives, and they will be. The last time Australia was competitive with other developed economies, the last time our inflation rate was below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, was in the early 1980s under the Fraser coalition Government with John Howard as Treasurer; the next time will be under a coalition government led by John Howard. In the meantime, I suggest the Treasurer should forget about the Prime Ministership until he can cope with prime numbers. I suggest this Government should learn the differences between a responsible Budget and vanity publishing, and I suggest we give these Bills the title they deserve-the misappropriation Bills. For these reasons the Opposition amendment warrants the strong support of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and the Advance to the Minister for Finance 1987-88 and to support the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Chaney, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate condemns the . . . Government for . . .
(a) producing stagnant productivity, high inflation, a continuing balance of payments crisis and rising interest rates which are hurting business and home buyers alike;

(b) raising, then dashing, Aboriginal expectations with unrealistic and divisive promises on national land rights and a so-called treaty and for appalling mismanagement at both ministerial and bureaucratic levels; and
(c) coercing participation in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey in the face of substantial doubt about its validity and legal basis,

and calls on the Australian people, as they have done in by-elections this year, to reject the Hawke Government and support the policies of the Liberal and National Parties, which reflect community values and which will deliver improved living standards for those millions of Australians who have been abandoned by a Labor Government now totally out of touch with their hopes and aspirations.

I think that says it all. There are two areas to which I wish to direct my attention tonight. The first is taxation and the second is program budgeting. The European countries are moving with ever-increasing speed towards the constitution in 1992 of a European community of trading nations which will be perhaps the biggest and most effective trading market in the world, involving 350 million people. There is great fear that it will become a `fortress Europe' and defend itself by imposing high protection barriers against other countries. I think these fears are exaggerated because the lifeblood of the Economic Community will be trade. It will have problems in working out what trading language and currency to use. Undoubtedly, these matters will be resolved quickly and Australia will be faced with this new trading bloc.

In the last week there has been an election in Canada. The issue in that election was closer trading relations with the United States of America. Undoubtedly, Canada and the United States will become a huge trading bloc. Certainly, to some extent the reason is the fact that they see a need to consolidate, to act as some kind of foil or counterfoil to what is happening in Europe. The European trading community will form one of the most important trading blocs that the world has ever seen. It will be bigger than, for example, the Soviet Union and it will certainly be bigger than Japan or China. Australia must face up to a reorientation of the whole of its business arrangements.

I am sure that none of the countries of Europe are particularly concerned with the future of Australia. However, I think Australia should be concerned with the developments that are happening around the world, such as the advent of this European Economic Community. We cannot rely on old trading agreements and favoured nation status as we did in the past for assurance of our markets. Companies that want to get involved in the European Economic Community will have to start making joint venture agreements and other agreements with companies in countries that are already involved in the European Economic Community.

As I said, I want to talk about tax. Australia, being a common law country, has developed policies concerning what is income and what is capital according to our old common law philosophies. These have been outdated by the new mercantile trading world into which we are moving and into which all other countries have moved. If we are to have lead in our saddlebags of our taxation laws, that will put Australia at a trading disadvantage and will affect foreign investment in Australia. For example, if we do not have the same tax structures as other countries, there will be no incentive to invest in Australia. If we do not get involved in the tax harmonisation measures that are taking place in the world today, Australia will have big problems.

I have mentioned the difference between capital and income, which is regarded entirely differently in other countries. The starting-up expenses of a company in Australia are regarded as capital expenses; overseas, these expenses are able to be deducted either immediately or rapidly over a period of five years. This is an important measure because overseas it attracts innovation and updating of machinery, plant and factories. In Australia, we do not have that incentive. Expenses for intangibles, such as good will and patents, are not regarded as a disposable expense in Australia. They are regarded as part of capital, whereas overseas they are not.

Australian tax laws are discriminating against equity capital-the capital that is required of people who want to invest in a business. It is discriminating against the starting up of companies. In Europe the costs of buying good will, trade names, trademarks or other intangibles of a wasting nature are deductible over a very short period, perhaps five years. In Australia, they are not; they are regarded as capital. In Australia, we have a restricted number of those intangibles. They are deductable, but over a much longer period, which is to Australia's disadvantage.

In the matter of capital losses, in Australia one is only allowed to deduct those losses against capital gains. Again, this is different from what occurs in Europe, where capital losses can be deducted against trading profits. In Europe, capital gains can be rolled over, so long as the gain on the sale of an asset is reinvested in a replacement asset. For example, when a replacement for a factory is acquired, this is allowed as a capital gains deduction. That facility promotes modernisation and innovation, whereas in Australia the roll-over of replacement assets is available only when the original asset is destroyed, perhaps by fire, or compulsorily taken over.

To bring Australia's tax laws into line with those of Europe, it would be necessary to allow for the deduction of provisions for employees' accrued leave, for repairs when deterioration occurs-not when repairs are carried out, as is presently the case-and for bad debts based on previous experience. Naturally, these provisions could lead to abuse, but surely, in order to catch up with what is happening overseas, we have the wit to control such abuses. Actually, a single rate of tax in Australia would solve a lot of these problems, but insufficient people support that concept.

A similar trend has occurred with regard to tariff harmonisation over the last 20 years throughout the world. Many countries, including Australia, now subscribe to a policy of tariff harmonisation. This has been to the benefit of trade. The same situation exists with regard to taxation in Australia. We should have tax harmonisation in Australia in order to give our companies a chance to compete on the world market and in order to be in a position to attract foreign investment, so that our tax laws are in harmony with those of other countries. Pressures will arise to implement this policy, and I am sure Australia will move to adopt it. I think it would be to Australia's advantage if we adopted it of our own volition rather than waiting to have it forced on us and our having to catch up with what is happening overseas in the new mercantile trading world.

One of the distortions that have occurred in our economy over recent years has been the debt financing of takeovers of profitable businesses in order to obtain a tax advantage. Wherever one finds there is a substantial tax advantage, it distorts the economy because people try to achieve it. Curiously, in Australia the companies that have been the best prey for this type of raid were the ones that had no debts, were completely paid off, were earning profits, paying dividends and paying taxes. Entrepreneurs found that by borrowing money, frequently from overseas, they could buy these companies, which put the companies suddenly into debt. They were no longer paying dividends or taxes. They were still making profits, but all of the profits were going overseas in order to pay off the debts and the interest on those debts.

This situation is not the fault of the companies. It is the fault of our archaic taxation system. We are seeing that this very day with business entrepreneurs from Australia trying to buy into companies overseas with debt financing. We are seeing it with the breweries in Scotland at the moment, and the attempted Lonrho purchase. The people who are subject to these raids are worried because they say that they are being bought by debt financiers. They are profitable companies that have an income and can afford to pay off the debt. But our financiers from Australia think that they are brilliant men. Because of the tax advantage of being able to deduct the interest on the huge loans that they get to buy these companies they see it as an economic deal. People overseas do not. They are calling for inquiries into the liquidity of the companies that are attempting to purchase them. That is not the fault of the entrepreneurs. It is not the fault of the company. It is the fault of the tax system which is distorting the type of business being done.
I would like the Senate to consider the complete dissociation from reality of our Taxation Office in Australia today, and particularly the Commissioner of Taxation. I would like to quote his words:

A continuing source of concern to me is the proportion of time, effort and top brain power some of Australia's largest corporations and wealth holders devote to the protection of wealth from the claims of society-
that is, in relation to taxation-
compared with that they devote to the creation of wealth.
He went on to say:

How much greater a nation might we become if this time and talent were devoted to creating more real wealth, rather than squirrelling away what the rest of the community is entitled to share through taxation.

That is the most negative approach any tax office could have to the stimulation of incentive and business development in any country. I am reminded of the Roman Empire which had tax commissioners in every village and every town but they were not allowed to collect more tax than the people were willing to pay. If they did, the people were entitled to kill them. The Roman Empire flourished for 500 years until it started to collect too much tax. This is what is happening here and it is reflected in the attitude of the Australian Taxation Office which is completely anti-business.

In 1987-88 the Australian Taxation Office collected $60 billion, which was an increase of nearly 15 per cent on the year before. This year it will collect $68 billion, which is up another 14 per cent on the previous year. The Commissioner says that the Australian Taxation Office is a successful business. That is entirely untrue; it is a parasite on business. It is a necessary one and I do not argue that point. It is his attitude and the way in which he is going around attacking business at the moment that I disagree with. The Commissioner says that it is a successful business and under the Treasurer's instructions he is coming down on businesses like a ton of bricks and treating them all as crooks. This is no way to get the business community to respond and earn money. The Taxation Commissioner himself is making increasingly stringent and, worse, unpredictable rulings. He is losing court case after court case as harassed citizens take him to court. Not only that, the Commissioner is attracting the wrath and the admonition of the judiciary in Australia for instigating these cases against business people in the first place.

There has been a great breakdown in the relationship between the people and the Taxation Office in Australia. I see this as a fearful thing in this country. We should be agreeable to paying taxes but if the tax rates are too high everybody will revolt against them. The whole problem of widespread rorts, tax minimisation schemes and the fringe benefits tax was brought about by high tax rates.

Instead of lowering the tax rates and giving people incentive to get on, make more money and generate more business, the Government has turned around and started to tax fringe benefits, capital gains and every other thing. That is just making the whole situation worse. The Government does not recognise the initial problem. The vast bulk of the increased revenue that is accruing to the Taxation Office right now is coming from people because their incomes have edged up into higher tax brackets which attract higher tax. By the time people have paid their tax, their mortgage interest and any interest they have on any other loan, they have very little left. This is the reason for the standard of living dropping as it has in Australia today. People are not prepared to work harder because if they do they pay higher tax.

There is a common misconception, aided and abetted by the Australian Labor Party, that it is the big companies that are getting away with high profits to the detriment of the working man. But nothing could be further from the truth. The truth is that the bulk of the taxes are paid by the bulk of the people. If one took all the profits of the top 100 companies in Australia today, not just their tax but every skerrick of their profits, that would run the Government for only a few weeks, which is not a very long time. The main tax comes from the bulk of the people, the pay as you earn taxpayers. They are paying more tax because they are going into higher tax brackets. In 1957 the number of taxpayers with a tax rate of 40 per cent or higher was one in 50. In 1987 it was one in two. Those figures speak for themselves.

Since coming into office the Hawke Labor Government has introduced over 300 taxation measures. Those designed to increase taxation have outnumbered those designed to decrease taxation by two to one. The Government has used various methods to increase taxes. There have been four new taxes: the capital gains tax; the fringe benefits tax; the entertainment tax; and the Medicare levy. There have been three extensions of taxes into new areas. They have been the sales tax on citrus products, wine, flavoured milk, et cetera; the superannuation taxes; and the tax on Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Three measures have been introduced to bring about automatic indexation of taxes: the excise on beer and cigarettes; fees for passports; and petrol taxes. There have been three abolitions of rebates and concessions: the abolition of the health insurance rebate, the abolition of housing interest rebates and the reduction of the depreciation allowance for farmers and industry. So far as bracket creep is concerned, the Government has let inflation push wage earners into higher and higher tax brackets. As a result of this concerted effort, taxes have increased dramatically since Labor came to office. For example, personal income taxes are up 107 per cent, company income taxes are up 133 per cent and sales taxes are up 147 per cent. During the same period inflation and average weekly earnings have gone up by about 50 per cent.

So much for tax. Before my time expires, I want to say a few words on program budgeting. Although there is a renewed emphasis on budgetary and financial management in the Commonwealth Government, program budgeting has been less than effective as an enhancement of budgetary documentation. Better information on programs, program objectives and performance indicators is essential if Parliament and Senate Estimates committees in particular are to carry out expenditure control. The Audit Act of 1901 places responsibility for the control and coordination of the Commonwealth's financial transactions on the Minister for Finance. It states:
The Minister shall cause to be kept proper accounts and records of receipts of, and payment out of, public moneys.
It stated further:
The Minister shall, after the expiration of each month of each financial year publish a Statement of Financial Transactions.
It then stated:
The Minister shall prepare a statement of the receipts and expenditure of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the Loan Fund and the Trust Fund during that year in respect of each Department.

The administrative arrangements order placed responsibility for the examination and evaluation of expenditure proposals and programs with the Department of Finance. The Department is also responsible for the collection and review of Forward Estimates. Announcing a reassessment of Budget documents in the paper Budget Performance: A Statement of the Government's Achievements and Intentions in Reforming the Australian Government Financial Administration, April 1984, the Minister stated:

The Government produces a very comprehensive set of budget documents. However, some were developed many years ago and, as a result, parts of the documents have outlived their original purpose and need to be reassessed as to their relevance to contemporary requirements. There are areas of duplication in the documents which will need to be eliminated; related information will need to be consolidated in meaningful and usable ways; the documents, even as they stand, would benefit from the provision of subject and other indexes. The Government sees a need to review these documents in a quite fundamental way to ensure that they meet the current information needs of Parliament and the public, and that they facilitate accountability by the Commonwealth administration.

These are all very beautiful words, but I want to explain what I think about program budgeting. The Department of Finance released Program Budgeting Specification and Guidelines in October 1985 to prescribe guidelines for the implementation and objectives of program budgeting. The specification and guidelines reinforced enhancement of budgetary documentation. I quote from that document:

By focusing budgetary processes more clearly on the purposes of government programs and emphasising the efficiency and effectiveness of their implementation, delivery and administration, the Government considers that program budgeting will assist its own budget decision making, assist parliamentary and public scrutiny and encourage more effective program management by Commonwealth agencies.

I move now to the report of Estimates Committee A of October 1984, which recommended that changes to the Budget documents should be examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I do not need to state the terms of reference of that Committee, but it was envisaged that program and subprogram statements would accompany the appropriations. The report stated:
The planned provision of program statements in the Budget Documents would be as additional information without any loss of detail provided in the present budget documents.
Program statements would include both narrative and financial information. Each program statement would provide:
a description of the program element;
its objective(s);
relevant financial information;
performance indicators-

which the Committee recognised would take some time to develop. Some examples of the presentation of program statements, including explanations of estimates for individual program elements, were provided. The Committee said that statements of program objectives and performance indicators would enable evaluation, and so on. However, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations emphasised the evolutionary and consultative process. It knew that some departments should have to trial this program budgeting. However, the Committee's second report contained the reports of Estimates Committees A and C. It recommended the refinement of Budget documents to eliminate discrepancies, but added:

The Committee does not believe it can comment further on these issues until program budgeting became more widely established, and especially until the pilot departments have had a second year of experience.

Then we come to this year. The 1988-89 appropriations examined by Estimates Committee F were those for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Social Security. The Committee emphasised unclear definitions of program objectives used for evaluating the efficiency of programs. In addition, it identified inadequacies in the presentation of program statements and explanatory notes. These inadequacies cover documentation, accomplishment of objectives, meaningful program objectives, execution and evaluation of programs, and selection of performance indicators. The report of Estimates Committee B for this year stated that its explanatory notes disclosed similar inadequacies, and it emphasised the requirement for the departments to improve their documentation, ensure that performance indicators are adequately developed, and assess the effects of external programs on departmental programs. The Committee emphasised the following point:
The larger issue, however, is the extent to which the presentation of explanatory material in program format assists the Senate and its Committees to scrutinise expenditure effectively.

I could go on. What I am saying is that, on the evidence before us, program budgeting is not a good way to go about assessing the Estimates of the Government. This system has been used in the United States, and I think we gained experience from that. But it has been ditched in the United States, and I hope that at some time in the future we will ditch it here in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Appropriation Bills, and this gives me the opportunity to bring the people's attention to the serious matter of taxpayers' money being spent illegally by a Government department, the Treasury. This is being done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in conducting an illegal compulsory household expenditure survey. This matter was first brought to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last July, when the survey was first implemented, by Mr Don Cameron, the member for Moreton. At that time Mr Cameron pointed out to the Treasurer that the household expenditure survey being undertaken by the Bureau of Statistics was a new survey and a compulsory survey, and that therefore its implementation was illegal. The only way the Bureau can conduct such a survey is to have it tabled before both Houses of Parliament before its implementation. Otherwise it must be a voluntary survey, not a compulsory one. This was not done.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Australian Statistician, Mr Castles, the reason for that survey's not being tabled was that it was not a new survey. He said that it was `virtually the same as the previous surveys in 1974-75 and 1975-76'. As Mr Cameron and I both pointed out on many occasions, the household expenditure survey is indeed a new survey. It is totally different from the surveys conducted previously. There are twice as many questions in this survey; they are far more intrusive than the questions in previous surveys. The format is different; so too is the methodology. Apart from anything else, the previous surveys were voluntary; this survey is compulsory. So how can the surveys possibly be virtually the same, as Mr Castles maintains?

I was so convinced that the survey was a new survey that I asked the Clerk of the Senate to give me a legal opinion. The Clerk's opinion was unequivocal. The survey was, in his opinion, a new survey and, because it was not tabled, it was being conducted illegally as a compulsory survey. The Clerk suggested that I get another opinion, so I asked him to get me one. Professor Whalan, Professor of Law at the Australian National University, was asked for his opinion. He gives legal opinions to the Senate. He gave me a similar opinion. As a result of these two legal opinions, the Bureau of Statistics panicked. Mr Castles, the chief Statistician, no doubt realising that he was now conducting an illegal survey, requested a legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department.

As I understand it, the Attorney-General's Department can give its client an opinion only as a result of the information with which it is supplied. I would like to quote from the final paragraph of the Bureau's letter to the Attorney-General's Department. It states:
The content of all four of the ABS household expenditure surveys has been virtually identical. The form in which the information has been sought has also remained unchanged.
I will leave out a bit of padding. The letter goes on:
The only significant difference in coverage has been that the 1974-75 survey, unlike the succeeding three surveys, was restricted to capital cities and-
this is important-

the only significant change in statistical methodology has been that in the case of rural households the period during which the personal diaries must be kept was reduced from four weeks in the 1975-76 and 1984 surveys to two weeks in the 1988-89 survey.

The Attorney-General did not ask for any further information. He did not ask to see the questions from both surveys so that he could compare them. I would like to quote from the Attorney-General's opinion, because I think that the way the Attorney-General's Department worded it is vital. The Attorney says to the Bureau of Statistics:

You state that the content of all four of the Household Expenditure Surveys has been virtually identical; also that the format in which the information has been sought has also remained unchanged. In this respect you have stated that for each Survey there is a `personal diary' for each member of the household, an `expenditure questionnaire' and an `income questionnaire' . . . You advise that the only significant change in statistical methodology has been that, in the case of rural households, the period during which the `personal diary' must be kept was reduced from four weeks in 1975-76 and 1988 Surveys to two weeks in the 1988-89 Survey . . .

Questions of fact and degree can arise in determining whether a course of action is different in these respects to be a new proposal within the meaning of subsection 6 (3). However on the basis of the advice you have provided, it appears that the 1988-89 Survey does not differ to any significant extent from its predecessors. It that is so, in my opinion the proposal in respect of the 1988-89 Survey did not answer the description of a `new' proposal within the meaning of subsection 6 (3) . . .
Accordingly, if the 1988-89 Survey is of the nature you described, tabling under subsection 3 of the ABS Act was not required prior to implementation of that Survey.

I find that very interesting. The Attorney-General's Department was not accepting any responsibility at all for the accuracy of the information that had been supplied to it. The Attorney was qualifying his legal opinion repeatedly by saying `if the information you gave me is accurate'. By this time Mr Cameron had approached the Ombudsman, who had indicated that the legality of the survey should be established before a court of law. Panic really set in, and Mr Castles again sought advice from the Attorney-General, in which he said:
The Ombudsman also advised Mr Cameron that:

If a definitive answer is necessary, then it would seem necessary for the matter to be tested in court, whether by way of application for a declaration or, perhaps, an injunction, or by defence to prosecution.
In my view, none of these possible courses of action would be satisfactory.
Honourable senators can bet they would not-not to him. He continues:
In order to minimise the possibility of legal proceedings--
he is pointing out that legal proceedings would be the last thing the Bureau wanted-

and, depending on the outcome, the risk of disruption to the activities of the ABS, I believe that the preferable course would be to table proposals for the continuation of all collections of information for statistical purposes which are currently being implemented by the Bureau and which have not been, or may not have been, the subject of a relevant tabled proposal.

So Mr Castles got the advice from the Attorney-General and belatedly decided to table the survey, halfway through its implementation. Believing that this could well have been the action the Bureau may have tried to get away with, I had taken the precaution some months before of asking the Clerk of the Senate and Professor Whalan whether, if the Bureau did try to pull this one, retrospective tabling would be legal. They both said, `Definitely not'. I do not blame them. The legislation says very clearly that, subject to subsection 4, each new proposal for the collection of information for statistical purposes by the Bureau shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament before its implementation unless the proposal is for the collection of information on a voluntary basis. We know that this survey was on a compulsory basis. I quote part of a paragraph from the advice given to me by the Clerk of the Senate. Referring to the view taken by the Attorney-General and the ABS, he said:

Such a view of the law, which does violence to the intention of Parliament and the rights of individuals, is, in my view, entirely unacceptable, and a court should not countenance it. It is time the requirements of the law took precedence to the requirements of policy, convenience and expediency in this matter . . . in so far as the ABS always intended to conduct the current survey as a compulsory one but did not table the proposal prior to its implementation, it may be argued that all the expenditure of money, and the work done, on the implementation of that proposal has been without lawful authority under the ABS Act.

They are rather serious accusations, and something that the Government repeatedly has refused to acknowledge. During the Estimates committee hearings I questioned the Bureau regarding the legality of the survey as well as about the information it gave the Attorney-General's Department when asking for its legal opinion. During the questioning, Mr Skinner of the Bureau made it very clear that the Bureau `had no plans to prosecute' the many people who had already refused to respond to the survey prior to the tabling. In other words, the Bureau well knew that the survey was illegal but was still prepared to use the information already collected illegally. The original advice to Mr Castles from his Department was that he should table the survey. I quote from a minute paper I received through freedom of information. Mr Giles, the Assistant Statistician, Social Welfare Branch, said:
The Household Expenditure Survey is the most burdensome household survey undertaken by the ABS and is also considered to be highly intrusive by some members of the community.
He concluded by saying:
I therefore seek your approval to table the 1988-89 Household Expenditure Survey.

There is a notation from Mr Sims, `No, for reasons we discussed'. The officers of the Bureau well knew that things had got into a real shambles. They well knew that their interviewers had been falsely telling people they would be fined $100 a day if they refused to participate in the survey. They well knew that, while they had received a legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department, the opinion was not worth a bumper because of the lack of information and the misleading information they had supplied to that Department. During questioning Mr Skinner was forced to acknowledge that he had not given correct information to the Attorney-General's Department when he said that the only significant change in methodology had been that the rural household diaries had changed from a four-week period to a two-week period. I pointed out that the earlier surveys were voluntary and that this one was compulsory. I said, `Would not that be a significant change in methodology?', to which he finally replied, `It certainly is significant. Yes . . .'. Yet the Attorney-General's Department had been told there was only one significant change in methodology and it had not been told about the significance of the change from voluntary to compulsory.

Mr Skinner also acknowledged that he had not sent the Attorney-General's Department copies of all the questions from the various surveys for comparison. Again, while Mr Castles had told the Attorney-General's Department that the format had remained unchanged,. there was an additional form in the survey which was required to be signed by those chosen for the survey, called the `Loan Authorisation Form', which when signed gave permission to those people's banks or lending societies to give the ABS all their private financial information. The Attorney-Generals' Department was not told about this intrusive form. It was completely unaware that such a form existed. This is the sort information that the Attorney-General's Department was given when it was asked to form a legal opinion as to whether the two surveys were virtually the same. It was on this sort of advice that the ABS sent out letters saying, `Now that we have tabled the household expenditure survey, we have removed any doubt about its legality' and telling the people who had refused to participate, `I hope you will now cooperate'.

As a layman, I am appalled that the Australian people can be hoodwinked by a government authority which is willing to rely for its legality in carrying out its functions on an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department, given on false and misleading information, and I am appalled that the Attorney-General's Department was willing to accept insufficient information, and did not request the further information it knew was required, to make an illegal opinion credible. How can the people of Australia have any confidence in the Attorney-General's Department under these circumstances? How can we rely on the letters written on Mr Castles's behalf to so many people pointing out that they now had to complete those surveys? During the Estimates hearings the Bureau acknowledged that the letter sent out to those people should never have been written.

Let me give the Senate an indication of the differences in the two surveys. I have pointed out the difference in methodology; that one was voluntary and one was compulsory. I have pointed out the difference in format; that a very intrusive form had to be signed although it did not have to be signed on a previous occasion. So let me give a very brief description of some of the differences in the questions. There were 61 additional areas of questioning in the 1988-89 survey in comparison with the 1974-75 survey. There were some 106 questions in the 1974-75 expenditure questionnaire compared with 216 questions in the expenditure questionnaire for 1988. The maximum number of feasible responses for the expenditure questionnaire rose from 577 in 1974-75 to 1,076 in 1988-89. Let me explain just how intrusive some of those questions were. People were asked: `Have you taken out any loans? What was the net amount? What was the purpose of the loan? What was your security? What were the terms of the loan?'. The questionnaire then went on to health, with such questions as: `In the last three months have you made any payments to a general practitioner or a family doctor? If so, for what sort of service?'. In other words, it asked, `Give us your full health history'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the number.

—And the number. it also asked, `What would the sale price of your house or flat be at the moment?'. There were so many questions. We come to one that asked of those who had taken out a loan on a house, `What was the purpose of the loan? What was the loan's security? What was your first mortgage or your second mortgage? Is it unsecured?'. It went on, `What sort of work do you do? Have you a second job? In your second job do you work for an employer, for wages or salary? Are you in your own business? Have you records for the financial year of July 1986-87? Please produce the previous financial year's records, the tax assessments and group certificates. How much tax was payable on your income for this period? What was the amount of the tax deduction for your earnings for this period?'. The Bureau is not the Australian Taxation Office. People were asked: `Did you receive a tax refund?. Did you pay or do you expect to pay any extra tax?.' So the questions went on-the most intrusive questions that could possibly be asked.
—How many bunches of spring onions?

—As Senator Patterson says, there are diaries to be filled out. People have to itemise every cent they spend. If they go to the supermarket to buy a litre of milk, it must be put down in the diary. If their children are given lunch money, it must be put down. If they bet on the horses or go to a casino, it has all got to be put down. It is without a doubt the most intrusive questioning that any survey has ever undertaken, yet the Bureau says it is virtually the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Following my questioning of the ABS and the Attorney-General's Department, the Ombudsman became very concerned and wrote to Mr Cameron and me expressing his worries. He has a few initial concerns, and I will just read the following from his letter:
The matters dealt with in my letter of 21 September 1988 and still outstanding are:
Whether the original 1988 HES-
household expenditure survey-
should have been tabled before implementation.
Whether some interviewers and ABS officers should be counselled against overzealous or officious assertion that the original 1988 HES was compulsory.

Then he said that there were, however, many new issues. He said that, having read the questioning in the Estimates Committee, he was now asking the Bureau of Statistics to give information on whether the Attorney-General's Department was given misleading or insufficient instruction when its opinion of the need for the tabling of the original 1988 household expenditure survey was being sought. He is asking whether the Attorney-General's Department was given sufficient and misleading information. He is also asking whether the ABS assertion that the original 1988 expenditure survey was not new, being `virtually identical' to earlier surveys, was misleading; whether the ABS assertion that the Attorney-General's Department's advice justified the original 1988 household expenditure survey was misleading; whether the ABS is correctly advising the public as to the operation of section 11 of the Census and Statistics Act; and whether the ABS assertion that the tabling of the tabled 1988 household expenditure survey makes the original 1988 household expenditure survey compulsory is misleading. He asks about the confidentiality of the survey data and the advice that his office should be giving to inquiries from members of the public concerned about their obligations to take part.

The Ombudsman tells me that he sought comments on the above matters from the Australian Statistician and that he will prepare his report in light of the response. He is presently waiting for a response from the ABS prior to putting down his report. That information, although asked for on 3 November, has not been forwarded. In reference to the Attorney-General's opinion, I quote from the Ombudsman's letter. He said:
Dear Senator Walters,

I refer to our telephone conversation on 7 November 1988 regarding whether the proposal tabled on 29 September 1988 for an Household Expenditure Survey to commence on 1 October 1988 . . . can be implemented as a compulsory survey given that preparatory work commenced prior to tabling. You provided me with copies of opinions by Mr P. O'Keefe and Professor D. Whalan on the matter.
I am raising these issues with the Australian Statistician and suggesting that he obtain the advice of the Attorney-General's Department.

We have not yet heard the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department on that matter. We have not yet heard the explanation that the Ombudsman requires from the Bureau of Statistics. I have asked the Government to stop any further interviews on its survey until the Ombudsman's report has been brought down. I have been totally ignored by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I would just like to read once again part of the opinion I received from the Clerk of the Senate when he was referring to the argument by the ABS and the Attorney-General's Department that retrospective tabling of the survey by the ABS made that survey illegal. He said:

Such a view of the law, which does violence to the intention of Parliament and the rights of individuals, is, in my view, entirely unacceptable, and a court could not countenance it. It is time the requirements of the law took precedence to the requirements of policy, convenience and expediency in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join with my colleagues in the Opposition in supporting Senator Chaney's amendments in relation to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89. In particular, I address my remarks to the maladministration of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and support the motion that the Senate condemns the Government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) coercing participation in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey in the face of substantial doubt about its validity and legal basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you all join the League of Rights?

—If Senator Walsh wants to join in this debate, he can put his name on the list. In 1973 the Australian Statistician of the day wrote to his Labor Treasurer seeking approval to conduct a household expenditure survey. He referred to the voluntary or compulsory nature of that survey and I would just like to quote him. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: (iii) replies to the survey proper would be on a voluntary basis. This would be a departure from normal practice where it is regarded as essential that virtually all respondents selected in a sample survey should supply replies. However, in this survey the questions asked are of necessity intrusive e.g. details of income) and also the task of completing diaries may be regarded as onerous by the householders. I believe it is widely accepted that the quality of information supplied by householders in answer to these questions is better if supplied voluntarily than if compulsion is used. Other countries accept a response rate in these surveys of between 65%-75% as giving valuable results. My experience in the pilot tests conducted during the feasibility study was that a voluntary collection gave a response rate within this range.

That was in 1973 and the way in which the Bureau has moved from voluntary household expenditure surveys in 1974-75 and 1975-76 to compulsory surveys in 1984 and 1988-89 is unclear. Answering questions in Estimates Committee C on 11 October on the very issue of the 1988-89 survey, Mr Skinner said:
On this occasion we believe we have got the authority to conduct this on a compulsory basis.
I do not know where he thought he got the authority but he thought he had it. He went on:

I would put it to Madam Chair that we are conducting this survey essentially in the same way that we conducted previous surveys in so far as we are seeking the willing cooperation of householders and in that we are using section 11 (1) of the Census and Statistics Act, which provides that the Bureau or the Statistician can ask questions. People who fail to answer those questions do not commit an offence; no penalty is incurred. The difference between the surveys, the 1988-89 survey and the previous two in the mid-1970s, is that if our interviewers are pressed-and I stress the word `pressed'-as to whether the survey is compulsory, in 1974-75 and 1975-76 the answer was no, and in 1988-89 and indeed in 1984 the answer was yes. However, the Bureau did not proceed in 1984, as I have mentioned, to prosecute anybody.
This claim by Mr Skinner does not sit well with two letters to the editor in the Australian dated 28 September 1988. The first one is from a constituent of mine in Box Hill, Victoria, who said:

When I objected that the questions were too personal and the information was none of the Government's business, the lady from the bureau told me that I had to answer her questions or I would be fined and she showed me a copy of the Statistics Act to prove her point.
There was another letter from somebody in Sydney whose name was supplied but who did not want his or her name to be disclosed. It said:
I didn't know I could refuse, so when they told me that I had to participate or be fined I just got angry and made up all the answers.
Please don't, under any circumstances, publish my name or Big Brother will have me in court for not telling him the truth.

That person's name was supplied to the Australian but not revealed. One of my constituents, who has been named in the other place and who was very concerned at the way she was dealt with, said that she was not prepared to answer the questionnaire. I have spent quite a lot of time speaking to her on the telephone. She was so moved that she went back and read Mill on freedom and liberty to really make sure that the stand she was taking was an appropriate stand. She decided that under no circumstances, even if it meant going to gaol, was she going to answer this intrusive questionnaire. I do not know what Mr Skinner was talking about but obviously some of the people who were confronted by the Bureau had a quite different opinion from what Mr Skinner seemed to believe was the situation. Apparently the Bureau became concerned about the attention being drawn to issues of privacy in regard to compulsory surveys. As I mentioned, when the 1986-87 report was tabled in this House almost no mention was made of this issue. A whole chapter, 13 pages in fact, was devoted to statistics and privacy in the 1987-88 report. The Bureau must have had a difficult time putting up a case for compulsory surveys.

Despite the help of the Parliamentary Library-which provides a service acknowledged too little in this place-a search of the psychological, sociological, and market research literature drew a blank. None of the articles provided, dating back to 1937, lent support to the Bureau's argument. There were a number of articles on signed versus unsigned questionnaires, on surveys where people were asked to put their names and where people were not asked to put their names, and on the lack of surveillance. But there were no studies on compulsory versus voluntary surveys. The Bureau must have been clutching at straws when it relied on a report by the West German Government to support its argument. The Bureau devotes almost two pages of its 13 page argument to this support. The ABS summarised it as follows:
It cannot, of course, be assumed that the findings of this investigation in the Federal Republic of Germany would apply in their totality in Australian circumstances.
That is a nice little qualification. The summary continues:

The results must, however, be regarded as significant-particularly when account is taken of the thoroughness of the study, the unambiguous nature of the technical conclusions and the strong support of the Government for the maintenance of compulsion in a country in which there are strong concerns for individual privacy.

If that had been a second-year university student presenting a summary of a report of the nature of the one from the West German Government, in my book that student would have failed. The Bureau may have summarised the report thus; however, I took the trouble to get a copy of the report. If one can work one's way through the obscure English translation one can only surmise that either the study was inadequate and/or that the report of the study was inadequate. Despite what the ABS would have us believe, the study only tells us about the response rates of compulsory as compared with voluntary micro-census surveys-quantitative data, not qualitative data. It does not examine the accuracy or the truthfulness of responses. It is a possibility that a percentage of those who respond in the compulsory surveys tell lies. This may distort the findings just as much as a failure to respond would do. I seek leave to table the West German report which I obtained through the Library, entitled, Experiences Resulting from the Implementation of the Microcensus Act. This report by the West German Government, dated 10 June 1985, was submitted in Bonn in January 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I will agree to its incorporation but it should have been shown to the Government before now.
—I was not seeking incorporation; I was seeking leave to table the report.
—I understand that Senator Patterson is seeking to table the document, not to incorporate it.
—But it is from West Germany and not the anonymous QC?
—It is a report from West Germany which I obtained from the Library. It is a summary obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
—It is not from the anony-mous QC who was cited as an authority in the Estimates committees? I just seek confirmation of that.
—For the third time, it is a report that I received from the Library which was purportedly obtained from the ABS. This is a report by the West German Government.
—That assurance is accepted. Leave is granted.
—I quote from the report where it talks about a micro-census being carried out in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries:

SPEECH.PARA: Spot checks comparable to the microcensus-
which is the micro-census which this report is studying-

are being carried out under obligation to give information on principle in 12 countries in the OECD realm-including the Federal Republic of Germany. Nine countries are practising voluntary giving of information.

Voluntary labour force spot checks in these countries, which-like the microcensus-are to supply safe absolute figures and rates of change up to the previous report period, achieve answer proportions lying between 81% and 95%.

We are talking about voluntary questionnaires. Other countries are getting response rates of 81 per cent and 95 per cent. The ABS failed even to mention that in its report. It talks only of the West German Government because it supports its argument. The report also states:

The distinctly higher proportions are above all obtained because the people questioned consider giving information at State surveys in the States under consideration as their duty as citizens on principle.

I suggest that if the ABS took the time to inform citizens about the importance of such a survey we might find that the Australian citizenry would also be inclined to respond. If this is the only evidence that the ABS can muster to support the need for a compulsory household expenditure survey it should go back to the drawing board. This issue of privacy and individual rights is so important that maybe the Australian Government should fund an independent study rather than rely on an inadequate report of a single study-I stress the word `single'-which it admits may not be applicable to Australia. No university department would be allowed by an ethics committee to carry out a compulsory survey with such fragile information and a study based on such poor methodology. Both the ABS report--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hardly a comparison.

—The honourable senator will have her opportunity. I hope that she has gone into as much detail. Both the ABS report and Senator Collins in his speech quoted Mr Howard's reply to the second reading debate on the Census Statistics Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. The ABS on pages 11 and 12 of its report committed the sin of selectively quoting Mr Howard. Senator Collins seems to have relied on the ABS report rather than reading the whole of Mr Howard's speech. For the record, I would like to set this matter straight. Senator Collins, as did the ABS, quoted a quite substantial amount of that speech and then went on to quote the third paragraph, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: What we have tried to do is to balance those two aspirations as much as we possibly can. Of course we need information. Of course governments have to ask questions, whatever political persuasion they are. Of course we need sound statistical data on which to base our decisions in whatever area those decisions are. But equally there is a growing and legitimate community resentment towards over-intrusive government.
That is where Senator Collins and the ABS chose to stop, but for the record I wish to go on with the speech:

A growing number of people ask `why' when governments ask them questions. I think that is a healthy trend. I think it is a trend that we ought to encourage. It is a trend which indicates a healthy scepticism towards an automatic acceptance that just because the Government wants something it happens to be correct. I think we will find, as a thread running through all the decisions that the Government has made in this area, an attempt by the Government over the last five years to strike a balance between those two conflicting principles.

There is quite a different picture when we read the whole paragraph. I would like to leave aside now the question of the intrusion of the privacy of individuals and households and address the stand of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and its senior officers and condemn it for the contemptuous way in which it has treated this Parliament. The burden of legal opinion is, quite clearly, that the 1988-89 household expenditure survey is, under almost any definition, new. The only opinion to the contrary is that of the Department of the Attorney-General. On the evidence presented to the relevant Estimates Committees that Department quite clearly was misled by the ABS when an opinion was sought. The facts were simply not given to the Attorney-General's Department which, in turn, did not bother to check up on what the ABS had said despite the publicity surrounding the legal validity of the compulsory nature of the survey. To return to the ABS, Assistant Statistician Giles on 10 March 1988 sent a minute to the Deputy Statistician, Mr McLennan, a section of which states:
I believe that there are some compelling reasons for tabling the 1988/89 household expenditure survey.

The household expenditure survey is the most burdensome household survey undertaken by the ABS and is also considered to be highly intrusive by some members of the community. As a consequence, the survey tends to generate ministerials arising from complaints by constituents to their local members of parliament. Being able to say that the survey had been tabled and subject to parliamentary scrutiny it then becomes a very useful ABS tactic. I therefore seek your approval to table the 1988/89 household expenditure survey.
To this a handwritten annotation was made by Mr G. Sims, which reads:
Mr. McLennan
Mr Edwards

Our policy outlined in the ABS Parliamentary Liaison Procedures Manual, suggests that tabling is unnecessary in this case (see extract attached). However, I would accept Mr Giles' arguments as consistent with the purposes of the tabling proposals-HES has a greater impact than other household surveys on reporting load and raises more questions about ABS ``intrusion''. I recommend tabling.
G. Sims

Notwithstanding that these officers have, I believe, wrongly interpreted the policy on tabling, the comments of Assistant Statistician Giles show an attitude to this Parliament and its members which is, to say the least, arrogant. The response of the Statistician to this recommendation for tabling was, `Mr. Sims, no, for reasons we discussed'. It does not take much imagination to divine those reasons: the growing concern about activities of the ABS and the very complaints mentioned and made by members of parliament during the 1984 survey. From June onwards the legal opinions began to flow in, one after the other. Among them were two which I had requested through the Clerk of the Senate, confirming the view that the HES was indeed `new' and therefore, to be compulsory, must be tabled.

Did the ABS admit that it had been wrong? No. It indulged itself in an orgy of criticism of members and servants of this Parliament who had been properly discharging their duty. Then late in the day, on Thursday, 29 September, the ABS hurried into the Parliament a collection of proposals numbered 13 to 57, of which No. 50 was the HES. And here we have the contemptuous act. This so-called `new' proposal was to commence a mere two days later, on 1 October. It was not a new proposal at all, just the old proposal dressed up in new clothes. What do the ABS's own guidelines tell us about tabling proposals? The guidelines state:

Proposals to collect statistical information from households or individuals can not be tabled retrospectively. For this reason, and because of the emergency nature of the provision for retrospective tabling, it should be assumed that all proposals, must be tabled while the Parliament is in session, and before the collection commences.

There is no set deadline, before the commencement of a collection, by which a proposal must be tabled. However, it is desirable to table four sitting weeks before the intended commencement date for the collection. To allow for internal ABS clearance, advice to the Minister, and arrangements for physically tabling in the Parliament, draft documentation should be handed to the Secretariat not less than seven weeks before the commencement date planned for the new statistical collection. It is the responsibility of subject matter areas to ensure that this is done.
The lead-time should be regarded as a minimum because proposals can be tabled only when Parliament is sitting.

As this was the same old survey-not compulsory-it became not one whit more compulsory after 1 October than it had been before. One has to wonder at the justification the Statistician gave for this belated decision to table any proposal at all, let alone 45 of them. He was `bearing in mind the desirability of exercising an ``abundance of caution'' '. Why did the Statistician not exercise this abundance of caution months ago? Despite all the disclaimers of the tabling document for these 45 proposals, the whole of the action of the Statistician is directed at undoing the damage done in his note of 16 March, which said:
Mr Sims, no, for reasons we discussed.

And what was the reason? Essentially it was the lack of compelling evidence of the need for a compulsory survey. I digress here to comment on a statement made by Senator Collins last Thursday when he was debating Senator Sheil's Census and Statistics Amendment Bill:

Subsection 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 provides that each new proposal for the collection of information has to be laid before both Houses of Parliament before its implementation-which is also subject to disallowance.

All the advice I have sought says that this is not the case. Yes, new proposals must be tabled, but they are not subject to disallowance. Senator Collins, in response to an interjection I made during his speech, said that he hoped I would have treated the debate more seriously. My reply to Senator Collins, if he were here, would be that I hoped that he would have treated the debate more seriously and got his facts right. The fact is that this Parliament cannot disallow a compulsory survey even if it is tabled. I would have hoped that, given the importance of this issue for the rights and privacy of individuals and the sensitivity of the issue, the Statistician, rather than haggling over whether this proposal should have been tabled or should not have been tabled, would have followed the advice of his own junior officers to table the proposal.

The contempt in which the Statistician has held this Parliament is sufficient evidence for this Parliament to take immediate steps: first, to review the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act to ensure that any surveys that are to be carried out compulsorily are justifiable; and, second, that mechanisms should be put in place through legislation, because of the sensitivity and the possibility of infringing rights of individuals, to allow appropriate scrutiny by this Parliament of proposals for surveys.

I have taken the opportunity afforded by the amendment in relation to the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to explain why I wholeheartedly support the motion that the Senate condemn the Government for coercing participation in the ABS household expenditure survey in the face of substantial doubt about its validity and legal basis.
