TALK.START.PARA: —This action is all the more incredible when one considers that the Better Health Commission report states that improving nutrition of individuals is the single most effective means of improving the health of the community. I would have thought that the Government's approach to health would be towards improving generally the health of the community-prevention rather than the expensive cures. The Government has attempted to cut back on the range of pharmaceuticals available. It is obviously attempting to rein in costs, but surely the first priority should be the better health of the community. Of course, to achieve that we need the research that gives the information which will lead to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government now is making a great deal of its new health for all program, the spending of $20m on health which will have a major focus on nutrition and health conditions-health and food nutrition relationships with things such as hypertension, cancer and other conditions. I wonder how many glossy brochures will appear under the heading `Health for all Australians', what opportunities there will be for photographs of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others in publicising the program. The Priority One program springs to mind. It was to provide jobs. It provided lots of glossy brochures; not a lot of jobs. I hope we are not having a repeat of that.

Instead of providing the additional resources one would expect to strengthen scientific activities which are the basis of such a program, the staff positions are being cut and the scientific program is being moved into another, non-scientific area. There is justified concern that no other agency, government or private, has the responsibility or necessary expertise to provide the scientific research for major aspects of the better health program. One is therefore entitled to question how cost-effective the expenditure of $20m plus the matched amounts from the States can be if the scientific work is cut. One once again asks whether science is the victim with this program.

Questionable indeed is the placement of long-established activities in the Department into a short term program area with the consequent staff reductions that I have referred to. Nutrition and its scientific basis are being put into a non-scientific area. I suggest it is jeopardising the 50-year history of scientific public health nutrition activity for the sake of this short term program. I am not referring so much to the job losses but to the loss of the scientific functions.

What sort of functions am I referring to? Work on the composition of foods that I have mentioned, the nutritional intake of Australians and fatty acids in the Australian diet is just an example. The significant work that this group has done is absolutely fundamental to the National Health and Medical Research Council. I believe that national repercussions will flow to the assessment of scientific and public health information. It will mean that legislative, industrial, professional users of the information and the references which have been developed will be deprived of access to a body of information and expertise held nowhere else in Australia. It probably will not even be able to be maintained on a proper basis. As I said, there is no other government agency or body responsible for or established for these activities. Consumer protection aspects of food safety could be lost. Who will check the nutritional adequacy of the Australian diet? Who would protect against spurious health claims? The Government's decision to give the unit the additional functions to service the health for all programs with fewer resources is, I suggest, short-sighted.

There is, though, another aspect of cutbacks in the scientific area that I want to refer to while I have the opportunity tonight: nutrition is not the only area that is suffering. I recently received a letter concerning the curtailment of services to the National Poisons Information Service, which is important to this country. The National Poisons Register, which provides a service directly affecting community health, is mentioned as another area where no work will be done as a result of staff cuts. I refer to a letter to me from the Pharmacist-in-Charge of the Australian Capital Territory Poisons Information Service at the Royal Canberra Hospital in which she said:

This register contains data on products of all types provided to the Department by manufacturers, agents and importers. The data is evaluated for its toxicological significance by an appropriately trained departmental scientist. The material, plus management material is then distributed, on microfiche, regularly, to all state poisons services and some hundreds of designated hospitals, and is used as a basis for arriving at appropriate poisons management for the public, by doctors, pharmacists, nurses and other health professionals.

Appropriate poisons managements starts with knowledge of what is in the substance to which the patient has been exposed. Only then can the correct treatment be instituted. Speed of identification is vital. This generally means minutes, rather than hours or days.

When information is not available quickly enough, the patient must then be treated and/or observed at a medical facility . . . as for exposure to an unknown poison, then the most appropriate care may be readily available at home.
Besides being a very costly procedure, unnecessary trauma to these patients may result.
At any time, when a member of the public rings a poisons service following exposure, immediate advice can be given using the resources of the National Poisons Register . . .

It seems incredible that the Government could even contemplate cutbacks such as would threaten the future of the important work of the Poisons Information Service. Yet it has been identified as one of the areas targeted by the Government for expenditure cuts. There are others, such as in the area of environmental health. For example, there have been suggestions that the Department's environmental health section, which supports committees monitoring and regulating the nation's air and water quality, will be abolished. So the reality of what is happening to the funding of the scientific functions within the Department of Community Services and Health belies the Minister's claims to me when he answered my questions directed specifically to the matter of nutrition, to which I referred earlier.

I suggest that the Government should look beyond the short term expedient of its glossy brochures. It should consider the long term obligation to preserve the expertise which has been built up within these areas of the Department in which significant scientific research has been undertaken. It should build on that expertise, not cut it out. I hope that the Government will reconsider what I regard as its misplaced priorities and ensure that adequate funding will allow the scientific functions to which I have referred to continue to be carried out effectively. It should not merely use this word `efficiency' to cover up cutbacks of the kind that I have dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks in the debate on the Appropriation Bills to a few specific areas that, hopefully, have not yet been covered by all speakers. Before turning to the specific areas that I wish to consider, it is perhaps time once again to reflect in what direction Australia is heading. Despite assertions to the contrary by our Treasurer (Mr Keating), Australia still has a long way to go before it can retreat from heading down the Argentinean road about which we heard so much of a couple of years ago. The latest balance of trade deficit confirms this point. We have a deficit of $1.6 billion; yet the Government tells us continually that it is still the greatest government.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some improvement in the unemployment rate. This time last year the figure was about 7.6 per cent and at present it is about 6.4 per cent. We should bear in mind, of course, that a new bunch of school leavers is about to join the job market. Increased employment can be mainly attributed to the buoyant mining, agriculture and building trade sectors. While the two great industries of agriculture and mining employ immense numbers of people, the multiplier effect means that extra labour is employed in related and service fields, such as in the manufacturing sector. I refer to the manufacture of machinery and chemicals and to a host of other enterprises. Transport, to which I will refer later, relies on agriculture and mining for a vast amount of its turnover.

The buoyant housing sector, brought about in no small measure by the drop in interest rates 12 months ago, the removal by the Government of the ban on negative gearing on rented properties and the placing of capital gains tax on everything except private housing, have contributed to the uplifting in employment in Australia. Interest rates are again a point of concern. If the present uplift continues as it has in the last couple of months, there will be the same round of mortgagee sales in about six months time as occurred after the last disastrous interest rates hike.

I want to refer to a couple of articles which bear out what I am saying. The Treasurer is increasing interest rates as a tool to slow down the overheating economy. But the effect of using that tool depends on what part of Australia's economy one belongs to. As a farmer, I am not responsible for the overheated economy which has been brought about by a reliance on excessive imports. The farmers are providers, along with the mining industry, of exports. I do not believe that we should share in this high interest rate hike. The overheating of the economy has been caused by sections of secondary industries that have been tied to the Government's apron strings for far too long. Many of them have been receiving what has been called temporary assistance since about 1900. It is time that they were put out on their own to compete with the rest of the world on an even playing field, in the same way as the agriculture and mining industries do, to see whether they can improve-and improve smartly-without giving in to every union demand that may be made.

An article which I consider should be compulsory reading for all members of this chamber-not only those who are present at the moment-was written by Senator Stone and appeared in the Australian of Thursday, 24 November 1988. He said:

The Government's decision to raise interest rates stems from Mr Keating's belated acceptance that the balance of payments deficit is again blowing out. Unless demand for imports can be checked, in six months the situation will be clearly inappropriate for measures such as his promised major real tax cut, which will add to that demand and worsen the balance of payments even more.
The 1988-89 Budget once again failed to cut the Commonwealth's own spending programs (as distinct from cutting back on funding for the States).

The Government cut funding to the States, but it failed to cut its own spending. Senator Stone said that the welcome move to a Budget surplus had been achieved by a much higher tax intake. The Government chose, yet again, to spend this as it went along. The article continued:
The real heart of Australia's economic problems today is in any case centred on our appalling productivity performance. This is an area where the Government has talked but done little.

In this article Senator Stone referred to a new document produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on productivity entitled Australian National Accounts: Gross Product Employment and Houses worked. It gives an estimate of real gross domestic product, that is GDP, per unit of labour-in short, labour productivity-in terms of both the number of persons employed and the number of hours worked. Two alternative calculations were proposed. I will refer to the one that is kindest to the Government. During the last three years since we turned the corner on the Argentinean road, using the GDP measure, we find that there was only a 1.6 per cent productivity improvement, which equates to 0.5 per cent per annum. The other method is calculated in terms of GDP per hour worked. The increase in productivity terms was even less, and equated to 0.4 per cent per annum. Of course, that shows in which area Australia is falling down. This Government has done nothing whatsoever to increase productivity. As I have said many times, it is only our exporting industries, agriculture and mining, that are helping our balance of payments situation.

I do not want to sound like the prophet of doom this evening, or at any time for that matter. I am mostly the opposite. I am normally an optimist. But, if this Government keeps using interest rates as a tool to combat the current account deficit, I am afraid that doom will soon arrive. On the point of housing, I must condemn the Government for failing to attract suitable migrants, those skilled migrants in the building trades, to overcome the shortage of skilled tradesmen in this industry. I have said time and time again in this place that there is a housing boom in Australia at present. We go nowhere near attracting the labour we need from overseas. We certainly do not have the labour we need in Australia.

While migrants today are being comfortably set up in businesses, professions or fast food chains or as social security customers, they are not being sought to take up the slack that exists, that is, in country areas or in the building trades. I know that we have interest from bricklayers from the United Kingdom. What does this Government do? It does not even class bricklaying as a trade. Is it because of endless restrictions or union pressure? In the past year the rate for bricklaying has risen from $250 per thousand to at least $450 per thousand and that, incidentally, is in the city. There is a list a kilometre long every morning in the papers of advertisements for bricklayers to fill the shortage. While the shortage exists in the city, how can one expect to get bricklayers in the country? Of course, the people in the country are entitled to have a style of living equal to that which is available in the city. The minimum country people can ask for, if they can afford it, is a brick house or even a brick veneer house. Prefabricated buildings lack a sense of permanency when they are erected.

I now turn to specifics. I, firstly, address industry's greatest asset or liability, that is, road funding. There is a need now for a more generous distribution of road funding to the States, bearing in mind the total collected in the name of roads, so that road construction and maintenance can proceed at a rate that meets the demands made on roads because of increased mining and tourist activity, et cetera.

As every senator will no doubt know, the Government collects in excess of $6 billion in fuel taxes but spends only $1.2 billion on road improvements. The figure of $1.2 billion has remained static for the last four, now approaching five, years. It gives an effective reduction in road funding, in real terms, of approximately 40 per cent over that time. As I said, the Government returns to the taxpayer only $1.2 billion or, one-fifth of what it collects. In other words, of the 21.53c per litre that is collected, only 4.76c per litre goes back to the road user.

If the Government were serious and prepared to take the matter on, it would need to allocate only another 2c to make a figure 6.76c per litre out of the 21.53c figure and that would provide an extra $420m per annum. That figure would go a long way to making roads more efficient and safe. At present at least 30 per cent of accidents are attributed to the roads because of broken surfaces, potholes, bad camber, narrow lanes, sharp curves, blind corners and poor signposting.

Additionally, I wish to mention the situation of some constituents of mine, who live in the cattle country near Wyndham in Western Australia. When I was there in June they pointed out to me that the only way they could go to take stock 400 miles east to market, which would be to Katherine, I presume, would be by going immediately west via Derby and to get around the Top, and that would add an extra 800 kilometres. This is a disgraceful situation. It is an act of irresponsibility for the Government not to allocate funding so that primary producers can get their product out when it is supposed to go to market and not have to do so at only certain times of the year when the weather changes, by which time the beef may have gone off.

With reference to the priority of roads, there is a cut from the centennial roads grants for next year. Honourable senators should note that we are going from the bicentennial road development scheme which was implemented by Malcolm Fraser in about 1980-81. It was a very successful program that tried to bring the roads of Australia up to the standard that Australia deserves. I notice that there is a cut in spending to come.

More responsibility should be shown by the Commonwealth and the States themselves in agreeing on what major roads are to be upgraded. In Western Australia we have had the case of the Great Northern Highway which goes through Newman and eventually finishes up at Port Hedland. The bitumen goes only as far as Newman, just as it did quite a few years ago. The rest of the highway is gravel. The obvious and logical course to follow would have been to bituminise that highway as part of the north-west highway. But for some unknown reason the Labor State Government under Peter Dowding-a temporary State government, I can assure honourable senators-probably aided by the Commonwealth Government, although I am not too sure about that, decided to build a completely new road of about 400 kilometres for the tourist trade but it did not fit in with any mining whatsoever. Someone's priorities were mightily wrong.

I now turn to shipping. Honourable senators are well aware that shipping, especially coastal shipping, has a lot to do with the freight rates and costs around Australia for mining, agriculture and other industries. In the mid-1980s, following the report of the Crawford Committee on the Revitalisation of Australian Shipping, incentives were provided to encourage unions to reduce manning levels on dry bulk carriers and coastal tankers from the mid and high 30s to the mid and high 20s.

In association with the provision of new vessels and the refitting of others, a 20 per cent reduction in manning levels was accomplished. When the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC) was established in 1986, further recommendations were made in an effort to bring manning levels into line with compatible countries. Again this was connected to vessel acquisition and modification which would permit reductions in manning levels.

However, by June 1988 only one MIDC vessel had been introduced. Additionally, in the IAC report on coastal shipping it is pointed out that the manning benchmark under the MIDC is still 20 per cent to 30 per cent higher than applies to vessels of other maritime countries with a similar standard of living. By mid-year less than 25 per cent of coastal shipping had been replaced with lower manning levels. The average manning level on vessels exceeding 1,000 tonnes dry weight was still 30. Clearly, we have a long way to go.

Clearly more remains to be done through government initiatives and consultations to achieve the desired results. Ship based operating costs have improved during the 1980s but our levels are higher than those of other maritime nations, due to capital, crew, fuel, port charges and other costs such as repairs and maintenance. I refer honourable senators to a section of the IAC report where it refers to the cost component in millions of dollars. The capital cost for coastal shipping was $4.365m; the figure for crew was $2.883m; the figure for fuel was $2.040m; the figure for other costs was $1.953m; and the figure for port charges was $1.814m. This totalled $13.055m.

In respect of capital costs, provisions of the Navigation Act with added union demands lead to extra costs for current Australian new and second-hand vessels meeting manning levels and accommodation demands which are, as mentioned, higher than in comparable countries. For example, a 100,000 dead weight tonnes bulk carrier's initial operation costs are up by $2m and its annual operating costs by $0.25m, when complying with these requirements. I will not go through all these things, but our crewing costs when compared with those of other countries are completely unreasonable. Australian ship operators employ 2.2 crew per berth compared to 1.5 per berth in Western Europe. This means that the cost of employing 31 crew members in Australia equates with employing 69 crew members in Europe; that is, crew costs per berth are inflated by 30 per cent, a cost impost of $29,000 per berth annually or $0.09m in overall annual impost costs. To move to MIDC crew levels and requirements would save $1.6m, which is 12 per cent.

The negotiation factors related to crewing levels are determined by the Navigation Act, which places sea going unions in a very powerful position because ship operators do not have access to alternatives. Costs are also exaggerated by the operation of the seamen's engagement system which, as honourable senators probably know, is a pooled employment scheme which involves administrative costs and the payment of attendance money to eligible seamen not assigned to a ship. We could go on all night about this. I think honourable senators know full well the story about shipping around Australia and the cost it adds to agriculture, mining and manufacturing.

I now turn to local government. One of the major issues of concern to some shire councils in my State of Western Australia concerns the program under which they have taken control of airstrips from the State or Federal Government. I think five years ago the aerodrome local ownership plan was developed, whereby local shires took over their own airstrips and maintained them on a joint basis with funding from the Federal Government. I am afraid the Federal Government has reneged on a lot of the deals that were made. The Government has announced that no more funds will be available this financial year or the next financial year. In the meantime, shires such as Kununurra have had to increase their passenger charges by 166 per cent.

Honourable senators may have read in the press in the last few days about the case of Port Hedland in Western Australia. Five years ago the shire took over the local airport under the local ownership plan. Before the takeover the Government was supposed to spend $240,000 to bring it up to scratch. I do not know whether the Government ran out of time or money, but this was not done. So the shire was asked to take over the airport-which it did-and the Government was to spend the $240,000 later on. Since 1983 the Shire of Port Hedland has allocated some $350,000 to match what the Government should have given it, but the Federal Government has failed to come up with its contribution. Not only that, but the Government has also failed to spend the $240,000. So we now have an airstrip that can take 737 aircraft and smaller. A 727 can land and so can a 767, I believe, but when they get to the end of the runway they cannot turn around. So it is impossible to use this airstrip for big aircraft. Port Hedland has been endeavouring in the last few years to get on the tourist run, along a route which would start in Cairns and from there go to Alice Springs, to Port Hedland and out of the country, or vice versa. So the shire has been trying to get the airport up to scratch for that purpose.

In addition to wanting to provide the people who live in the Pilbara region with the ability to get into and out of the country on holidays, the shire wanted to develop, in conjunction with about four other shires, the tourist potential of the Hamersley Ranges area of Western Australia. For the benefit of those who have not seen the Hamersley Ranges, they would rival Kakadu National Park any day-and not only that, it also has a climate that allows it to be visited nine months of the year. Probably only in January and February would it be too uncomfortable to visit whereas, from my observation, I would say that there are only five months in which one can visit Kakadu National Park.

So since 1983 the shire in Port Hedland has been promised money from the Federal Government to upgrade its airport. This year's Budget has been brought down, and the Government has said an allocation will not be made in next year's Budget either. If I am right the only allocations for airports under the local ownership plan were about $0.09m for an airport somewhere up in north Queensland and a very small amount somewhere else and, as I have indicated, it has already been said that there will be no allocation next year. When the shire took over the airport in 1983 it had a budget of about $700,000 to complete the whole aerodrome and bring it up to national standard. But this delay has caused the cost to go up to such an extent that I now believe it would take close to $2m to bring that airport up to scratch, and unfortunately Port Hedland shire has decided to go it alone and bring the terminal generally up to scratch so that it can at least be used. But obviously millions of dollars must be spent on the strip and the shire will not be able to handle that itself.

My time is coming to a close and I would like to mention quickly the wheat industry. I have seen no allocation in the Appropriation Bills for wheat underwriting for next year. That causes me concern. As honourable senators will know, new wheat marketing legislation is being considered and I am worried about the sort of wheat marketing Act we may have next year.

I would like also to mention briefly the lack of funds allocated to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for the improvement of regional transmitters. As honourable senators will know, parliamentary broadcasts have already been shifted to standby transmitters, pending the completion of more powerful transmitters, but no money has been allocated and it does not look like it will be for a while. Parliamentary broadcasts are not my only concern. There will certainly be a lack of communications facilities for other purposes as well. Also, I was very saddened to see in the press reports of the cutbacks to the allocation for rural information programs such as the Country Hour.

I finish by pointing out that since this Government has been in power it has let the current account deficit rise out of all proportion and, while cutting spending where it is needed most, it wants to increase taxes to record levels. I am very disappointed, and these problems are problems that we will address when in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not so long ago that all of us were impressed by the pictures we saw and the stories we read of the floods in Bangladesh and the tragedy that befell that country. But, as so often happens, after seeing the stories on television and the photographs in the newspapers for two or three nights, for most of us that is just about the end of it. Those in Bangladesh cannot escape so easily and will be living with the consequences of the disaster for some considerable time. I was pleased to see Australia follow up its initial response of providing $350,000 in financial aid and $1m worth of food and material aid with a $25m aid program over three years. This was a recognition of the long-term nature of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: It is hard for us to come to terms with the enormity of what has occurred. I would like to cite some of the statistics. The area that has been affected by the floods is 83,709 square kilometres; the number of people affected is 45 million; 70,000 hectares of crops were wiped out; more than 12 million homes were completely destroyed and about 24 million were partially destroyed; a million cattle were lost; and 60,000 kilometres of roads, 600 kilometres of railway lines, 44 bridges, and more than 8,000 educational institutions were damaged or destroyed. One can hardly take in the enormity of these figures.

Part of the task ahead for the country is to rebuild its infrastructure and re-establish its crops and agricultural areas devastated by the floods, just in order to feed the population. However, if this effort is not to be in vain there is another aspect to what must be done to aid the people of Bangladesh, and that relates to flood prevention. Floods in South East Asian countries are occurring with increasing frequency. Waters pour down from the Himalayas onto the plains not only of Bangladesh but also of India, which had a considerable amount of its territory flooded, and of China. The main rivers contributing to the Bangladesh flood were the Ganges, the Megna, the Brahmaputra and their tributaries, all of which originate outside Bangladesh, in the Tibetan Plateau and in the Himalayas, and have traversed China, Nepal, Bhutan, India and Bangladesh before arriving at the Bay of Bengal.

Meaningful flood measures will require the cooperation of a number of governments in the area. More interest needs to be taken in the problem. A joint program is needed for any real progress to be made. In the interests of the peoples of the whole region, not just Bangladesh, the international community must bring its expertise to the problem to ensure that efforts are made to bring these countries together to come up with a solution. Without that, the tragedy we have seen this year is likely to be repeated.

I hope that the Australian Government will pursue the matter-in addition to the money that has been given-whenever it is able to in one of the international forums. Australia should use its influence in the United Nations and other forums to see that what expertise is available is given to the countries in the region. Having given aid, we should not forget that the flood has occurred, but should continue to look for ways to solve the problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will action be taken against Queensland authorities for shooting 40,000 more Red Kangaroos than allowed by their commercial quota for 1988; if so, what action will be taken; if not, what purpose is serviced by setting kangaroo quotas.

(2) Does the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service statement contained in a press release of 4 July 1988 that no harvest quotas for Red Kangaroos or Wallaroos was agreed for 1988 mean that the Queensland Government does not accept quotas and programs endorsed by the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1988 quotas for Queensland were announced on 18 May 1988 following approval of the Queensland management program under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, analysis of population data and consideration by the National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos. The Queensland Minister and his wildlife authority were dissatisfied with the quota levels established for Red Kangaroos and Wallaroos and sought a review. The commercial harvesting of these two species was halted by Queensland authorities on 11 June 1988 for Red Kangaroos and 9 July 1988 for Wallaroos. Although aerial surveys of the Queensland pastoral zone in late May 1988 indicated that population of these two species had increased, I was not prepared to entertain a review of the quotas given that the quota for Red Kangaroos had been exceeded.

As a consequence of problems with quota compliance during 1985, all States operating approved kangaroo management programs gave undertakings in 1986 to improve the administration of the commercial kill to ensure quota compliance. Since then, the quota system has functioned successfully as an additional safeguard to ensure conservation of the species involved by setting a conservative upper limit on the total commercial kill for each species.

Although Queensland had administrative problems with the Red Kangaroo quota this year, compliance has been achieved for Wallaroos and greater care is being taken to ensure compliance for Eastern Grey Kangaroos and Whiptail Wallabies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the schedule for full implementation of the Hamilton Report `Supporting Service Families'.
(2) Are there particular recommendations contained in the Report that will not be implemented; if so, what are they.
(3) Are there recommendations that will be implemented in part; if so, what are they.
(4) Are there recommendations that will be modified; if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All of the recommendations made in the Hamilton Report `Supporting Service Families' have been formally considered and the majority have been, or are being implemented. A number of matters are not yet resolved and negotiations on these are continuing. No firm timings can be given.
(2) After formal consideration it was decided that Recommendations A-36 `Co-ordinated Family Support Structure' and A-8 `Dependent Health Services' would not be implemented.
(3) Recommendation A-11d `Local Information Kits' has been implemented in part.

(4) Recommendations A-3c `FILS Functions', B-4 `Reunion Travel', B-5 `Child Care During Removal' and B-7 `Removals for Separated Spouses' have been implemented in a modified form, and recommendation B-6 `Old Locality Housing Assistance' has been agreed in a modified form and awaits Determination action to implement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the Defence Force separation figures given in the `fact sheets' issued by Defence Public Relations for each month since 1 July 1987 compiled using exactly the same criteria as the detailed Australian Defence Force statistics issued prior to 1 July 1987; if not, what are the details of changes to the original criteria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Defence Force separation figures given in the `fact sheets' issued since 1 July 1987 and those in the Australian Defence Force Statistics issued prior to 1 July 1987 are based on exactly the same criteria.

As mentioned by Mrs Kelly in her press release at that time, the object of the changes was to give a clearer picture of actual personnel numbers in the ADF by presenting year-to-date average strengths.

Although figures for separations and enlistments in the `fact sheets' were consolidated into fewer groups, the total numbers in each case were clearly identified as they had been in the previous publication.

In the interest of giving an even more meaningful analysis of the separation statistics the actual separations were separated from February 1988 into six distinct categories (pension eligible, pension ineligible, reserves leaving full time duty, temporary/involuntary, officer cadets and trainees) but without changing the established criteria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the survey of Australian Defence Force Working Hours as announced by the Chief of the Defence Force on 4 August 1987 (Department of Defence Press Release number 119/87) begun; if so, when did it commence.
(2) What will be the cost of the survey.
(3) When is it due to end.
(4) When will the results be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Planning for a survey to assess the working hours and activities of the members of the Australian Defence Force was commenced in late 1987. A design brief for the survey, produced by a consultancy group, was presented to Headquarters Australian Defence Force on 23 May 1988. The design brief was referred to the Department of Industrial Relations on 9 June 1988 to obtain their agreement regarding the methodology to be used for the survey.

(2) The final cost of the survey is not known at this time. Tenders from consultancy organisations, to assist with the survey, will be called when the Departments of Defence and Industrial Relations have reached agreement as to the methodology to be employed to conduct the survey. Accurate cost estimates will not be available until these tenders are received.
(3) A completion date for the survey has not yet been determined. At least 12 months will be needed to conduct the survey once the methodology has been decided upon.
(4) The results will be released after the survey and analysis of the results has been completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister advise what is the status of the application by the maker of the Giocattolo sports car in Caloundra, Queensland, for the duty-free importation of a component known as a transaxle from West Germany.
(2) Is it true that this component is not made in Australia and duty will add approximately $6,000 to the cost of the car.
(3) In view of stated efforts to support manufacturing in Australia and in this case an import-competing industry, what is the delay in granting duty-free exemption for this component.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I wrote to the Managing Director of the sports car manufacturer, Giocattolo Motori Pty Ltd, on 19 August 1988 to advise the company that I could not accede to its request for duty-free entry for transaxles additional to that already available to the company.

The Government's By-Law for Export Scheme is relevant to the company's plans. The Scheme is part of the Government's strategy to encourage the development of innovative, export-oriented companies. It provides the opportunity for duty-free entry into Australia for most of the transaxles involved because of the company's stated intention to export the majority of its vehicles.
(2) It is correct that transaxles are not manufactured in Australia at present. In representations to me, the company has claimed that the duty would add $6,000 to the cost of the vehicle.

(3) The question of any delay in granting duty-free entry for the company's imports of transaxles does not arise. As indicated in (1) above duty-free entry for most of the transaxles involved is already available. For the small proportion of Giocattolo vehicles which is destined for the domestic market, duty free entry of transaxles would put at risk the continuing success of the PMV Plan. Given the major economic benefits to all Australians of a successful outcome of the Plan, this is a risk the Government is not prepared to take.
